Unit 1 Characteristics and Classification of Living Organisms 
 
Characteristics of Living Organisms 
â€¢ Living organisms are classified into 5 groups: animals, plants, fungi, prokaryotes (bacteria) and 
protoctists 
â€¢ There are 7 main characteristics carried out by all organisms 
Nutrition 
â€¢ Obtaining of food to provide energy and substances needed for growth and repair 
â€¢ Plants: involves photosynthesis and taking up of mineral ions from soil (autotrophs) 
â€¢ Animals: Eat plants to gain energy and nutrients (ingestion) which is used for growth and repair 
(heterotrophs) 
Respiration 
â€¢ Involves the chemical reactions that release energy in the cells 
â€¢ Glucose + oxygen  
 
carbon dioxide + water + energy 
â€¢ Energy is used for growth and repair 
Movement 
â€¢ Organisms move a part or parts of themselves in order to change their position or place. 
â€¢ Plants move slowly whilst growing, and leaves change position to absorb more light 
â€¢ Animals move part of whole body to obtain food or flee predators 
Excretion 
â€¢ The removal of waste products formed during metabolism 
â€¢ Plants store their waste in leaves, which subsequently fall off 
â€¢ Animals breathe out Carbon dioxide and produce urine  
Sensitivity 
â€¢ Organisms sense stimuli and respond to them 
â€¢ Plants move their leaves according to the position of the sun, or they open and close their 
flowers 
â€¢ Animals have sensory glands and organs which detect light, sound pressure, etc. 
Growth 
â€¢ Permanent increase in size and dry mass 
â€¢ Increase in cell number, cell size or both 
â€¢ Plants grow throughout their life, animals stop at a certain size 
Reproduction 
â€¢ A process which results in the formation of new individuals 
â€¢ Asexual reproduction is whereby one parent creates the offspring, there is no genetic variation, 
and the individual is genetically identical to the parent 

â€¢ Sexual reproduction is whereby two parents gametesâ€™ fuse to create a new individual who carries 
a mixed set of genes 
Classification 
â€¢ Kingdom 
â€¢ Phylum/Division 
â€¢ Class 
â€¢ Order  
â€¢ Family 
â€¢ Genus  
â€¢ Species 
Importance of classification 
â€¢ Classification is the sorting out of living organisms into groups 
â€¢ Scientists look at the differences and the similarities to then classify organisms when it comes to 
their  morphology (outward appearance) and their anatomy (inward structure) 
Binomial system of classification 
â€¢ The binomial system consists of two names (genus and species/trivial) 
â€¢ Worldwide system used by scientists 
â€¢ Used to avoid confusion as many animals have more than one name 
Genus 
â€¢ The genus refers to a group of similar individuals that are closely related but do not interbreed 
with each other 
â€¢ The genus is always written with a capital letter 
â€¢ The name is always written in italics or underlined 
Species/trivial 
â€¢ A very similar group of individuals that can interbreed to produce fertile offspring 
â€¢ Written in small letters 
â€¢ Never used on its own 
Modern Classification 
â€¢ DNA sequencing and studying the sequencing of amino acids in proteins is more accurate than 
just observations 
â€¢ If the sequences are very similar, they are placed in the same genus/species 
Features of organisms 
All living organisms have: 
â€¢ Cell membranes 
â€¢ Cytoplasm with ribosomes and enzymes 
â€¢ DNA 
There are two main types of cells: 

â€¢ Prokaryotic: simples structure with no nucleus 
â€¢ Eukaryotic: More complex cells structure with a nucleus 
Animal Kingdom 
â€¢ Multi cellular and eukaryotic 
â€¢ Compact bodies 
â€¢ Growth occurs throughout the body 
â€¢ Need to obtain food 
â€¢ No cell walls, large vacuoles or chloroplasts 
â€¢ Have a nervous system- coordinate responses to stimuli 
Plant Kingdom 
â€¢ Eukaryotic and multicellular 
â€¢ Have chloroplasts filled with chlorophyll, cellulose, cell walls and large permanent vacuoles 
â€¢ Autotrophic  
â€¢ Roots spread through soil to absorb water and minerals 
â€¢ Grow at roots, tips and stems 
â€¢ Can be divided into two groups: flowering and non-flowering 
Prokaryote (Bacteria) Kingdom 
â€¢ Unicellular, microscopic  
â€¢ Simple cell structure 
â€¢ Spherical/rod shaped/short chains 
â€¢ Have a cell wall (Sometimes encased in a slime capsule) 
â€¢ No nucleus 
â€¢ Prokaryotic 
â€¢ Cells contain plasmids (loops of DNA in cytoplasm) 
â€¢ No chloroplasts or mitochondria 
â€¢ Some have flagella which is used for movement through liquid 
Protoctists Kingdom 
â€¢ Amoeba, algae, plasmodium 
â€¢ Unicellular/ multicellular (vary size) 
â€¢ Nucleus present  
â€¢ Prokaryotic 
â€¢ Autotrophic or heterotrophic 
Fungi Kingdom 
â€¢ Eukaryotic (Complex cell structures) 
â€¢ Cell walls and nuclei present 
â€¢ Cell walls consist of chitin 
â€¢ No chlorophyll 
â€¢ Main body is called mycelium 
â€¢ Multi/Unicellular 
â€¢ Made up of branching network of hype-releases enzymes that digests food outside the fungi 

â€¢ Saprophytic or parasitic  
â€¢ Reproduce by forming spores 
Viruses 
â€¢ ARE NOT CELLS 
â€¢ DNA/RNA surrounded by protein coat 
â€¢ Genes code for: replication and protein coat  
â€¢ Parasites: use host cell to multiply 
â€¢ Not classified in any of the kingdoms as they are not alive 
â€¢ Classified according to the type of genetic material and protein 
 coat 
Vertebrates 
â€¢ Vertebral column/spinal chord 
â€¢ Internal skeleton made from bone cartilage 
â€¢ Belong to phylum Chordata  
â€¢ Divided into 5 groups: Fish, Amphibians, Reptiles, Birds and Mammals 
Fish 
â€¢ Aquatic except mudskippers 
â€¢ Streamlined, body covered with scales 
â€¢ Fins for balance and to control movement 
â€¢ Eyes present but no ears 
â€¢ Lateral line detects pressure changes  
â€¢ Gills for breathing in oxygen dissolved in water 
â€¢ External fertilization and development 
Amphibians 
â€¢ Cold blooded 
â€¢ Moist, scale-less skin 
â€¢ Adults have 4 legs 
â€¢ External fertilization and development 
â€¢ Tadpoles breathe with gills, adults breathe with lungs on land and with skin in water 
â€¢ Examples include: toads, frogs and salamanders 
Reptiles 
â€¢ Cold blooded 
â€¢ Body covered with dry hard scales-cut water loss 
â€¢ Live on land 
â€¢ Breathe with lungs 
â€¢ Internal fertilization, lay leathery waterproof eggs 
â€¢ Development is external 
 
 

 
Birds 
â€¢ Homoeothermic 
â€¢ Have feathers and wings 
â€¢ Most can fly 
â€¢ Internal fertilization: lay shelled eggs 
â€¢ External development 
Mammals 
â€¢ Homoeothermic 
â€¢ Hairs on skin except whales and dolphins 
â€¢ Females have mammary glands for producing milk 
â€¢ Lungs for breathing 
â€¢ Internal fertilization; embryos develop inside motherâ€™s bodies  
Invertebrates 
â€¢ Do not have a spinal cord/vertebral column 
Arthropods 
â€¢ Largest group in the animal kingdom 
â€¢ Have segmented bodies, exoskeletons and jointed legs 
â€¢ Molt throughout their lives or only during early stages of development  
Crustaceans 
â€¢ Cephalothorax and abdomen 
â€¢ Chalky exoskeleton 
â€¢ Two pairs of antennae and compound eyes 
â€¢ Between 5 and 20 pairs of legs 
â€¢ Breathe using gills 
â€¢ Mostly aquatic except woodlice and some land crabs 
â€¢ Examples include: crabs, shrimps, crayfish and lobsters 
Myriapods 
Centipedes 
â€¢ Bodies are not divided into separate regions 
â€¢ Have one pair of legs on each segment 
â€¢ Fast moving herbivores 
â€¢ Powerful jaws to paralyze prey 
Millipedes 
â€¢ Two pairs of legs on each segment 
â€¢ Slow-moving herbivores 
â€¢ Feed on leaf litter 

 
Insects 
â€¢ Bodies divide into 3 parts: head, thorax and abdomen 
â€¢ 3 pairs of legs on thorax 
â€¢ Many have 2 pairs of wings 
â€¢ One pair of antennae and compound eyes 
â€¢ Breathe through spiracles 
â€¢ Waterproof cuticle to prevent water loss 
â€¢ Most can fly 
Arachnids 
â€¢ Bodies divided into 2 parts: cephalothorax and abdomen 
â€¢ Four pairs of legs and no wings 
â€¢ No antennae and several pairs of simple eyes 
â€¢ Paralyze prey with poison fangs 
â€¢ Weave silken webs with spinnerets 
Ferns and flowering plants 
â€¢ Multicellular  
â€¢ Chloroplasts make them green 
â€¢ Cellulose cell walls 
â€¢ Transport systems:  
Xylem vessels: carry water and mineral salts from roots to leaves 
Phloem tubes: transport dissolved substances from leaves to the rest of 
plant 
Ferns 
â€¢ Strong stems, leaves and roots 
â€¢ Waxy cuticle on leaves to reduce water loss 
â€¢ Live in a variety of habitats 
â€¢ Grow underground through rhizomes 
â€¢ Produce spores which are distributed via wind 
Flowering plants (Angiosperms) 
â€¢ True leaves, stems and roots 
â€¢ Reproduce via flowers that make seeds 
Shoots and Roots 
â€¢ Shoot: the part of the plant above the ground 
â€¢ Stem functions: 
1. Support the structure of the shoot 
2. Spaces out leaves  
3. Stem hold flower in position for pollination 
4. Allows transport of water and sugars via xylem and phloem tissue 

 
 
â€¢ Roots: found below the ground 
â€¢ Root functions: 
1. Anchor the plant into the ground 
2. Absorbs water and mineral ions from the soil 
Dicotyledons and Monocotyledons 
Monocotyledons 
â€¢ Grasses and cereals  
â€¢ Parallel veins on leaves 
â€¢ Leaves are narrow and long in grasses 
â€¢ Leaf shape may vary 
â€¢ Flower parts in multiples of 3 
â€¢ One cotyledon inside each leaf 
Dicotyledons 
â€¢ Broad leaves 
â€¢ Network of branching veins (net veins) 
â€¢ Flower parts in multiples of 4 or 5 
â€¢ Two cotyledons inside each leaf

Diseases and Immunity 
Disease 
â€¢ Pathogens are organisms that cause diseases (bacteria, viruses, fungi, protoctists and worms) 
â€¢ Diseases caused by these pathogens are called transmissible diseases ad they can be 
passed/transmitted from one person to another. They are also called infectious diseases 
Method of 
transmission 
Description 
Examples of diseases 
Through air 
Pathogens in tiny droplets of liquid from the airways and 
lungs of infected people 
Influenza, tuberculosis, 
common cold 
Contaminated food 
and drink 
People preparing food who do not wash their hands; 
foods that are not cooked properly; human faeces 
contaminating water supplies; flies transfer pathogens 
on their bodies 
Cholera, typhoid 
Direct contact 
Uninfected people touch infected people, or items, that 
infected people have used 
Athleteâ€™s foot 
Insect vectors 
Insects e.g. mosquitoes feed on the blood of an infected 
person and then feed on an uninfected person 
Malaria, dengue fever 
Body fluids 
Blood from an infected person enters the blood of an 
uninfected person, e.g. an unsterilized needle shared 
between drug users 
HIV/AIDs, hepatitis  
Person  activity  
Pathogens pass from uninfected person to sexual 
partner in blood, semen or vaginal fluid 
HIV/AIDs, nonspecific 
uteritis (NSU), chlamydia  
 
Defences against diseases 
1. The first line of defence prevents pathogens entering the body 
2. The second line destroys any pathogens that beak through the first line of defence 
3. The third line produces antibodies that defend us against specific pathogens  
Barriers to infection 
Mechanical barriers 
â€¢ The dead outer layers of the skin form a barrier to entry  
â€¢ The hairs in the nose trap large particles that are inhaled 
Chemical barriers 
â€¢ The stomach makes hydrochloric acid that kills pathogens in food 
â€¢ Cells that line the airways make mucus that traps dust particles and microorganisms. The mucus 
is moved away from the lungs and up in the throat by cilia. The mucus is swallowed and any 
pathogens are destroyed by stomach acid  
If any pathogens get through these barriers and enter the blood, then there is a second line of defence. 
Blood defences 
â€¢ White blood cells form a line of defence against pathogens 
â€¢ Phagocytes engulf bacteria and viruses into vacuoles where they are digested and destroyed 
(phagocytosis) 

â€¢ Lymphocytes produce antibodies  
â€¢ When activated- antibodies have a variety of effects on pathogens  
â€¢ Such as stopping pathogens from moving around the body and it easier for phagocytes to engulf 
them 
â€¢ Vaccination is a way to make lymphocytes produce antibodies and give them long term 
protection against certain diseases 
Defence against disease 
â€¢ All pathogens have chemical proteins on their surface called antigens 
â€¢ When you catch a disease lymphocytes respond by making antibodies, which can lock onto the 
surface of the pathogens 
There are several ways in which antibodies attack pathogens: 
i. 
They cause bacteria to stick together in a group, making it easier for phagocytes to find and 
engulf them 
ii. 
Some bacteria have flagellum, antibodies can attach to flagella and stop them from moving  
iii. 
Bacteria such as diphtheria and tetanus can release toxins into the blood, antitoxins ae a special 
group of antibodies which combine with toxins and neutralise them making them harmless 
iv. 
Some antibodies kill bacteria directly by punching holes through cell walls. This weakens cell 
walls so water enters by osmosis causing the cells to burst 
Immune response 
â€¢ Each type of pathogen has its own antigens which have a specific shape. The antibodies are 
made against each type of antigen that have a shape that fits around the antigen. The antibody 
has a complimentary shape to the antigen  
â€¢ When contracting an infection you will be ill and have a variety of symptoms, you will begin to 
feel better in a week or two and will be back to your normal healthy self 
â€¢ If the virus attacks the system for the second time, you will not have the same symptoms or be ill. 
Lymphocytes are responsible for this and are activated during immune response  
â€¢ You are born with a large number of different types of lymphocytes. These cells are specific to 
different antigens on the surface of different pathogens. When a pathogen invades, some 
lymphocytes respond and invade to make more cells of the same type 
â€¢ Many of these lymphocytes become bigger and fill many ribosomes attached to a network of 
endoplasmic reticulum. The antibodies are secreted into the blood and lymph and distributed 
around the body. The antibodies lock on to the specific antigens on pathogens that have invaded 
the body  
â€¢ Other lymphocytes are activated to patrol around the body looking for infected cells. When they 
find an infected cell they destroy it and stop it from producing more pathogens 
â€¢ The reason HIV is such a serious infection is that it destroys the bodyâ€™s lymphocytes that are 
responsible for much of our defines against infectious disease 
â€¢ The response to the first infection is slow  
â€¢ The response to the second attack by the same pathogen is faster 
â€¢ This process of defence against pathogens by antibody production is known as active immunity  
â€¢ Becoming immune after catching a transmissible disease and being ill is a natural way to gain 
active immunity  

â€¢ During immune response, many lymphocytes are produced- many develop into anti body 
producing cells but some do not 
â€¢ They remain in blood and lymph circulating around the body  
â€¢ These are memory cells which respond whenever there is another invasion by the same 
pathogen with the same antigens 
â€¢ During each immune response to specific pathogens, more and more lymphocytes are produced 
to stay in the body  
â€¢ Therefore when the pathogen invades the body there will be far more lymphocytes with the 
ability to produce the right antibodies 
â€¢ The response to any subsequent infection is therefore much faster and much greater  
Vaccination  
â€¢ It is possible to promote active immunity without being ill  
â€¢ This is done by injecting a vaccine that contains live pathogens, dead pathogens or antigens 
taken from the surface of proteins. 
â€¢ Each vaccine stimulates immunity to a specific type of disease e.g. measles, mumps, rubella 
â€¢ In some cases, the vaccine provides protection against a specific strain of that disease, in the 
cases if influenza diseases 
â€¢ Vaccination is an artificial way to gain active immunity 
Aspects of immunity  
Passive immunity  
â€¢  If protection is required in a hurry, antibodies may be given by injection. This provides only 
temporary immunity, but it should be sufficient to give protection. Immunity gained this way is 
passive immunity  
â€¢ Antibodies pass across the placenta and are present in the break milk, so giving a baby protection 
against diseases which his/her mother will have immunity against 
â€¢ This is also temporary as the babyâ€™s body treats the motherâ€™s antibodies as foreign and destroys 
them  
â€¢ The immunity is gained without exposure to antigens so it is safer than active immunity 
â€¢ Passive immunity is used in cases where people are at risk of  tetanus entering the body through 
open wounds 
â€¢ Health workers inject a vaccine that neutralise toxins produced by the bacteria which can cause 
muscle paralysis  
â€¢ Venom from snakes, scorpions, spiders and other dangerous animals act far too quickly for active 
immunity to be of any use 
â€¢ People who have been bitten by venomous animals need anti venom extremely quickly  
â€¢ Anti-venom contains antibodies to the molecules in the venom 
â€¢ Specialist companies collect venom from these animals and inject them in small quantities to horse 
and sheep 
â€¢ This prompts an immune response and the antibodies are collected from the blood, processed and 
made available to hospitals in areas where people are at risk of being bitten by venomous animals 
â€¢ No memory cells are produced in passive immunity, so this type of immunity is short term but 
instantaneous  
â€¢ As soon as the antibodies enter the body they are available to be used 

â€¢ There is no wait between the arrival of the antigens and the production of the antibodies as there is 
in active immunity 
Malfunction of the immune system  
â€¢ Sometimes the immune system does not work perfectly 
â€¢ When this happens it detects our own antibodies as something foreign and this prompts an 
immune response 
â€¢ As a result the immune system attacks and destroys healthy tissue by mistake  
â€¢ Malfunctions of the immune system cause a variety of diseases collectively known as 
autoimmune diseases  
â€¢ Examples are: rheumatoid arthritis, multiple sclerosis and type 1 diabetes  
Type 1 diabetes  
â€¢ This type of diabetes is caused when the immune system attacks and destroys the cells of the 
pancreas that make insulin 
â€¢ This usually happens rapidly usually before the age of 20 
â€¢ Insulin helps to control the concentration of glucose in the blood 
â€¢ It is made in response to an increase in the glucose concentration in the blood usually while a 
meal is being absorbed 
â€¢ Insulin stimulates the liver and muscles to store glucose as glycogen  
â€¢ This means that glucose is not stored for times when it will be needed by cells to release energy 
in respiration 
The symptoms of Type 1 diabetes are: 
i. 
Weight loss- cells use protein and fat instead of glucose as sources of energy  
ii. 
Thirst- this is due to the increased concentration of glucose in the blood that lowers its water 
potential  
iii. 
Tiredness due to lack of glycogen that can be converted to glucose to provide energy between 
meals  
One indicator of diabetes is the presence of glucose in urine  
People with diabetes are treated with regular injections of insulin. The drug is manufactured using 
techniques of genetic engineering and many different types are available so that diabetics can control 
their blood glucose concentration efficiently  
Controlling the spread of disease 
Preventing infection  
Personal hygiene 
â€¢ People of all ages should wash their hands after urinating or defecating and also before 
handling or eating food 
â€¢ Hair should be washed with shampoo to prevent dandruff and head lice 
â€¢ Everyone should wash themselves frequently, especially in hot weather  
â€¢ Brushing teeth regularly, and flossing to prevent dental cavities 
â€¢ Cuts and bruises washed with an antiseptic and plasters placed on open wounds  

Hygienic Food Preparation  
â€¢ Food should be covered to keep flies away 
â€¢ Kitchen surfaces should be cleaned with disinfectants to kill bacteria 
â€¢ Food should be cooked thoroughly to make sure any bacteria (e.g. salmonella) are killed 
â€¢ Cooked food should be separated from raw food 
â€¢ Water used for cooking/drinking should be boiled or sterilised by adding water purification 
tablets if it comes from sources that might be contaminated  
Proper Waste Disposal  
â€¢ Household waste should be placed in covered bins and collected at regular intervals 
â€¢ Collected rubbish should be disposed of correctly, recycled, incinerated or buried in properly 
regulated landfill sites 
â€¢ If not regulated carefully will attract rats and flies who are diseases carriers 
â€¢ Effluent from rubbish tips may contain harmful chemicals that cause pollution  
Sewage Treatment  
â€¢ Toilet water is a serious health hazard if not disposed properly 
â€¢ Human wastes are broken down by microorganisms in sewage treatment works 
â€¢ The pathogens that cause typhoid and cholera are transmitted through faeces and transmit to 
people who drink water or eat food contaminated by raw sewage  
â€¢ Thorough sewage treatment breaks down the transmission of typhoid and cholera so these 
diseases are unknown in countries with proper sanitation  
The role of vaccination 
â€¢ Vaccination programs are an important part of health  
â€¢ Infants and children are vaccinated against diseases that used to be common and responsible 
for many deaths  
â€¢ Many of these diseases are now very rare in many parts of the world 
â€¢ During eradication programmes vaccination is used in two ways: 
â€¢ Mass vaccination schemes attempt to give active immunity to everyone  
â€¢ Some do not respond to vaccines but they can be protected because the chances of them coming 
into contact with the disease are small and most people around them have immunity and will not 
transmit the disease 
â€¢ Careful surveillance by health officials identify people who have infectious diseases and the 
spread of the disease is limited or stopped by vaccinating all people who have come into contact 
with infected people  
â€¢ For some diseases there are no cure, such as HIV, Ebola and dengue fever

Bacteria Diagrams

Gas Exchange in Humans 
The Gas Exchange System 
Structure 
â€¢ 
The lungs are spongy organs found inside the chest (thorax) and are surrounded and protected by the 
sternum (breastbone). 
â€¢ 
The diaphragm is a sheet of fibrous tissue and muscle that separates the thorax from the abdomen 
â€¢ 
The movement of the diaphragm changes the volume of the lungs to move air when you breathe in and out 
â€¢ 
The intercostal muscles between the ribs move the ribs during breathing, especially during deep 
breathing  
â€¢ 
Air enters the nose or mouth and passes through the throat to the larynx (voice-box).  
â€¢ 
It then enters the trachea (windpipe), which connects the throat to the lundgs 
â€¢ 
It branches to form two bronchi which enter each kung 
â€¢ 
These continue to divide to form many bronchioles, which end in tiny air sacs called alveoli. 
â€¢ 
It is here that gas exchange takes place 
â€¢ 
The tubes through which air moves are often called airways 
â€¢ 
The larynx contains vocal chords, when air passes over these you make sounds 
â€¢ 
You cannot breather and swallow at the same time, this is because as you swallow a flap called the 
epiglottis moves to cover the opening of the larynx, this stops food from going down your trachea 
â€¢ 
The trachea is kept open by C shaped rings of cartilage. The arms of the cartilage are joined by muscles 
at the back of the trachea 
â€¢ 
The cartilage prevents the trachea from collapsing as you breathe in when the air pressure decreases 
Composition of air 
Gas Exchange Surfaces 
â€¢ 
Have a very large surface area for diffusion of gases 
â€¢ 
Moist surfaces so that gases can dissolve before diffusion 
â€¢ 
A thin surface 9only one cell thick in each alveolus) so the 
gases do not have to diffuse very far 
â€¢ 
A good supply so that lots of carbon dioxide is removed 
quickly and lots of oxygen is supplied quickly, maintaining 
concentration gradients 
â€¢ 
Ventilation of the lungs ensures that the air in the air 
passages is changed; this helps maintain the gas concentration 
gradients between air in the alveoli and that in the blood 
Gas exchange at the alveolus  
â€¢ 
Oxygen molecules from the alveolus diffuse into the red blood cells and combine with haemoglobin. The 
red blood cells can then transport oxygen to the body tissues 
â€¢ 
There is a lot of carbon dioxide in the capillary, carried from respiring tissues to the blood plasma. It 
diffuses in the opposite direction, through the capillary wall acoss the alveolar wall into the space insid 
the alveolus, from here it is breathed out 
â€¢ 
Alveoli are surrounded by elastic tissue. This stretches whilst breathing and recoils when breathing out 
to helps remove air from the lungs 
â€¢ 
The air we breathe out is saturated with water vapour that has evaporated from the moist walls of the 
alveoli

Breathing  
â€¢ 
Diaphragm and ribcage movements create changes in overall chest volume 
â€¢ 
This change in volume then causes a pressure change in the chest cavity  
Inspiration  
Expiration  
External intercostal muscles contract, internal 
intercostal muscles relax, ribs move upwards and 
outwards  
Internal intercostal muscles contract and external 
relaxes, ribs move downwards and inwards 
At the same time: muscle in diaphragm contracts 
and flattens 
Muscles in diaphragm relaxes, bulges outwards 
(organs press up from below) 
This increases the volume inside the thorax: 
decrease in overall pressure 
This decreases the volume inside the thorax, so 
therefore increases the pressure 
Atmospheric pressure is greater than thoracic 
pressure so air moves into the lungs 
Air is forced out of the lungs and alveoli (elastic 
recoils) 
 
Cleaning the Air 
â€¢ 
Air is warmed and moistened when inhaled by the nose 
â€¢ 
Hairs filter the air- removing particles and some pathogens 
â€¢ 
In the trachea, bronchi and bronchioles: 
â†’ Goblet cells secrete mucus which traps pathogens 
â†’ Ciliated epithelial cells have cilia which beat to carry mucus and trapped pathogens to the throat, 
where it is swallowed 
Rate and depth of breathing  
Breathing and exercise 
â€¢ 
Normal breathing rate at rest: 12-16 breaths per minute 
â€¢ 
Rate and depth increases with exercise because: 
â†’ Muscles need more oxygen 
 
â€¢ 
Breathing is deeper and faster in order to get more oxygen in the blood and get rid of more carbon 
dioxide 
â€¢ 
Rapid rate of respiration in muscles continues after exercise 
â€¢ 
Pulse rate remains high after exercise as the heart is still beating fast to keep up with the oxygen demand  

Depth of Breathing  
â€¢ 
An adult can take in 5l of air on their deepest breath  
â€¢ 
The vital capacity of a person is the maximum volume of air breathed out after breathing in as much air as 
possible 
â€¢ 
At rest 0.5l of air is breathed in and out 
â€¢ 
During exercise 4.5l of air is breathed in and out  
Controlling of breathing  
â€¢ 
The medulla, the part of the brain located nearest to the spinal cord, directs the signal to the spinal chord 
to maintain breathing  
â€¢ 
Breathing is an involuntary action  
â€¢ 
During exercise carbon dioxide builds up in the blood, causing pH levels to drop (blood becomes acidic) 
â€¢ 
pH change is detected by the brain which sends impulses to the diaphragm and intercostal muscles to 
contract faster, leading to an increase in rate and depth of breathing 
â€¢ 
This lowers the carbon dioxide concentration in the blood and the pH returns to normal 
â€¢ 
This is an example of homeostasis

Respiration  
Aerobic respiration  
â€¢ All cells need energy  
â€¢ Provided by burning glucose 
â€¢ The energy is released very gradually in a series of small, enzyme controlled reactions 
â€¢ Respiration is a number of chemical reactions that break down nutrient molecules in living cells 
to release energy  
â€¢ In aerobic respiration oxygen is used in the breakdown of glucose 
â€¢ Respiration takes place in all loving cells at all times 
â€¢ Most energy is released in the mitochondria 
â€¢ Cells that require a lot of energy have many mitochondria  
â€¢ Liver cells have high metabolism and have many mitochondria 
â€¢ The epithelial cells of the small intestine absorb glucose and other molecules by active 
transport, so have large numbers of mitochondria

Using energy  
Energy is required for; 
â€¢ Muscle contraction 
â€¢ Cell division 
â€¢ Absorption of nutrients in the gut by active transport  
â€¢ Sending impulses along nerves 
â€¢ Protein synthesis for making enzymes, some hormones and antibodies 
â€¢ Making new cell membranes and cell structures like the nucleus during growth  
â€¢ Keeping the body temperature constant, some energy is released in the form of heat 
Anaerobic respiration 
â€¢ Anaerobic respiration is the chemical reaction in cells that beak down glucose to release energy 
without using oxygen  
â€¢ During strenuous exercise, too little oxygen may reach the body muscles for aerobic respiration 
to supply all the energy the energy the muscles need 
â€¢ Muscle tissue respires anaerobically to release energy 
â€¢ Most of the enzyme catalysed reactions of aerobic respiration do not happen without oxygen 
â€¢ As a result glucose is not broken down to carbon dioxide and water but to lactic acid instead

â€¢ Cardiac muscle does not respire anaerobically as it would not release enough energy for the 
heart to beat properly 
â€¢ Some bacteria also respire anaerobically to make lactic acid (often used to make yogurt) 
â€¢ Yeast respires anaerobically when oxygen is absent or short in supply in their surroundings to 
make alcohol and carbon dioxide

â€¢ Plant roots respire anaerobically when land is flooded and soils become saturated with water so 
little or no oxygen is available  
â€¢ Far less energy is released from each molecule in anaerobic respiration compared to aerobic 
respiration 
â€¢ This is because glucose is not completely broken down and a lot of energy remains stored in 
lactic acid and in alcohol in the form of chemical bond energy  
Lactic acid 
â€¢ Lactic acid can slowly poison muscles and cause cramps so it must be removed from the body  
â€¢ The build-up of lactic acid in the muscles and blood, during vigorous exercise, causing an 
oxygen debt 
â€¢ The oxygen debt is repaid after strenuous exercise by breathing faster and deeper in order to 
supply more oxygen for aerobic respiration to break down lactic acid 
â€¢ Oxygen debt is removed during recovery by aerobic respiration of lactic acid in the liver 
â€¢ After exercise the heart continues to beat at a fast rate in order to transport lactic acid in blood 
from the muscles to the liver  
â€¢ The enzyme catalysed reactions that release most of the energy in aerobic respiration occur in 
mitochondria 
â€¢ These cell structures do not function without a supply of oxygen  
â€¢ During anaerobic respiration, glucose is partly broken down in the cytoplasm and alcohol or 
lactic acid is produced from the end product of this partial breakdown

In aerobic respiration oxygen is used in the breakdown of glucose . Yeast respires anaerobically when oxygen is absent or short in supply in their surroundings to make lactic acid .

Excretion 
 
â€¢ Excretion is the removal from the body of the 
waste products of metabolism, toxic materials 
and substances in excess of requirements 
Excretory products  
â€¢ Carbon dioxide made in the body tissues during 
respiration, it is transported to the lungs in the 
blood plasma 
â€¢ Urea is made in the liver from excess amino 
acids 
â€¢ Substances that are excreted are produced by 
cells during metabolism 
â€¢ Substances that have been egested have been 
eaten and passed through the alimentary canal 
without being digested and absorbed into the 
bloodstream  
Assimilation  
â€¢ Assimilation means that food molecules that have been absorbed now becomes a part of the 
cells or are used by cells  
The functions of the liver as part of assimilation  
â€¢ Stores glucose by removing it from the blood and storing it as glycogen. This helps to regulate 
the concentration of glucose in the blood 
â€¢ Uses amino acids to make proteins such as fibrinogen  
â€¢ Breaks down excess amino acids 
â€¢ Converts fatty acids and glycerol into fat which is stored around the body  
â€¢ Produces cholesterol from fats  
Roles of the liver  
â€¢ The liver carries over 200 different roles in the body 
â€¢ All the blood from the digestive system flows through the digestive system before going into the 
rest of circulation  
â€¢ The liver makes bile to neutralise acid when entering the small intestine and emulsifies fat 
â€¢ The liver breaks down harmful substances such as alcohol and drugs  
Deamination  
â€¢ Excess amino acids are broken down by the liver 
â€¢ Each amino acid is broken down into two by the proves of deamination  
â€¢ One molecule is converted to carbohydrate or fat and used as a source of energy  
â€¢ The other molecule is ammonia which combines with carbon dioxide to form urea 
â€¢ This is carried to the kidneys, filtered and excreted as urine  
 

Kidney structure 
â€¢ Responsible for the excretion of urea and excess salts from the body  
â€¢ They control the concentration of water and ions in the body  
â€¢ Waste chemicals are transported to the kidney  
â€¢ Blood enters the kidneys through the renal artery 
â€¢ Inside each kidney is a complex network of filtering units called kidney tubules 
â€¢ As the blood flows through the units, small molecules such as glucose, salts, water and urea are 
forced out of the blood plasma to form the filtrate  
â€¢ The filtrate passes along the tubule and useful substances are reabsorbed into the blood  
â€¢ The volume of water reabsorbed depends on the bodyâ€™s water concentration  
â€¢ If you are dehydrated the body will reabsorb as much water as possible and produce 
concentrated urine to preserve water 
â€¢ If you have taken in a lot of water or it is really cold, the kidneys will absorb less water and you 
will produce dilute urine 
â€¢ At the end of each tubule, urine is released and flows into the ureter and to the bladder where it 
is stored 
â€¢ From here it leaves the body, at intervals, through a shorter tube called the urethra  
â€¢ The renal vein carries blood with a low concentration of chemicals away from the kidneys  
Inside the kidneys  
â€¢ If you cut open the kidney lengthways, youkan see the areas; 
i. 
The cortex- a brown outer layer 
ii. 
The medulla- a reddish inner area 
iii. 
The pelvis- a white area 
â€¢ Inside each kidney are thousands of tiny tubes called kidney tubules which you can only see 
with a microscope  
â€¢ The function of the kidney tubules is to filter blood and remove waste chemicals and determine 
how much water is excreted  
â€¢ The filtering is carried out in the cortex 
â€¢ The waste chemcials and excess water are removed from the body in the urine which flows from 
the kidneys down the ureter and is stored in the bladder  
Kidney Functions 
Structure of a kidney tubule 
â€¢ Blood containing waste chemicals flows into the kidney via renal artery 
â€¢ Renal arteries branch into many arterioles, arterioles supply blood to closely packed capillaries 
called a glomerulus  
â€¢ After filtration, blood flows out of the glomerulus into another arteriole 
â€¢ Blood flows around the rest of the tubule which joins to form the renal vein  
â€¢ The kidney consists of a Bowmanâ€™s capsule at one end  
â€¢ The end of the kidney tubule drains into a collecting duct which goes through the medulla, 
empties in the pelvis and then flows into the ureter 
Filtration  
â€¢ Blood pressure in renal artery is high, blood vessel entering glomerulus is thicker than blood 
vessel leaving it, more blood entering glomerulus than leaving it, causes pressure, pressure 
causes the blood to be filtered 

â€¢ Ling of capillary is like a net, blood cells and large molecules, like blood proteins are too big to 
pass through wholes so remain in blood 
â€¢ Small molecules like urea, glucose, salts, and water pass out of the glomerulus into the  
Bowmanâ€™s capsule 
Reabsorption 
â€¢ All glucose, some salts and much water is reabsorbed in kidney tubule/nephron 
â€¢ Reabsorption requires active transport  
â€¢ Adaptations to reabsorption: 
i. 
Microvilli provide a large surface area for reabsorption 
ii. 
Numerous mitochondria provide energy for active transport 
â€¢ After reabsorption, excess salts and urea are dissolved in water  
â€¢ Fluid flows through nephron some water may be reabsorbed by body if low concentration of 
water in body 
â€¢ Fluid enters collecting ducts as urine 
â€¢ Flows from collecting duct to ureter and then bladder 
â€¢ Urine collects and stored in bladder 
â€¢ Expelled through urethra at intervals 
â€¢ Blood leaving kidneys has lower concentration of waste chemicals 
Kidney Dialysis 
â€¢ Protein in the urine indicates damage to the glomeruli, ruptured membranes allow larger 
molecules to pass through  
â€¢ A person can survive with one kidney that has only 10-15% normal function 
Dialysis  
â€¢ A tube is connected to one of the patientâ€™s veins 
â€¢ Blood flows along the tube into the machine 
â€¢ Blood is pumped over a surface of dialysis membrane-membrane separates blood from dialysis 
fluid 
â€¢ Dialysis fluid contains glucoses and salts (in normal concentrations0 so net movement of these 
access membrane 
â€¢ Waste and urea leaves the machine in the dialysis fluid 
â€¢ Cleaned blood passes back into vein  
â€¢ Membrane is semi permeable  
â€¢ Dialysate has the same water potential as blood as it contains no excess salts 
â€¢ Dialysate contains no toxic chemicals or urea initially  
â€¢ Blood and dialysate moves in opposite directions 
â€¢ All of the toxic chemicals and urea will diffuse into the dialysate  
â€¢ Only excess water and salts diffuse across the membrane into the dialysate 
â€¢ Proteins canâ€™t move across the membrane 
â€¢ The small arrows indicate a nett movement of substances into the blood due to a lower 
concentration of water/salts  
Advantages 
i. 
There is no shortage of dialysis machines 
Disadvantages 

i. 
Dialysis is expensive in the long run 
ii. 
Patients have to stick to a strict diet 
iii. 
Dialysis patients require treatment 3 times a week, each lasting for 4 hours 
Kidney Transport 
â€¢ Replaces the dysfunctional kidney with a healthy one from a donor 
â€¢ Blood type and tissue type needs to be matched reduces chances of rejection due to immune 
attack on new tissue 
â€¢ Immune suppressants drugs are given 
Advantages 
i. 
Transplant is completed once and doesnâ€™t require weekly hospital treatments 
ii. 
Allows patients to lead a normal life 
Disadvantages  
i. 
Shortage of kidneys-need to match tissue and blood type 
ii. 
Patients have to take immune suppressant drugs ïœ more susceptible to disease 
iii. 
Generally last for 8 years, immune system can reject transport immediately or after a few years

Urea is made in the liver from excess amino acids and ammonia combines with carbon dioxide to form urea, which is carried to the kidneys, filtered and excreted as urine .  Inside each kidney are thousands of tiny tubes called kidney tubules which you can only see  with a microscope . The function of the kidney tubule is to filter blood and remove waste chemicals and determine  how much water is excreted . The waste chemcials and excess water are removed from the body in the urine which flows from  the kidneys down the ureter and is stored in the bladder .  Transplant is completed once and doesnâ€™t require weekly hospital treatments . Advantages include the need to match tissue and blood type . Patients have to take immune suppressant drugs more susceptible to disease .

Coordination and Response 
Nervous control in humans 
â€¢ All organisms are sensitive to changes in the environment, known as stimuli, (singular stimulus) 
â€¢ Receptors are cells that detect stimuli 
â€¢ Effectors are the organs, such as glands and muscles that bring about responses 
â€¢ Glands secret useful substances and muscles contract to bring about movement 
â€¢ The actions they take as  a result are called responses  
â€¢ Two systems are involved- the sensory system for detecting changes in the environment and the 
nervous system for coordinating responses and initiating actions 
Human Nervous System 
â€¢ The human nervous system consists of two parts: the central nervous system (CNS) and the 
peripheral nervous system (PNS) 
â€¢ The central nervous system is made up of the brain and spinal chord 
â€¢ The brain is protected by the skull and the spinal cord by the vertebral column 
â€¢ The cranial nervous system is connected to different parts of the body by nerves that make up 
the peripheral nervous system 
â€¢ Cranial nerves and spinal nerves are in pairs on either side of the brain and spinal cord 
respectively 
â€¢ Cranial nerves link the brain with all the organs in the head and also some in the thorax and 
abdomen 
â€¢ Spinal nerves link the brain to the arms, thorax, abdomen and legs 
â€¢ Spinal nerves leave the spinal cord in pairs through spaces between the vertebrae 
â€¢ Each nerve is made up of lots of nerve cells or neurones surrounded by a protective fibrous 
tube 
â€¢ Neurones transmit information in the form of nerve impulses which are like pulses of electricity 
passing along a wire 
Involuntary and Voluntary actions 
â€¢ Voluntary actions are under conscious control and involve the brain in decision making 
â€¢ Involuntary actions occur unconsciously without us having to think of them, but we can choose 
to control them occasionally  
â€¢ Sequence of events in a simple reflex reaction: 
ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘¢ğ‘ â†’ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘Ÿâ†’ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘œğ‘Ÿğ‘‘ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘Ÿâ†’ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘œğ‘Ÿâ†’ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘œğ‘›ğ‘ ğ‘’ 
â€¢ The coordinator is part of the body that connects information about the stimulus to the effector 
â€¢ This always happens inside the central nervous system to allow communications with other 
parts of the body and brain to be aware of stimuli 
â€¢ Inside the spinal cord, neurones from pain receptors connect with neurones to the muscles 
 
 
 

Neurones and reflex arcs 
Neurones 
â€¢ Neurones are highly specialised cells 
â€¢ Their structure allows them to transmit information as nerve impulses over long distances 
â€¢ The cell body contains nucleus and almost all of the cytoplasm 
â€¢ However, neurone have thon extensions that may be quite short but extend a long way through 
the body 
â€¢ Sensory neurones transmit impulses from sense organs to the brain and spinal cord 
â€¢ Motor neurones transmit impulses away from the brain and spinal cord to effector organs-
muscles and glands 
â€¢ Sensory and motor neurones are surrounded by insulation 
â€¢ This insulation is known as myelin, formed by separate cells that grow around the neurones to 
form a layer rich in fat 
â€¢ Relay (connector) neurones are short and pass on impulses from sensory neurones to motor 
neurones inside the brain and spinal cord 
â€¢ When any two neurones meet, they do not touch, there is a tiny gap called a synapse 
â€¢ When an impulse reaches a synapse a chemical transmitter substance is released from the first 
neurone 
â€¢ It diffuses across the synapse and triggers an impulse in the second neurone 
â€¢ Since the chemical transmitter is only produced on one side of the synapse, it ensures that 
impulses travel in one direction through the nervous system  
Reflex arcs 
â€¢ A reflex arc is the pathway of the impulse along the neurones 
â€¢ A hot flame is an example of a stimulus  
â€¢ The receptor is the heat sensor in the skin 
â€¢ When it is stimulated the heat sensor generates an impulse 
â€¢ The impulse travels to the spinal cord along a sensory neurone 
â€¢ Inside the grey matter of the spinal cord the impulse passes across a synapse to a relay neurone 
â€¢ The relay neurone passes the impulse across a second synapse to a motor neurone 
â€¢ The motor neurone transmits the impulse to a muscle in the arm 
â€¢ The muscle is the effector and it contracts to remove the hand from the hot object 
â€¢ The action is the response 
â€¢ Many reflexes are protective, they happen very quickly to prevent injury  
Synapses and drugs 
â€¢ A synapse is a junction between two neurones 
â€¢ The gap between two neurones is called the synaptic gap 
â€¢ The neurone that carries the impulse to the synapse is called the presynaptic neurone 
â€¢ The neurone that carries the impulse away from the synapse is called the postsynaptic neurone  
â€¢ Chemicals known as neurotransmitters are released by the presynaptic neurone and diffuse 
across the synaptic gap to trigger an impulse in the postsynaptic neurone  
 

Structure of the synapse  
â€¢ The axons of neurones end in swellings called synaptic bulbs 
â€¢  The surface of the synaptic bulb is called the presynaptic membrane 
â€¢ It is separated by the synaptic gap from the postsynaptic membrane of the cell body or axon of 
the next neurone 
â€¢ The synaptic bulb has many vesicles containing neurotransmitter molecules 
â€¢ It also contains many mitochondria which suggests that energy is required in synaptic 
transmission 
â€¢ The post synaptic membrane has a large number of protein molecules on its surface which act as 
receptor sites for the neurotransmitter substance 
Synaptic transmission 
1. When an impulse arrives at the synaptic bulb it causes vesicles containing the neurotransmitter 
to move across the presynaptic membrane  
2. The vesicles fuse with the presynaptic membrane, releasing the neurotransmitter into the 
synaptic gap 
3. The neurotransmitter diffuses across the synaptic gap and attaches to specific receptor sites on 
the post synaptic membrane. The receptor sites have a complimentary shape to the 
neurotransmitter, but the binding is only temporary 
4. The binding of the neurotransmitter triggers an impulse in the postsynaptic neurone. Once this 
has happened the neurotransmitter is broken down by an enzyme in the synaptic gap 
5. The mitochondria provide energy to reform the neurotransmitter  
 
â€¢ Nerve impulses only travel in one direction i.e. from presynaptic neurone to postsynaptic 
neurone 
â€¢ This happens because vesicles of the neurotransmitter are only present in the presynaptic bulb 
and the receptors are only found on the postsynaptic membrane  
The effect of drugs on synaptic transmission  
â€¢ Most drugs that affect the nervous system have their effects at synapses 
â€¢ These drugs influence the release of neurotransmitter s 
â€¢ Interact with receptor by either stimulating or inhibiting them  
â€¢ Amphetamines are a type of excitatory drug that increases activity in the nervous system: 
i. 
Stimulate the release of neurotransmitters in the brain, increasing brain activity, 
making the person more alert 
ii. 
They also have the effect of suppressing appetite 
â€¢ Heroin and beta-blockers are examples of inhibitory drugs, that reduce the effects on 
neurotransmitters 
â€¢ Heroin acts on the presynaptic neurones to reduce the release of neurotransmitter and this 
reduced the sensation of pain  
â€¢ Beta-blockers are drugs that block receptors for neurotransmitters and are taken by people to 
reduce blood pressure and heart rate  
 

Sense Organs 
â€¢ Sense organs are groups of receptor cells that respond to specific stimuli  
â€¢ The eyes respond to light rays and gives us our sense of sight 
â€¢ The nose responds to chemicals in the air and gives us our sense of smell 
â€¢ The tongue responds to chemicals in our food and drink and gives us our sense of taste 
â€¢ The ears respond to sound vibrations that gives us our sense of hearing, the ear also detect 
movement and position of the body, providing information about balance 
â€¢ The skin responds to pressure and gives us our sense of touch, it also detects pain and 
temperature 
Eye Structure 
â€¢ Your eye sits inside a socket in the skull and is moved about by 3 pairs of eye muscles 
â€¢ The eye is a complex of organ composed of different tissues 
â€¢ At the front of the eye is a delicate, transparent layer, through which light enters the eye 
â€¢ Light then passes through the pupil which is a hole in the centre of the pigmented iris, through 
the lens to the retina at the back of the eye 
â€¢ The retina is a tissue with light-sensitive receptor cells 
â€¢ At the very front of the eye is a delicate, transparent layer, which provides protection.  
â€¢ It is kept moist by tear glands, that clean your eyes every time you blink  
â€¢ Tears also contain lysosome, an enzyme that kills bacteria 
â€¢ What you see in front of you is called your visual field  
â€¢ Each eye views the same visual field but from a slightly different angle  
â€¢ When shutting the eyes, the two fields overlap to give stereoscopic visions, which allows us the 
ability to judge distances accurately 
â€¢ Essential for tree-dwelling animals and predators which need to judge distances accurately to 
survive 
Control of the pupil reflex 
â€¢ The size of the pupil is controlled by a pair of antagonistic muscles in the iris 
â€¢ The circular muscles are arranged around the pupil 
â€¢ The radial muscles run outwards from the pupil like spokes in a wheel 
â€¢ Antagonistic muscle pair 
â€¢ Circular muscles contract to reduce the size of the pupils 
â€¢ The radial muscles contract to increase the size of the pupils  
Focusing  
â€¢ Light enters the eye through the transparent cornea  
â€¢ Passes through the lens to be focused on the retina 
â€¢ The image is inverted because of the way the light rays reflected from the top and bottom of the 
object enter the eye and cross over behind the lens 
â€¢ Information about this inverted image goes to the brain to be interpreted the right way up 
â€¢ We learn how to do this in the first few months of life  
 
 

Rods and Cones 
â€¢ Rods and cones are light receptor cells on the retina 
â€¢ Rod cells are sensitive to light of low intensity and send impulses only when it is dark, 
responsible for night vision 
â€¢ Cone cells are only sensitive to light of high intensity 
â€¢ There are three types of cone cell, each sensitive to different wave lengths of light  
â€¢ The brain interprets impulses from cone cells to give us coloured vision 
â€¢ The fovea is the centre of the retina which contains no rods nor cones 
â€¢ Each cone has its own neurone to the brain so this area in the middle of our visual field gives us 
a detailed image 
â€¢ The rest of the retina contains rods and few cones 
â€¢ This area gives us peripheral vision which is not very detailed  
â€¢ The position of the fovea is in the centre of the retina on the horizontal level as the blind spot 
Accommodation  
â€¢ Term used to describe the changes that occur in the eye when focusing on far and near objects 
â€¢ As light enters the eye it must be refracted to see the image clearly  
â€¢ The lens is surrounded by elastic tissue that can stretch and recoil 
â€¢ The shape of the lens is controlled by the ciliary muscles  
Whilst seeing distant objects 
Whilst seeing close objects 
The ciliary muscles relax 
Pressure inside eye pulls sensory ligaments tight 
Lens pulled into elliptical (thin) shape 
Light rays refracted as they pass through lens and 
focus on the retina 
The distant object is in focus 
The ciliary muscles contract to counteract 
pressure in the eye 
Suspensory ligaments are slack  
Elastic tissue recoils and becomes spherical (fat) 
Light rays are refracted more 
The near image is now in focus 
 
Hormones 
The endocrine system 
â€¢ A hormone is a chemical substance produced by an endocrine glad and transported in the 
blood to alter the activity of target organs 
Adrenaline 
â€¢ Secreted by adrenal gland 
â€¢ Makes you more aware and ready to take action 
â€¢ Fight or flight reaction: 
i. 
Increasing the breathing rate 
ii. 
Increasing pulse  
iii. 
Widening pupils for more light to enter eyes 
â€¢ Stimulates increase in rate of chemical activity  
â€¢ Stimulates liver cells to convert glycogen to glucose  
â€¢ Adrenaline coordinates uptake of oxygen and changes in the blood  

Effects of adrenaline 
â€¢ Air passages widen, allow more air into alveoli, increases volume of oxygen to be absorbed 
â€¢ Breathing rate increases to increase the uptake of oxygen and excrete carbon dioxide at a 
faster rate 
â€¢ Arterioles in the brain and muscles dilate to deliver more glucose and oxygen for respiration 
in these organs 
â€¢ Arterioles in the gut and other organs constrict to deliver blood to the muscles 
â€¢ If too much adrenaline is realised, as a result of prolonged strength/anxiety, high blood 
pressure and heart disease may result 
â€¢ Beta-blockers help to reduce blood pressure and heart rate  
Comparing the endocrine and nervous system 
Feature 
Nervous system  
Endocrine system 
Structures  
Nerves  
Secretory cells in glands 
Forms of information 
Electrical impulses  
Hormones  
Pathways 
Along neurones  
In the blood 
Speed of information transfer 
Fast  
Slow 
Longevity of action 
Short time 
Usually slow and long lasting 
Target area 
Only the area at the end of a 
neurone 
Whole tissue or organ 
Response  
Muscle contraction or secretion 
by glands 
Conversion of glucose to 
glycogen, protein synthesis, 
rate of respiration 
 
Controlling conditions in the body 
â€¢ Homeostasis is the maintenance of constant or balanced internal conditions of the body so that 
enzymes can control metabolism efficiently  
â€¢ Negative feedback loop creates responses to counteract the effect of a variable 
â€¢ Positive feedback loop increases the intensity of the variable to trigger response  
Controlling body temperature 
The skin 
Functions: 
â€¢ Protects body from damage 
â€¢ Stops pathogen from entering  
â€¢ Prevents too much water loss 
â€¢ Detects changes in temperature 
â€¢ Detects pressure (touch) and pain  
â€¢ Loses heat by conduction, convection, radiation and evaporation 
â€¢ Mammals have fur or hair which traps a layer of air close to the skin 

â€¢ Air is a poor conductor of heat 
â€¢ Air pockets reduce the amount of heat loss to the atmosphere by keeping convection currents of 
air away from the skin 
â€¢ When it is cold hair erector muscles contract so that the hair stand erect to trap a thick layer of 
air reducing heat loss 
â€¢ When it is hot hair muscles relax so hairs lie fat 
â€¢ Less air is trapped close to the skin so more heat canâ€™t be lost via convectional currents of air 
â€¢ Mammals also have a layer of fatty tissue beneath the skin that is a good insulator 
Controlling temperature in the body 
â€¢ A very effective way to regulate body temperature is to change how much blood flows through 
the capillaries near the surface of the skin  
â€¢ Arterioles supply these capillaries with blood 
â€¢ The muscle around the arteriole can relax 
â€¢ Increase in blood flow in the capillaries 
â€¢ Known as vasodilation  
â€¢ Heat lot to surroundings by convection and radiation  
â€¢ In the cold, walls of arterioles constrict  
â€¢ Reduces blood flow through capillaries  
â€¢ Blood diverted to stay in the fatty layer in the skin 
â€¢ Known as vasoconstriction  
Tropic responses  
Gravitropism  
â€¢ A gravitropism is a growth response to the stimulus of gravity  
â€¢ Roots are positively gravitropic because they grow in the same direction as gravity 
â€¢ Shoots are negatively gravitropic, they grow in the opposite direction to gravity  
Auxin  
â€¢ Plant hormone that controls growth 
â€¢ Stimulates shoot growth by causing cells to elongate 
â€¢ Inhibits root growth by slowing down elongation  
â€¢ If a seedling is put on its side then the auxin builds up on the lower side of the shoot and root 
â€¢ In the shoot the auxin stimulates the cells there to elongate and therefore grow more on the lower 
side 
â€¢ This causes the shoot to bend upwards 
â€¢ In the root the auxin builds up on the lower side 
â€¢ Auxin slows down growth by inhibiting elongation 
â€¢ As a result the cells on the upper side of the root elongate more than those on the lower side so 
the root bends downwards 
â€¢ Auxin is made in the shoot tip 
â€¢ Auxin moves away from the shoot tip down the stem 
â€¢ Auxin is unequally distributed so most is found on the shaded side 
â€¢ The auxin stimulates the cells on the shaded side to elongate more than the cells on the side of 
direct light 

â€¢ The shoot grows more on the shaded side and bends towards the light  
â€¢ Roots are not sensitive to light 
Phototropism  
â€¢ (Positive) phototropism, or positively phototropic plants grow towards the light  
â€¢ Advantage: leaves are exposed to maximum surface area to the light 
Synthetic plant hormones 
â€¢ Synthetic auxins are very effective as selective weed killers 
â€¢ Important crops (cereals) have narrow leaves, whilst weeds have broad leaves 
â€¢ Herbicides [2,4-D] are sprayed on the crop but tend to run off the leaves of the cereal because 
they are thin and point upwards 
â€¢ The weed killers are more likely to be absorbed by the broad leaved weeds 
â€¢ The auxins increase the growth rate of the affected leaves, by increasing rate of cell division 
â€¢ The weeds cannot provide enough food from photosynthesis to maintain this rate of growth and 
will soon die
summary_text: The human nervous system consists of two parts: the central nervous system and the peripheral nervous system . Neurones transmit information in the form of nerve impulses which are like pulses of electricity . Sensory and motor neurones are surrounded by insulation known as myelin, formed by separate cells that grow around the neurones .  When an impulse arrives at the synaptic bulb it causes vesicles containing the neurotransmitters to move across the presynaptic membrane . The binding of the neurotransmitter triggers an impulse in the postsynaptic neurone . The neurotransmitter is broken down by an enzyme in the synaptic gap .  Each eye views the same visual field but from a slightly different angle . The size of the pupil is controlled by a pair of antagonistic muscles in the iris . Light enters the eye through the transparent cornea to be focused on the retina . The image is inverted because of the way the light rays reflected from the top and bottom of the  object enter the eye and cross over behind the lens .  Adrenaline coordinates uptake of oxygen and changes in the blood . If too much adrenaline is realised, as a result of prolonged strength/anxiety, high blood pressure and heart disease may result . Beta-blockers help to reduce blood pressure and heart rate .

raw_text:
Drugs 
What are drugs? 
A drug is any substance that is taken into the body that alters or influences the chemical reactions in 
the body. 
Types of drugs 
â€¢ Some drugs are active ingredients and are used to treat/cure people from disease 
â€¢ Others are mood enhancing altering sensory perception  
â€¢ Aspirin, paracetamol, morphine and antibiotics are medical drugs designed to supress pain, 
counteract flu or kill pathogenic bacteria 
â€¢ Alcohol, nicotine and caffeine are socially acceptable drugs that people take for pleasurable 
effects, to help them relax or concentrate 
â€¢ Drugs that tend to be illegal for more severe effects are sometimes called recreational drugs 
â€¢ Hallucinogens such as Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) cause psychedelic visions 
â€¢ Stimulants like cocaine, ecstasy and amphetamines are mood enhancing drugs for a short lived 
feeling of well-being and energy 
â€¢ Drugs act upon the body in various ways  
â€¢ Nicotine and heroin interfere with the way the nervous system works and are addictive  
â€¢ The aforementioned drugs act at synapses in the nervous system and change the way in which 
neurones send impulses 
â€¢ They do this by combining with the protein molecules on the cell membranes of the neurones  
â€¢ The liver is the site of the breakdown of alcohol and other toxins 
â€¢ Drugs are broken down in the body by enzymes and the products are excreted 
â€¢ The breakdown of the products can be detected in urine  
â€¢ So urine tests are carried out to see if people have been taking drugs 
â€¢ Many drugs are addictive  
â€¢ If the body become reliant on the drug, the person becomes addicted and needs to take it 
regularly 
â€¢ In several countries, the possession or on non-medicinal drugs is illegal 
â€¢ The bodyâ€™s metabolism may become used to the drug  
â€¢ The liver may produce more enzymes to break it down so the dose of the drug has to increase to 
have the effect that the user first experienced  
Antibiotics 
â€¢ Group of chemicals made by microorganisms (bacteria and fungi) that are used to kill pathogens 
or stop their growth 
â€¢ Antibiotics are prescribed by doctors to treat diseases caused by diseases 
â€¢ Antibiotics can be injected or taken orally 
â€¢ A course of antibiotics has to be taken over a period of time 
â€¢ Penicillin was the first antibiotic to be discovered and mass produced 
â€¢ Penicillin acts on bacteria by inhibiting cell wall formation leading to a breakdown of the cell 
wall and the leakage of cell contents  
â€¢ Some antibiotics stop substances from crossing cell membranes and others prevent bacteria 
from catalysing reactions 

â€¢ Antibiotics have no effect on viruses  
â€¢ A big problem with antibiotics is that many bacteria have become resistant to them  
â€¢ Viruses are not cell 
â€¢ They do not carry out their own metabolism and dependent on their host  
â€¢ To control viruses- we would essentially have to inhibit our own metabolism which would be 
impossible  
â€¢ This is why antibiotics are not used to treat viruses 
â€¢ There are anti-viral drugs available such as AZT which is used to treat HIV/AIDs but work 
differently to antibiotics 
â€¢ There are less anti-viral drugs than antibiotics  
â€¢ Bacterial resistance to antibiotics has been caused by overuse especially in hospitals 
â€¢ Overuse was responsible for the development of a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus 
or MRSA 
â€¢ This has caused death in hospital patients with suppressed immune systems 
â€¢ Prescribing antibiotics only when necessary and ensuring that people complete their courses of 
antibiotic treatment by taking all their pills are a way to control bacterial resistance  
Heroin  
The biology of heroin  
â€¢ Morphine and codeine are two compounds extracted from opium poppies and used as 
painkillers in medicine  
â€¢ Heroin is a compound modified from morphine  
â€¢ Heroin has only limited medial uses as it is highly addictive so rarely used  
â€¢ Heroin is a powerful depressant that slows down the nervous system  
â€¢ Heroin has a chemical structure that is similar to endorphins, a group of chemicals found in the 
brain 
â€¢ Endorphins are made naturally in the brain when the body is experiencing pain or stress 
â€¢ They work by flooding the synapses in the brain and preventing neurones from transmitting 
impulses from pain receptors, producing pain relief  
â€¢ The heroin molecules bind to the endorphin receptor sites on the post synaptic membranes of 
the synapse, blocking nerve transmission 
â€¢ This mimics the function of endorphins 
â€¢ When people take heroin for the first time they experience feelings of contentment and 
happiness, this state is known as euphoria 
Addiction to heroin  
â€¢ Heroin becomes part of the bodyâ€™s metabolism and the body quickly gets used to the drug  
â€¢ This includes the nerve cells where it has its effect  
â€¢ More painkillers are needed to prevent them sending impulses to the brain 
â€¢ The feeling of pain becomes unbearable and addicts have to take heroin to reduce the pain  
â€¢ This is how the body develops tolerance and the drug has to be taken in greater quantities to 
experience euphoria or deaden pain  
â€¢ People who start taking heroin want to repeat the feelings they first experienced, but easily 
become hooked or addicted 
â€¢ This can happen within two to three weeks of misuse  

â€¢ Heroin is taken by smoking, sniffing or injecting  
â€¢ Injecting is highly dangerous as veins can collapse and tissues start to die causing gangrene 
â€¢ Long term addicts run out of places to inject it 
â€¢ Some addicts share needles and syringes which could cause HIV or hepatitis  
Social Problems 
â€¢ The drug often dominates the lives of addicts until they get their next fix 
â€¢ The drug can be expensive which leads people towards crime to sustain their habit 
â€¢ It can be difficult to keep a job, and addiction usually leads to family breakdown and 
homelessness 
â€¢ Addicts prefer the company of other addicts isolating themselves from family and friends 
â€¢ Heroin is produced in Afghanistan and the Golden Triangle (Laos, Vietnam, Burma and 
Thailand) 
â€¢ It is then illegally transported elsewhere 
â€¢ A user who stops taking the drugs experiences unpleasant withdrawal symptoms 
â€¢ These include sleeplessness, hallucinations, muscle cramps, sweating, vomiting and nausea 
â€¢ A great deal of willpower and support is needed to overcome addiction  
â€¢ Often the only way to recover is through rehabilitation  
â€¢ This may involve staying at a treatment centre 
â€¢ In some countries addicts are given another drug called methadone which gives the same effects 
as heroin  
Alcohol  
The biology of alcohol 
â€¢ When consumed, it is absorbed into the blood quickly since it is a small molecule and does not 
have to be digested  
â€¢ It is soluble in cell membranes and easily absorbed through the wall of the stomach and small 
intestine 
â€¢ The presence of food in the stomach slows down the absorption  
â€¢ Alcohol gets distributed throughout the body in the blood 
â€¢ Some is lost through the lungs and the kidneys 
â€¢ It is absorbed by liver cells and broken down by enzymes so its concentration in the blood 
decreases  
â€¢ This breakdown happens faster in men than women  
â€¢ Because men have more of these enzymes and tend to be more active 
â€¢ Men also have more water and less fat in their bodies as compared to women, which also 
decreases the concentration faster  
â€¢ Like heroin, alcohol is a depressant 
â€¢ It affects the brain by slowing down the transmission of nerve impulses  
â€¢ In small quantities this has the effect of removing inhibitions so people find it easier to be social  
â€¢ With larger quantities this lack of inhibition leads to: 
i. 
Loss of coordination, judgement and control of fine movements 
ii. 
Slower reaction times 
iii. 
Loss of self-control  
â€¢ Unlike heroin, alcohol does not lead to addiction as quickly, it at all 

â€¢ Many people drink alcohol in small to moderate quantities throughout their lives without 
becoming addicted  
â€¢ The alcohol content of drinks is measured in units 
â€¢ One unit is 8 grams of alcohol, this quantity is broken down by the liver in one hour 
â€¢ The UK government recommends that men should not drink more than between 3 to 4 units 
â€¢ And women 2 to 3 per day  
Addiction  
â€¢ Some people become dependent upon alcohol and are sometimes referred to as alcoholics 
â€¢  They develop a tolerance as more enzymes that metabolise alcohol are made in the liver 
â€¢ They need to take greater quantities to get the same effect  
â€¢ The feel tense and irritable and find it hard to cope with everyday problems without a drinks  
Social Problems  
â€¢ The misuse of alcohol is a factor in crime, family disputes, martial breakdown, child neglect, 
absenteeism, vandalism and violent crime 
â€¢ Damage done by alcohol is considerable and difficult to measure  
â€¢ Alcohol and drugs are involved in many road accidents  
â€¢ Alcohol can disturb a person concentration but make them feel more confident 
â€¢ In some countries it is illegal to drink alcohol and then operate a car or machinery 
Long term effects of alcohol  
â€¢ Drinking in large quantities for many years can lead to stomach ulcers, heart disease and brain 
damage 
â€¢ Drinking in large quantities interferes with the metabolism of the liver causing fat to build up 
â€¢ This condition is known as fatty liver 
â€¢ The liver tissue is damaged and replaced by fibrous scar tissue  
â€¢ If heavy drinking persists then the liver becomes full of nodules 
â€¢ This condition is known as cirrhosis  
â€¢ The liver becomes less able to carry out its job of removing toxins from the blood  
â€¢ This condition is irreversible and fatal unless drinking is stopped  
â€¢ Long term consumption also leads to brain damage and personality and behavioural changes  
The misuse of drugs in sport  
â€¢ Anabolic steroids are substances similar to testosterone  
â€¢ They work by mimicking the protein-building effects of this hormone 
â€¢ The result is muscle strength resulting in increased strength and endurance 
â€¢ There are a number of harmful side effects resulting from the excessive use of anabolic steroids 
â€¢ In men: increased aggression, impotence, baldness, kidney and liver damage and development of 
breasts 
â€¢ In women: development of male features, facial and body hair and irregular periods 
Smoking and health  
â€¢ Tobacco plants make nicotine as a way to protect against insect attack (natural pesticide) 
â€¢ Nicotineâ€™s molecular structure allows it to interact with our nervous system  

Biology of Tobacco Smoke  
Nicotine  
â€¢ Absorbed quickly through the alveoli to enter the bloodstream  
â€¢ Interacts with nerve cells at synapses 
â€¢ Stimulant  
â€¢ Makes heat beat faster, narrows arterioles which increases blood pressure  
â€¢ Increases stickiness of blood platelets that promote blood clotting  
Tar 
â€¢ A black sticky material that collects in the lungs as smoke and coals 
â€¢ Does not pass into the bloodstream  
â€¢ Irritates the lining of airways and stimulates production of mucus 
â€¢ Accumulation of mucus because cilia is damaged by smoking  
â€¢ Smokers cough to make this material move to the back of the throat 
â€¢ The chemicals compounds in tar can cause cancer and are described as carcinogenic  
Carbon Monoxide 
â€¢ Poisonous gas 
â€¢ Combines with haemoglobin thus reduces the amount of oxygen transported by 10% 
â€¢ Put added strain on a heart, as response to nicotine 
â€¢ When more oxygen is required, less blood is delivered as it flows through the coronary arteries 
to supply the heart muscle 
â€¢ If a women smokes during pregnancy, there may not be enough oxygen for the fetus to develop 
â€¢ The baby may have a smaller birth weight or be born prematurely  
Diseases caused by smoking  
â€¢ Chronic obstructive pulmonary diseases (COPD)-Collection of lung diseases including chronic 
bronchitis and emphysema  
â€¢ Effect of hot tobacco smoke on airways reduces efficiency in keeping the lungs clean  
â€¢ Cilia on the cell lining the air passages stop beating  
â€¢ Mucus, dust, dirt and bacteria stick to the airways 
â€¢ Stimulates bodyâ€™s immune system sends phagocytes to the place where this happens 
(particularly bronchi) 
â€¢ Large amounts of phlegm (mucus, bacteria and white blood cells are produced and people 
attempt to cough it up 
â€¢ This is called chronic bronchitis  
â€¢ People with this condition find it difficult to move air in and out of their lungs as bronchi are 
partially blocked 
â€¢ Particles, bacteria and tar reach the alveoli 
â€¢ Phagocytic white blood cells digest a pathway through the lining of the alveoli to reach them  
â€¢ Eventually this weaken the wall of the alveoli so much that they break down and burst 
â€¢ Reducing the surface area for gas exchange 
â€¢ This condition is known as emphysema  

â€¢ Which leaves people gasping for breath as they cannot absorb oxygen or remove carbon dioxide 
efficiently  
â€¢ Many long term smokers have both of these conditions  
â€¢ The cause of lung cancer is the carcinogens in tar  
â€¢ They promote DNA changes of cells lining the airways 
â€¢ The cells grow and divide out of control 
â€¢ The growth is slow but eventually may form a small group of cells known as a tumour  
â€¢ If this is not discovered, it may occupy a larger space obstructing airways and blood vessels  
â€¢ A part of the tumour may break off and spread to other organs  
Heart disease 
â€¢ Tobacco smoke increases the chances that fat will deposit in the walls of the artery 
â€¢ As nicotine increases the chance that blood will clot, there is an increased risk of developing 
CHD 
â€¢ Blocked arteries reduce the supply of oxygen to the heart and this damages the heart muscle

Reproduction 
â€¢ Reproduction means producing new living organisms. Animals and plants reproduce to make 
new individuals of the same species. There are two types of reproduction: asexual and sexual 
reproduction  
Asexual reproduction  
â€¢ In asexual reproduction there is only one parent  
â€¢ All the offspring are identical to the parent as they inherit exactly the same genetic information 
â€¢ They are genetically identically identical to the parent, which means there is little variation 
amongst the offspring  
â€¢ Bacteria: the bacterial cell divides into two making a new cell wall. This type of asexual 
reproduction is called binary fission, because the parent cells splits into two 
â€¢ Pin mold is a fungus which grows on bread 
â€¢ It reproduces asexually by making spores 
â€¢ There are small and light, like specs of dusts and they float through the air 
â€¢ When a spore lands on a damp surface it splits open and a thread grows out  
â€¢ This thread or hypha, grows over the surface of the bread forming a dense network of threads 
called a mycelium  
â€¢ Eventually short hyphae grow upwards and produce spore cases or sporangia at their tips. 
â€¢ Inside each sporangium hundreds of new spores are formed asexually by division of the nuclei 
â€¢ Each nucleus gains a small quantity of cytoplasm and protective spore case 
â€¢ When ready, sporangia break open and the spores are dispersed  
â€¢ Potatoes reproduce asexually by means of stem tubers, which are swollen underground stems 
that grow from the parent plant  
â€¢ Sucrose is transported in the phloem from the leaves into these underground stems that swell as 
they convert the sucrose into starch  
â€¢ The parent plant dies at the end of the growing season leaving the tubers in the ground to 
survive over the winter  
Sexual reproduction  
â€¢ In sexual reproduction there are two parents  
â€¢ The parents have sex organs  
â€¢ The sex organs make sex cells or gametes  
â€¢ In animals, the male gametes are sperm cells  
â€¢ In flowering plants the male gametes are nuclei inside pollen grains 
â€¢ In animals, the female gametes are egg cells 
â€¢ In flowering plants the female gametes are inside structures called ovules 
â€¢ The fertilized egg or zygote divides to form an embryo which may grow into a new individual 
plant  
â€¢ At fertilization, half the genetic materials comes from the male gamete and half comes from the 
female gamete  
â€¢ The nuclei in the gametes contain one set of chromosomes  
â€¢  A zygote has a nucleus that contains two sets of chromosomes-one from each gamete  
â€¢ Unlike asexual reproduction, the offspring produced are not genetically identical to the parents  

â€¢ This means that sexual reproduction brings about variation in the offspring  
Advantages and disadvantages of asexual reproduction in plants  
â€¢ Asexual reproduction is fast 
â€¢ If left in the ground, potato tubers grow into new plants in the same place as the parent, but 
compete with each other for resources 
â€¢ Seeds produced in sexual reproduction may be dispersed to new areas where there may not be 
as much competition  
â€¢ However, many seeds land in unsuitable places for growth so many are wasted 
â€¢ There is very little, if any, variation as a result of asexual reproduction  
â€¢ This can be a disadvantage if these individuals are affected by a certain disease 
â€¢ Disease could spread very quickly through crop monoculture, in which all the plants are 
genetically identical  
â€¢ If environmental conditions change, it is unlikely that there will be individuals with features to 
adapt to these mew conditions 
â€¢ Sexual reproduction gives a rise to variation 
â€¢ If there is plenty of variation, species are better able to survive and evolve  
Flower Structure 
â€¢ Flowering plants carry out sexual reproduction by producing flowers, which have male and 
female parts  
â€¢ The male parts make pollen grains to carry male gametes to the female parts 
â€¢ The transfer of pollen grains is pollination 
â€¢ Female gametes are deep inside the female part and pollen grain grow a tube to reach them 
â€¢ Each pollen tube delivers a male gamete so it can fuse with the female gamete to form a zygote 
â€¢ Fusion of male and female gametes is fertilization  
Flowers vary in structure depending upon their method of pollination  
Insect pollinated flowers 
Flower parts are often arranged in rings attached to the end if a swollen flower stalk. The sepals form 
the outer ring and the carpels form the inner ring. 
â€¢ Sepals are leaf-like structures that protect the flower when it is a bud 
â€¢ Petals are brightly colored and scented. Many have nectary at the base, which makes sugary 
nectar. Visiting insects land on the petals to feed on nectar 
â€¢ Stamens are the male sex organs. Each one is made up of two [arts: the anther, where the pollen 
is made, and the filament, a stalk which holds the anther,  
â€¢ Carpels are the female sex organs. Each carpel is made up of a stigma, a style and an ovary  
â€¢ The ovules are inside the ovary. Each ovule has a female gamete- the egg cell 
â€¢ Pollen grains are often spiky and sticky 
â€¢ The grains are adapted to attach to hairs in the surfaces of insect bodies 
â€¢ The grains become dislodged onto a stigma when an insect enters another flower of the same 
species 
 

Wind pollinated flowers  
â€¢ Grasses and cereals are all pollinated by the wind  
â€¢ The flowers are small, green and inconspicuous compared to insect pollinated flowers 
â€¢ They have no scent and no nectar  
â€¢ The anthers produce pollen grains that are small, smooth and light so that they are easily 
carried on the wind  
â€¢ These flowers make huge numbers of pollen grains as the chances if pollen grains landing on a 
stigma are very small  
â€¢ The anthers hang outside the flower so the wind can blow away pollen  
â€¢ The feathery stigmas are also positioned outside the flower 
â€¢ They act like a net, providing a large surface area for catching pollen grains that get blown into 
them  
â€¢ Wind pollination can waste a lot of pollen, which is why the anthers produce so much 
â€¢ But the fact that plants such as grasses and cereals grow close to one another means that pollen 
is more likely to be transferred than if they are separated by large distances 
Pollination  
â€¢ Pollination is the transfer of pollen grains from the anther of the male part of the flower to the 
stigma of the female part of the flower 
â€¢ Self-pollination involves the transfer of pollen from the anthers to the stigma of the same flower 
or a different flower on the same plant  
â€¢ Cross pollination involves the transfer of pollen from the anthers of one flower to the stigma of 
another flower on a different plant of the same species 
â€¢ The benefit of cross pollination is that it results in greater variation in which natural selection 
can operate on
