Fertilization and seed formation  
â€¢ If a pollen grain lands on a ripe stigma it starts to grow a pollen tube to take the male nucleus to 
the female nucleus 
â€¢ Fertilization occurs when the male nucleus fuses with the female nucleus 
â€¢ This occurs inside the ovule 

â€¢ Each pollen grain grows a pollen tube to take the male nucleus to the ovule 
â€¢ As it grows, the pollen tube gains nutrition from the tissues of the style and carries nutrition 
from the tissues of the style and carries the male gamete nucleus with it  
â€¢ The first pollen tube reaches the ovary 
â€¢ It enters the ovule through a small hole-the micropyle 
â€¢ The male gamete and then fuses with the egg cell nucleus  
â€¢ This is fertilization in which a zygote is formed by fusion of the two nuclei  
Seed Formation 
â€¢ After fertilization, the zygote divides and grows into the embryo 
â€¢ The ovule forms the seed with the embryo inside it  
â€¢ The ovary forms the fruit with the seeds inside it  
â€¢ Many of the parts of the flower are not needed when fertilization has occurred, so the sepals, 
petals and stamens, wither and fall off  
â€¢ Each fertilized ovule grows to form a seed, each seed is made up of: an embryo, an energy store 
and a seed coat/testa 
â€¢ The ovary forms the fruit  
Condition for germination  
â€¢ Water is needed for the seeds to swell. This swelling breaks the seed coats of some seeds. Cells 
absorb water, develop vacuoles and expand. Cell expansion makes the radicle (embryonic root) 
grow out from the seed. Water is also needed to dissolve the soluble products made by enzymes 
from the food stores. Water also activated these enzymes. 
â€¢ Oxygen is needed for aerobic respiration to provide the embryo with energy  
â€¢ A suitably warm temperature is needed so that the enzymes can work efficiently  
The Male Reproductive System  
â€¢ The testes are the male sex organs  
â€¢ They produce the male gametes/spermatozoa/sperm 
â€¢ The testes also male testosterone  
â€¢ This stimulates changes in a boyâ€™s body as he develops into an adult during puberty 
â€¢ This happens between about 10 and 16 years of age 
â€¢ The testes are located inside a sac called the scrotum which hangs outside the body 
â€¢ This keeps the testes at a cooler temperature as sperm cells need at temperature of lower that 
37Â°C to develop properly and be stored 
â€¢ After puberty, the testes constantly produce sperm cells which are stored in small tubules just 
outside the testes where they mature 
â€¢ A much wider tube called the sperm duct connects these tubules to the urethra  
â€¢ The prostate gland and other glands secrete fluids in which sperm cells can swim  
â€¢ The prostrate secretes mucus and other glands secrete sugars which sperm cells use as a 
source of energy for their respiration  
â€¢ Sperm cells and the fluid together form semen, also known as seminal fluid  
â€¢ The two sperm ducts join with the urethra, which runs down the center of the penis 
â€¢ Urine and semen never pass down urethra at the same time  

â€¢ A ring of muscle around the urethra contracts to prevent the loss of any urine from the bladder 
during sexual intercourse  
Male and Female gametes 
â€¢ Gametes are sex cells  
â€¢ The male gamete is called the sperm  
â€¢ The female gamete is called the ovum or egg 
â€¢ The sperm cell is a specialized cell that is adapted for swimming by having a flagellum that 
lashes from side to side 
â€¢ Sperm cells carry genetic information from the male parent to the female parent  
â€¢ The nucleus contains the fatherâ€™s chromosomes 
â€¢ An egg is bigger than a sperm because it provides the food store that supports the embryo after 
fertilization  
â€¢ An egg cells is fertilized by a sperm cell  
â€¢ The head of the sperm contains enzymes to help it reach the surface of the egg cell  
â€¢ The cell membrane of the sperm cell fuses with the egg cell membrane  
â€¢ The sperm nucleus moves through the cytoplasm of the egg and the two nuclei fuse together to 
form a zygote (fertilized egg) 
â€¢ After fertilization, the jelly coat changes, so that no more sperm can enter

â€¢ Each sperm cell has mitochondria, which releases energy to power the swimming by the tail  
â€¢ The acrosome contains enzyme that digest a pathway through the jelly coat surrounding the egg 
The Female Reproductive System 
â€¢ Ovaries are female sex organs that produce the female gametes called ova or eggs  
â€¢ The ovaries also make the female hormones estrogen and progesterone, which starts to happen 
with girls between 10 and 15 years of age during puberty  
â€¢ Estrogen stimulates the development of the sex organs and secondary sexual characteristics in 
a girlâ€™s body as she starts to develop into an adult  
â€¢ Progesterone prepares the uterus so that it is ready to receive an embryo in the case of 
pregnancy  
â€¢ The ovaries are attached to the inside of the abdomen just below the kidneys 

â€¢ After puberty, an egg is released from an ovary about every 28 days  
â€¢ The ovaries tend to release an egg or eggs on alternate months  
â€¢ The egg passes out of the ovary and into the funnel shaped opening of the oviduct in a process 
called ovulation  
â€¢ The egg moves slowly down the oviduct towards the uterus (womb) 
â€¢ If sperm cells are present in the oviduct the egg will be fertilized  
â€¢ If the egg is not fertilized it will die after about a day  
â€¢ If the egg is fertilized it will divide to form an embryo which may attach itself to the lining of the 
uterus where it develops into a fetus  
â€¢ The lower end of the uterus has a ring of muscle called the cervix 
â€¢ It leads to a muscular tube called the vagina that opens to the outside of the body  
â€¢ Above the opening of the vagina is the opening of the urethra through which urine from the 
bladder passes out  
â€¢ Above the urethra is the sensitive clitoris 
â€¢ The outer opening of the vagina is called the vulva  
â€¢ The vagina is sometimes known as the birth canal, as it through here that a baby passes at birth  
Sexual Intercourse 
â€¢ During sexual intercourse males and females stimulate each other  
â€¢ Blood is pumped into special spongy tissue in the penis so that it becomes erect  
â€¢ The erect penis is placed into the vagina during sexual intercourse  
â€¢ Fluid made by the walls of the vagina lubricates movements of the penis within the vagina  
â€¢ This movement stimulates the penis and contractions begin in the sperm ducts to move sperm 
cells from the tubules around the testes towards the penis  
â€¢ As they flow, secretion from the glands including the prostate gland are added to form the semen 
or seminal fluid 
â€¢ Contractions of the urethra move the seminal fluid through the penis into the vagina  
â€¢ This is an ejaculation and the man experiences feelings of pleasure called an orgasm  
â€¢ Repeated movements of the penis against the clitoris or against the vagina walls may also 
produce orgasms for the woman 
Fertilization and Implantation  
Human fertilization  
â€¢ Fertilization occurs when the nucleus of a sperm cell fuses with the nucleus of an egg cell  
â€¢ After intercourse, sperm cells swim through the mucus in the cervix into the uterus and then all 
the way to the oviduct  
â€¢ Many sperm cells do not survive this difficult which is why so many sperm cells are produced  
â€¢ To increase the chance of some of them reaching the oviduct  
â€¢ If there is an egg in the oviduct, a sperm cell may succeed in penetrating it  
â€¢ Enzymes released by the acrosome on the head of the sperm digest a pathway through the jelly 
coat surrounding the egg 
â€¢ After the sperm membrane has fused with the egg membrane the nucleus enters the egg 
cytoplasm and the flagellum is left outside  
â€¢ The sperm nucleus fuses with the egg nucleus to form the zygote nucleus which is diploid as it 
contains two sets of chromosomes 

â€¢ This stops other sperm cells from entering so only one sperm is able to fertilize the egg 
â€¢ If there is no egg in the oviduct, no fertilization can take place  
â€¢ However, the sperm can stay alive for 2 or 3 days  
â€¢ So if intercourse happened just before ovulation, the sperm can fertilize an egg released during 
this time  
 Implantation  
â€¢ Fertilization takes place in the oviduct  
â€¢ After this, the fertilized egg or zygote begins to divide  
â€¢ It divides once to form a two-celled embryo  
â€¢ Then it continues to divide to give four cells, then eight but after a while this cycle of divisions 
becomes less regular  
â€¢ Some cells continue to divide while other stop or slow down the rate at which they divide 
â€¢ After a few hours the embryo is a hollow ball of cell 
â€¢ It moves down the oviduct, pushed along by peristaltic contraction of the oviduct and the beating 
of the ciliated epithelial cells lining the oviduct  
â€¢ It may take a number of days for the embryo to the reach the uterus  
â€¢ The embryo embeds into the soft lining of the uterus  
â€¢ This is called implantation  
â€¢ The uterus lining has thickened in preparation and contains numerous blood vessels 
â€¢ The embryo obtains nutrients and oxygen from these blood vessels by diffusion  
â€¢ Carbon dioxide and chemical waste diffuse out in the opposite direction  
Pregnancy  
â€¢ Pregnancy is the period of time between fertilization and birth, which in humans is 9 months  
â€¢ This period of time is called the gestation period  
â€¢ After the embryo has implanted into the lining of the uterus, it grows projection into the soft 
tissue to gain nutrients and oxygen to support its growth  
â€¢ These projection continue to grow into the placenta 
â€¢ An umbilical cord grows to attach the fetus to the placenta so it fills the amniotic sac which 
surrounds it  
â€¢ The placenta is the site of oxygen and nutrients for carbon dioxide and other wastes; they diffuse 
between fetal blood and maternal blood 
â€¢ The fetus obtains all its food from its mother. It produces some urea which diffuses into the 
motherâ€™s blood to be excreted through her kidneys  
â€¢ The umbilical cord attaches the fetus to the placenta. The cord contains an artery that transports 
deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta and a vein that returns oxygenated blood to 
the fetus  
â€¢ The amniotic sac make amniotic fluid to surround and protect the fetus against mechanical 
damage 
â€¢ Amniotic fluid is formed from filtered blood has a composition similar to plasma. Cells from the 
fetusâ€™ skin are shed into the amnion sac and when the organs have developed the fetus carries 
out breathing movements taking fluid into the lungs. The fetus urinates the fluid and rinks it, it 
does not provide any nutrients for the fetus  

â€¢ The placenta acts as a barrier to toxins and pathogens. However, even though the womb is a 
sterile environment, the fetus is still susceptible to disease.  
â€¢ Rubella can case deafness and blindness in the fetus  
â€¢ The HIV virus that causes AIDs may cross the placenta so a baby may be born HIV positive if the 
mother is affected 
â€¢ However, with careful management the virus may not be transmitted to the fetus  
Main stages in the development into a baby to be born 
â€¢ One month after fertilization, a human embryo looks a bit like a fish embryo or tadpole. The 
embryo does not yet have arms or legs but it is clear where these will develop. The heart has 
started to beat 
â€¢ Two months after fertilization the embryo has a face, limbs, fingers and toes and looks human. It 
is now called a fetus. Most of the organs are formed  
â€¢ Three months after fertilization the nerves and the muscles of the fetus are developing rapidly  
â€¢ Five months after fertilization, although only about 180 mm in length, the fetus has perfectly 
formed eyebrows, fingernails, fingerprints and body hair. Its movement may have been felt by the 
mother for the last month  
â€¢ Seven months after fertilization development is almost complete  
Ante-Natal Care and Birth  
â€¢ Ante-natal care is the care before birth and it is vital for health of the fetus in the womb  
â€¢ A pregnant woman will need to ensure that she gets adequate quantities of: 
âœ“ Calcium as the bones of the fetus are growing  
âœ“ Iron so her body can make the extra red blood cells needed to carry oxygen to the fetus 
âœ“ Carbohydrates so that the pregnant woman has enough energy to carry her heavier body 
around  
âœ“ Protein to provide amino acids for the making of tissue in the motherâ€™s uterus for birth 
and new tissues in the developing fetus  
â€¢ The mother should not smoke since nicotine and carbon monoxide cross the placenta can result 
in premature or underweight  
â€¢ She should not drink alcohol, as it can cause a variety of effects including birth defects and 
mental defects  
â€¢ Drugs, such as heroine can diffuse across the placenta so the babies may be born addicted to 
heroine  
Birth 
â€¢ A normal pregnancy takes about 9 months  
â€¢ Some babies can be born prematurely perhaps because there has been a problem during 
pregnancy  
â€¢ An early breaking of amnion membrane around the fetus for the most common reason  
â€¢ A few weeks before birth, the fetus usually turns over inside the uterus 
â€¢ This positions its head above the cervix 
â€¢ Hormones released by the fetus and the build-up of pressure in the uterus stimulate hormonal 
changes in the mother  
â€¢ A hormone, oxytocin, is released from her pituitary gland that stimulates the muscles of the 
uterus to contract  

â€¢ The mother starts to feel small contractions of the uterus wall. This is the beginning of labor 
â€¢ These contractions become stronger and more frequent  
â€¢ Stronger contractions become stronger and more frequent  
â€¢ Stronger contractions slowly stretch the opening of the cervix and the amnion breaks, allowing 
the amniotic fluid to escape  
â€¢ The muscles of the uterus wall now contract very strongly and start to push the baby towards 
the cervix 
â€¢ The cervix widens or dilated and the babyâ€™s head is pushed through the vagina  
â€¢ This part of birth takes place quite quickly  
â€¢ As soon as it is born the baby breathes for the first time  
â€¢ It is important that the baby has airways clear if mucus and can breather easily  
â€¢ The umbilical cord is tied and cut just above the point where it attached to the baby  
â€¢ The remains of the cord heal to form the babyâ€™s navel 
â€¢ After a few minutes the placenta comes away from the uterus wall. it is pushed out of the vagina 
as the afterbirth  
â€¢ The process of labor with the muscular contractions of the uterus is painful for the mother  
â€¢ Pain killing drugs can also be given to ease the pain during birth  
â€¢ These may be given by an epidural 
â€¢ This involves inserting a catheter (tube) into the space between the spine and the spinal cord 
â€¢ The drugs prevents the transmission of impulses from pain receptors in the brain  
Breast Feeding  
Advantages  
Disadvantages  
Contains antibodies aiding passive immunity 
Can be embarrassing for the mother 
The child is less likely to develop some cancers 
and diabetes 
Mother may not be able to produce enough milk 
The mother is less likely to develop womb, breast 
and ovarian cancer 
Painful for mother 
Promotes bonding with the mother 
Father may feel secluded 
 
Breast milk vs formula 
â€¢ Breast milk contains antibodies 
â€¢ No sterilizing of equipment needed 
â€¢ No mixing of powder or need for boiled water 
â€¢ Cost nothing vs. expensive formula 
â€¢ HIV positive mothers may not be able to breast feed so formula is the only alternative 
Sex Hormones  
â€¢ You are born with a complete set of sex hormones but only become active later on in life, called 
puberty  
â€¢ Girls usually develop earlier than boys 
â€¢ The actual age of puberty varies from person to person  
â€¢ The changes that take place are all controlled by the hormones  

â€¢ At the beginning of puberty the pituitary gland at the base of the brain starts to make hormones 
that stimulate the testes and hormones  
â€¢ These make the sex organs active  
â€¢ The sex organs start to produce hormones which develop our secondary sexual characteristics  
Puberty in boys 
The testes start making testosterone which stimulates: 
â€¢ The growth of the male sex organs  
â€¢ The testes to make sperm cells 
â€¢ Growth of hair on the face  
â€¢ The deepening of the voice  
â€¢ Development of muscles in the body  
Puberty in girls  
The ovaries start making estrogen which stimulates: 
â€¢ The growth of the female sex organs  
â€¢ The start of the first menstrual cycle and the first period 
â€¢ Growth of hair on parts of the body  
â€¢ Growth and the development of breasts 
â€¢ Widening of the hips  
Menstrual Cycle  
Hormone  
Where it is produced  
Function 
FSH (Follicle 
Stimulating Hormone) 
Pituitary gland 
Stimulates the formation/maturation of an egg cell 
in the follicle 
Stimulates the formation of estrogen  
LH (Luteinizing 
Hormone) 
Pituitary gland 
Stimulates the thickening of endothelium lining  
Triggers the release if a mature egg from follicle 
Estrogen  
Ovary- follicle cells 
Inhibits the secretion of FSH 
Stimulates the secretion of LH 
Progesterone  
Ovary- corpus luteum 
Helps to maintain thickened lining of the 
endothelium  
 
Day 1 -5 
Ovary: 
â€¢ FSH secreted by the pituitary gland to stimulate the maturation of one/more follicles in the ovary  
â€¢ The egg is stored in the follicle  
Uterus: 
â€¢ The endothelium breaks down leading to menstruation  
 
 

Day 5-14 
Ovary: 
â€¢ Follicle keeps maturing  
Uterus: 
â€¢ FSH stimulates the secretion of estrogen by the follicle cells: the ovarian tissues starts to 
prepare the endometrium lining  
â€¢ Estrogen inhibits the secretion of FSH and stimulates the secretion of LH  
â€¢ Lining of the endothelium thickens 
Day 14/15 
â€¢ Ovary: LH also secreted by the pituitary gland trigger the release of the egg from follicle into the 
fallopian tube  
Day 15-28 
â€¢ Ovary: remains of follicle is called the yellow body (corpus lutem) which secretes progesterone  
â€¢ Uterus: progesterone secreted by the yellow body and the presence of estrogen keeps the 
endometrium thick, waiting for possible embryo implant. Inhibits the secretion of LH and FSH  
â€¢ Day 28: Scenario 1: The egg is not fertilized  
â€¢ No implantation takes place, the corpus lutem degenerated, causing a lack of progesterone 
â€¢ This means the endometrium lining is no longer thick  
â€¢ Back to day 1 
â€¢ Day 28: Scenario 2: Egg is fertilized 
â€¢ Implantation occurs. Embryo stimulates the yellow body to keep on forming progesterone and 
estrogen. Maintains the endometrium and inhibits FSH and LH formation.  
Methods of birth control  
â€¢ Birth control allows couples to decide when, and how many children they want to have  
â€¢ To prevent pregnancy the birth control should either: 
i. 
Stop the sperm from reaching the egg 
ii. 
Stop the eggs from being made 
iii. 
Stop the fertilized egg from implanting and developing in the uterus 
Barrier methods 
â€¢ The cap or diaphragm is a rubber dome. The woman places it over her cervix before intercourse. 
It prevents the manâ€™s sperm from entering the uterus. It should be cleaned with sperm-killing 
cream or foam  
â€¢ The condom is a thin rubber tube. It is rolled over a manâ€™s erect penis before intercourse. It stops 
sperm from entering the womanâ€™s body. It also gives protection against STIs.  
â€¢ A femidom is the female equivalent of a condom and is inserted into the vagina.  
Chemical methods 
â€¢ The IUD (intra-Uterine Device) is a small plastic device that is wrapped in copper or contains 
hormones. It is fitted inside the womanâ€™s uterus and it is thought to work by preventing sperm 

passing through the uterus. It may also prevent an embryo from implanting in the uterus should 
conception occur 
â€¢ IUS (intra-uterine system) is a small T-shaped device that is placed in the uterus. It contains 
progesterone that is released slowly and causes the mucus in the cervix to become thick and 
sticky, making it unlikely that sperm will swim through  
â€¢ The pill is an oral contraceptive taken by mouth. They contain estrogen and progesterone in 
varying concentrations. There are also progesterone-only pills. These work by preventing the 
release of eggs. As a result, no eggs mature to be released by the ovaries and so pregnancy 
does not occur. This pill has to be taken every day 
â€¢ It is a reliable and convenient form of contraception  
â€¢ However, failure to take the pill regularly can result in pregnancy 
â€¢ The side effects of the pill include: sore breasts, weight gain, depression and painful periods 
â€¢ In a very small number of women, the pill can be the cause of heart and circulation problems 
â€¢ A contraceptive implant is a small flexible rod that is placed just under the skin of the upper arm. 
It releases progesterone which prevents ovulation and works for up to 3 years 
â€¢ Contraceptive injections also contain progesterone. There are different types that work between 
8 and 13 weeks  
â€¢ Spermicides are chemicals that kill sperm. They are sold as foam, cream or jelly. The woman 
puts the cream into her vagina before intercourse. Spermicides are not very effective on their 
own and should be used with another method  
Natural methods  
â€¢ Abstinence  
â€¢ Rhythm method- this relies on determining when ovulation is most likely to occur and abstaining 
from sex in the days just before and after that date  
â€¢ A woman keeps a record of when she has her periods and then predicts each month when 
ovulation should occur 
â€¢ This is about 2 weeks after having her period  
â€¢ This is not a very reliable method, especially in women who do not have very regular periods 
â€¢ Symptoms based method-e.g. checking for an increase in body temperature and changes in 
cervical mucus that becomes wetter and less sticky just before ovulation. 
Surgical methods 
â€¢ Vasectomy- a manâ€™s sperm tubes are cut and tied. The operation is not usually reversible. The 
man can still ejaculate but there are no sperm in the semen, just fluid  
â€¢ Sterilization- a womanâ€™s oviducts are cut and blocked.  
Control of fertility  
Fertility drugs 
â€¢ Couples are regarded as being infertile if they have had regular, unprotected sexual intercourse 
for 12 months without the woman becoming pregnant 
â€¢ The most common cause of infertility in women is that the woman does not release eggs 
â€¢ This may be due to the lack of FSH 
â€¢ Treatment for this type of infertility may involve regular injection of a fertility drug containing 
FSH 

â€¢ Other treatments involve tablets that make the pituitary insensitive to estrogen  
â€¢ Estrogen inhibits the production of FSH  
â€¢ So if the effect of estrogen on the pituitary is blocked by the drug, the pituitary continues to 
releases FSH and ovulation occurs 
â€¢ Unfortunately, fertility treatment does not always work for a variety of reasons that may not be 
easy for doctors to discover 
â€¢ Or it may work to well resulting, in twins, triplets or even quadruplets 
Artificial insemination  
â€¢ Some couples cannot have kids because the male in infertile 
â€¢ This may be because does not produce enough sperm or they are problems with ejaculation  
â€¢ It is possible that semen may be collected from them man and placed via a fine plastic tube into 
the womanâ€™s uterus. This process is called artificial insemination (AI). 
â€¢ If the man does not produce enough sperm for this, or if the sperm is defective then a donor may 
provide a sample of semen for the AI. 
â€¢ AI by a donor can lead to problems later in life because the childâ€™s father is not the biological 
father who probably remains unknown 
In vitro fertilization  
â€¢ Egg and sperm are collected from potential parents and mixed together in a laboratory dish 
where fertilization occurs 
â€¢ To increase the chances of success, the woman is often injected with FSH to stimulate the 
development of several follicles so that several eggs can be collected from her ovaries 
â€¢ A small incision is made in the body wall and a fine plastic tube inserted to collect the eggs from 
the follicles on the surface of the ovaries  
â€¢ The eggs are kept in a solution that contains nutrients and oxygen  
â€¢ Semen is collected from the man/sperm donor and is mixed with the eggs and left for up to 24 
hours for fertilization to occur 
â€¢ A technician checks that fertilization has occurred and that the zygotes have started to divide 
into embryos 
â€¢ These are kept in the solution for a few days and then the doctor places them into the womanâ€™s 
uterus  
â€¢ If the procedure is successful, the embryo will develop into a fetus  
â€¢ It is also possible to take the nucleus from a defective sperm cell and inject it into an egg 
â€¢ The zygote is then cultured for several days so it grows into an embryo and is transferred into 
the woman in the hope that it implants in the uterus  
The social implication of contraception and fertility treatments 
â€¢ IVF is an expensive procedure and is not available to all 
â€¢ Success rates for IVF are often about 30% for woman under 35 years of age 
â€¢ In countries with a publically funded NHS decisions have to be made about who receives IVF and 
how many repeats should be done if the first one in unsuccessful 
â€¢ In many parts of the world, childless couples are unable to afford this treatment 
â€¢ A problem is what to do with spare embryos that are implanted 
â€¢ Some maintain that it is not acceptable to just dispose of them or use them for medical research  

Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) 
â€¢ A sexually transmitted infection (STI) is a disease that is transmitted via body fluids during 
sexual contact.  
â€¢ STIs include HIV, syphilis and gonorrhea amongst the major infection that can be transmitted 
Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) 
â€¢ The main type of cell that it infects is a type of lymphocyte  
â€¢ HIV may lead to the development of Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) 
â€¢ If someone has been infected with HIV they are known as HIV+ 
â€¢ The virus weakens the bodyâ€™s immune system  
â€¢ It is easier for the HIV+ person to be infected by other diseases such as TB and pneumonia  
â€¢ People who do not have HIV are described as HIV negative 
HIV and lymphocytes 
â€¢ HIV attacks and destroys an important type of lymphocyte that coordinated the immune system 
â€¢ During an infection these lymphocytes stimulate other lymphocytes to produce antibodies 
â€¢ During an HIV infection the number of these T lymphocytes decreases is fewer antibodies are 
produced every time there is another infection  
â€¢ By reducing the number of T lymphocytes, HIV weakens the bodyâ€™s ability to fight disease 
â€¢ Eventually the person infected with HIV will succumb to any number of other infections because 
of their weakened immune system  
â€¢ AIDS is the name given to a collection of diseases brought on by the weakening of the bodyâ€™s 
immune system  
â€¢ The early symptoms of AIDS are very much like flu, with swollen glands and a high temperature.  
â€¢ Later the symptoms may include weight loss, various types of cancer and a decrease in brain 
function 
â€¢ Not all HIV+ people develop AIDS 
â€¢ Some remain HIV+ without any symptoms at all  
How is HIV transmitted? 
â€¢ HIV is transmitted in the blood and semen 
â€¢ The virus can pass from one person to another during unprotected sex 
â€¢ The virus can also be passed via hypodermic needles contaminated with infected blood 
â€¢ In this way, HIV is spread quickly amongst drug addicts who share needles 
â€¢ Unborn babies are also at risk of HIV 
â€¢ This is because the virus can pass across the placenta to the fetus  
â€¢ Even more likely is its passage from the motherâ€™s blood at birth when the two bloodstreams 
come into close contact  
â€¢ HIV can also be transmitted in breast milk  
â€¢ Blood used for transfusions is another way which HIV has been transmitted  
How can HIV/AIDs be prevented? 
â€¢ There is no cure for HIV/AIDS and no vaccine for HIV 
â€¢ There are anti-viral drugs e.g. AZT, and some of these prevent the virus from multiplying inside 
the body cells  

â€¢ Antibiotics do not work against viruses, but people with AIDs tale them to treat the bacterial and 
fungal infections that they have 
â€¢ Since HIV cannot be cured, it is important to prevent the transmission of the virus 
â€¢ Contact tracing is used to identify people who may have been put at risk either as a result of sex 
or the sharing of needles 
â€¢ These people are offered an HIV test which reveals the presence of HIV antibodies in their blood 
â€¢ However, the antibodies only appear after several weeks of the person being infected 
â€¢ Other methods to reduce the spread include: 
âœ“ The use of condoms to provide a physical barrier to transmission of the virus during sex 
âœ“ Setting up free needle exchange schemes for people who inject drugs 
âœ“ Screening donated blood for HIV antibodies and eliminating contaminated blood 
âœ“ Educational programs that make people aware of HIV and how it can be prevented

Potatoes are transported in the phloem from the leaves into these underground stems that swell as they convert sucrose into starch .  Wind pollinated flowers are small, green and inconspicuous compared to insects pollinated by the wind . Cross pollination involves the transfer of pollen from the anthers of one flower to the stigma of  another flower on a different plant of the same species .  Cell expansion makes the radicle (embryonic root) grow out from the seed . This swelling breaks the seed coats of some seeds . Water is also needed to dissolve the soluble products made by enzymes from the food stores .  The testes are the male sex organs that produce the male gametes/spermatozoa or sperm . The female gamete is called the ovum or egg . Ovaries are organs that make the female sex hormones that produce eggs called ova or ova . The ovaries tend to release eggs on an ovary about 28 days every 28 days . After puberty, an egg is released from the ovaries every month for about 28 months .  One month after fertilization, a human embryo looks a bit like a fish embryo or tadpole . A normal pregnancy takes about 9 months . The sex organs start to produce hormones which develop secondary sexual characteristics .  The IUD (intra-Uterine Device) is a small plastic device that is wrapped in copper or contains hormones . It is fitted inside the womanâ€™s uterus and it is thought to work by preventing sperm from passing through the uterus . A femidom is the female equivalent of a condom and is inserted into the vagina . Spermicides are chemicals that kill sperm and are sold as foam, cream or jelly .  Couples are infertile if they have had regular, unprotected sexual intercourse for 12 months without becoming pregnant . The most common cause of infertility in women is that the woman does not release eggs . Treatment for this type of infertility may involve regular injection of a fertility drug containing FSH .  HIV may lead to the development of Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS) AIDS is the name given to a collection of diseases brought on by the weakening of the bodyâ€™s immune system . raw_text:
Inheritance 
Chromosomes, genes and DNA 
â€¢ The transfer of features from one generation to the next is called inheritance  
â€¢ The characteristics are controlled by genes which are like coded instructions 
â€¢ The study of inheritance is known as genetics 
â€¢ Genes from one generation are transmitted to the next in the gametes 
â€¢ At fertilization, the gametes fuse to form a zygote which contains the genetic information from both 
parents  
â€¢ A new individual grows from the zygote-half of its genetic information comes from its male parent 
and half from its female  
Chromosomes  
â€¢ A chromosome is a thread of DNA, made up of a string of genes 
â€¢ There 46 chromosomes in the nucleus of a human cell 
â€¢  This is called the diploid number 
â€¢ The chromosomes are different shapes and sizes 
â€¢ They can be sorted into pairs based on their shape and size 
â€¢ Chromosomes are made out of a long chain molecules called DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) 
â€¢ DNA is wound around molecules of protein 
â€¢ During cell division the DNA and protein are packed very tightly together and the chromosomes 
are coiled up 
â€¢ At other times they are uncoiled so the cell can use the information in the DNA 
Genes 
â€¢ Genes are lengths of DNA 
â€¢ Each chromosome has many genes along its length, although the actual number depends on its 
length 
â€¢ Each gene is a unit of inheritance in that it codes for a specific protein  
â€¢ It is a chemical code that the cell interprets as an instruction to make a protein molecule 
â€¢ Human have between 20 000 to 25 000 different genes  
â€¢ The proteins produced by cells influence how the body works and what it look like 
â€¢ Some features that genes control are influenced by the environment (height i.e. diet & exercise) 
â€¢ Other genes are not affected by the environment (e.g. blood group) 
Protein synthesis 
â€¢ The length of DNA, making up a particular gene carries the information needed to make a 
particular protein.  
â€¢ Inside every cell, there are thousands of different chemical reactions taking place 
â€¢ Enzymes control all these chemicals  
â€¢ DNA determines which enzymes are produced in each cell and therefore which chemical reaction 
take place inside cells 
â€¢ The structure of DNA contains bases 
â€¢ The information is found in the sequence of bases along the length of DNA 
â€¢ These determine the sequence of amino acids in the protein  

â€¢ DNA also controls the production of antibodies and receptors for neurotransmitters 
â€¢ DNA carries information to build proteins from amino acids 
â€¢ The information moves from the DNA to the site of the protein synthesis in the ribosomes by a 
kind of messenger molecule 
â€¢ This molecule is mRNA (messenger RNA) 
â€¢ The role of mRNA is to carry a copy of the base sequence on DNA out of the nucleus to the 
ribosomes in the cytoplasm where protein synthesis occurs 
The genetic code  
â€¢ There are four different bases found in DNA (A,T, C and G) 
â€¢ Each amino acid is coded for by a different base triplet on DNA 
â€¢ When mRNA copies the code on DNA it does so by the rule of base pairing 
â€¢ However, mRNA does not have the base T-this is replaced by another base U (uracil) 
â€¢ Therefore A on DNA will code for U on mRNA 
The coded information on mRNA is used to assemble amino acids in the correct sequence for each 
protein. 
â€¢ The mRNA arrives at the ribosomes from the nucleus 
â€¢ The mRNA strand contains the base triplets for each particular amino acid in the protein  
â€¢ The mRNA then passes through the ribosomes and each ribosome assembles amino acids into 
protein molecules 
â€¢ The amino acids bond together forming a long chain-the protein 
â€¢ The specific order of amino acids is determined by the sequence of the bases in the mRNA and 
each amino acid is joined to the next one by a peptide bond 
All body cells in an organism contain the same genes. However, in a particular cell many genes may not 
be expressed because the cell makes only the specific proteins it needs  
Mitosis 
â€¢ Mitosis is a type of nuclear division that occurs during growth and asexual reproduction. The 
daughter cells are genetically identical 
â€¢ Before a cell can divide, new copies of genetic information in the DNA of the chromosomes must 
be made 
â€¢ This copying process occurs before the nucleus divides 
â€¢ While it is going on, the DNA in the chromosomes is uncoiled and arranged very loosely in the 
nucleus 
â€¢ The new copy of DNA of each chromosome is attached to the original copy 
â€¢ As mitosis begins, the DNA coils up so that each chromosome becomes thicker  
â€¢ During mitosis, the two copies separate so each new cell gets a copy of each chromosome  
â€¢ As a result of mitosis, each daughter cell has the same chromosome number as the original parent 
cell 
â€¢ As the chromosomes have been copied by a reliable system, they are genetically identical to each 
other and to the parent cell 
â€¢ If they were genetically different they would be rejected by the bodyâ€™s immune system  
â€¢  
 

The Significance of mitosis 
Mitosis is important for the following processes: 
â€¢ Growth  
â€¢ Repair of wounds 
â€¢ Replacement of cells that wear out and die 
â€¢ Asexual reproduction  
Stem Cells 
â€¢ Some of the cells that form an embryo remain as unspecialized cells 
â€¢ They do not develop into any type of specialized cell 
â€¢ These cells keep dividing by mitosis to provide the body with a constant supply of new cells 
â€¢ These cells are needed to replace cells that get worn out and die 
â€¢ Each time a stem cell divides, one daughter cells starts to become specialized for some specific 
function  
â€¢ The other daughter cells remains unspecialized and undergoes mitosis again  
Meiosis 
â€¢ Meiosis is a type of cell division that is essential for sexual reproduction  
â€¢ It takes place in the reproductive organs and results in the formation of gametes with half the 
normal chromosome number  
â€¢ This is known as the haploid number  
â€¢ Meiosis halved the number of chromosomes so egg cells and sperms cells have 23 chromosomes 
each  
â€¢ The zygote has 46 chromosomes, 23 from the motherâ€™s egg cell and 23 from the fatherâ€™s sperm  
â€¢ Meiosis occurs in sex organs in humans- the ovaries and testes 
â€¢ In flowering plants meiosis occurs in the anthers and in the ovules 
â€¢ In meiosis the daughter cells are not identical 
â€¢ They are genetically different and this contributes to genetic variation that provides the raw 
materials for selection and allows organisms to evolve in response to changing environments 
Differences between mitosis and meiosis  
Mitosis  
Meiosis  
One division  
Two divisions 
The number of chromosomes remains the same 
The number of chromosomes is halved 
The daughter cells are genetically identical 
The daughter cells are genetically different from 
the parent cells

Inheritance and genes 
â€¢ Pedigree diagrams show how features are inherited in families  
â€¢ An allele is a version of a gene. Most genes have many alleles 

â€¢ The genotype is the genetic makeup of an organism;  the phenotype is all the features of an 
organism other than its genotype 
â€¢ A dominant allele is always expressed in the phenotype  
â€¢ A recessive allele is only expressed when no dominant allele is present  
â€¢ A homozygous individual has two identical alleles of a gene and a heterozygous individual has 
two different alleles of a gene 
Monohybrid inheritance 
â€¢ Monohybrid inheritance involves the inheritance of a single characteristic such as plant height or 
flower color 
Codominance  
â€¢ Codominance occurs when both alleles are expressed in the phenotype as neither is dominant 
over the other

â€¢ All egg cells contain an X chromosome

chromosome  
â€¢ Since there are equal numbers of sperm with the X chromosome and sperm with the Y chromosome, 
there is an equal chance of the zygote inheriting XX or XY and the child being female or male  
Sex inheritance  
â€¢ The Y chromosome is very small and much smaller than the X 
â€¢ Therefore the Y chromosome has fewer genes than the other chromosomes and far fewer than the 
X 
â€¢ One gene of the Y chromosomes stimulates the development of the testes in the embryo 
â€¢ If it is not present/mutated then the body that develops is female  
 
 

Sex Linkage  
â€¢ The genes that are located on the chromosomes are described as sex-linked even though they 
have nothing to do with determining gender or controlling sexual characteristics 
â€¢ Among the gens in the X chromosomes are genes involved with controlling vision and blood 
clotting  
â€¢ Males only have one copy of the genes that are on the X chromosomes, if any of them are recessive 
then the effect will be seen  
â€¢ Because women have two X chromosomes they are less affected by sex linked recessive alleles 
and this is why sex-linked conditions are more common in boys than in girls

Variation and selection 
Variation  
Types of variation 
â€¢ All humans have many features in common as we are all members of the same species 
â€¢ We have many features in common but there are significant differences which we use to 
categorize animals into different species 
â€¢ In biology, the term variation means: 
o Differences between species- we use them when constructing keys 
o Differences within species 
â€¢ There is considerable variation between individuals of the same species 
â€¢ Variation occurs in the feature we can see 
â€¢ Variation also occurs in features we cannot see which need specialist equipment to detect 
â€¢ For example, the different types of hemoglobin called phenotypic variation  
â€¢ Genetic variation is the differences between the genotypes of individuals. 
â€¢ There are two types of phenotypic variation within a species: 
o Continuous variation  
o Discontinuous variation  
Continuous variation  
â€¢ If a frequency histogram is plotted, it is likely that the mean height will be in the middle of the 
range and correspond to the group with the largest number of people 
â€¢ This type of distribution is called a normal distribution  
â€¢ This type of variation is called continuous variation 
â€¢ For example, there are many genes that contribute to your overall height 
â€¢ However, other factors such as quantity and quality of food you eat and the amount of exercise 
you take also influence your height 
â€¢ People also go through growth spurts at different ages that influence the results 
â€¢ Continuous variation also occurs in plants 
Discontinuous variation 
â€¢ Some people have attached earlobes, other people do not 
â€¢ This is called discontinuous variation  
â€¢ In this type of variation there is usually a small number of phenotypes and no intermediates 
â€¢ Discontinuous variation is caused by genes alone and the environment has no effect 
â€¢ The ABO blood group is another example  
â€¢ It is either A, B, AB or O 
â€¢ There are no intermediates 
â€¢ Some flowering plant species have flowers of distinctly different colors 
Inheritance versus the environment 
â€¢ Identical twins develop from the same embryo are genetically identical 
â€¢ However, they are different in many ways 

â€¢ These differences will have come about because they developed slightly differently in the womb 
and have been exposed to different environmental influences 
â€¢ Identical twins separated at birth, or shortly afterwards, and brought up apart often show 
striking similarities 
â€¢ These are often to do with personality, which shoes the influence that genes have on us 
â€¢ The effect of environmental factors can be investigated with plants  
â€¢ For example, the Mexican hat plant 
â€¢ You can detach these plants and grow them in pots and keep them under different conditions 
â€¢ Any variation shown will be because of environmental factors 
Mutations 
â€¢ A mutation is a change in a gene or chromosome that may cause a change in a phenotypic 
characteristic 
â€¢ A gene mutation is a change in the base sequence of DNA 
â€¢ Often the change can be harmful, but some mutations can be beneficial or have no effect at all 
Causes of mutation 
â€¢ Gene mutations are the only way in which new alleles are formed 
â€¢ They are caused by damage to DNA or by a failure in copying process that occurs before 
nuclear division 
â€¢ They occur naturally at random, but the rate at which they occur is increased by exposure to 
ionizing radiation and some chemicals 
â€¢ UV radiation, X-rays and Gamma rays are the most damaging  
â€¢ The greater the dose of radiation, the greater the chance of mutation  
â€¢ If mutation occur in body cells, they may affect the individual 
â€¢ Gene mutations are the cause of many human genetic diseases 
â€¢ Sickle cell anemia is an example 
â€¢ It is only mutation that occur in gamete-forming cells, or gametes themselves, are important in 
the long term 
â€¢ This is because these mutations can be inherited and provide new forms of variation  
Sickle cell anemia 
â€¢ These red blood cells are in the shape of a sickle 
â€¢ These cells have abnormal hemoglobin which makes it difficult for the red blood cells to carry 
oxygen 
â€¢ SCA can prove fatal if the distorted blood cells block blood vessels  
â€¢ Or if the spleen destroys the abnormal cells at a greater rate than red blood cells can be 
produced, causing anemia  
â€¢ SCA is a genetic disease resulting from a gene mutation  
â€¢ The normal allele, ğ»ğ‘ğ´ or ğ»ğ´, codes for normal hemoglobin  
â€¢ The mutant allele, ğ»ğ‘ğ‘† or ğ»ğ‘†, codes for the abnormal form of hemoglobin  
â€¢ The two alleles are codominant  
â€¢ People who are heterozygous have both forms of hemoglobin in their red blood cells 
â€¢ Heterozygous who carry one SCA allele have a much milder form of the disease called a sickle 
cell trait 

â€¢ The possession of two SCA alleles puts a great selective disadvantage since the abnormal form 
of hemoglobin is not very good at transporting oxygen which causes several problems 
â€¢ The SCA allele is common among people from areas where malaria is common  
â€¢ This is because people who are heterozygous have both abnormal and normal forms of 
hemoglobin and do not usually have a problem with transport of oxygen 
â€¢ But they do have a resistance to malaria as the parasite that causes this disease cannot enter 
red blood cells 
â€¢ The link between SCA heterozygotes and resistance to malaria is an example of natural selection  
o There is a strong selection pressure against people who are homozygous for sickle cell 
anemia, ğ»ğ‘†ğ»ğ‘†, because they could die of anemia 
o There is a strong selection pressure against people homozygous for the normal allele, ğ»ğ´ğ»ğ´, 
because they could die from malaria 
â€¢ In areas where malaria is common, there is a strong selective advantage for heterozygous 
individuals, ğ»ğ´ğ»ğ‘†, since they do not suffer badly from anemia and they are protected from 
anemia 
â€¢ So the sickle cell allele remains in the population in areas where malaria is an important 
selective agent 
Adaptive features 
â€¢ An adaptive feature is an inherited feature that helps an organism to survive and reproduce in 
its environment 
â€¢ Adaptive features are behavioral as well as structural 
â€¢ Adaptive features are likely to increase an individualâ€™s fitness which refers to its chances of 
surviving in its environment, reproducing and having offspring  
Pond plants 
â€¢ Hydrophytes are plants that grow submerged or partially submerged in water 
â€¢ Buoyed up by water, with no need for water transport, floating plants save energy since they 
produce little or no xylem tissue 
â€¢ Roots, if present are for anchorage as there is no need to absorb water and mineral// no root 
hair cells 
â€¢ The leaves and stems of hydrophytes have little or no cuticle since there is no need to conserve 
eater 
â€¢ The problem with hydrophytes is that carbon dioxide needed for photosynthesis diffuses slower 
through water than air 
â€¢ The same applies for oxygen since it is not soluble in water 
â€¢ Many hydrophytes have an extensive system of air spaces in their stems and leaves which allow 
gases to diffuse through quickly 
â€¢ These air spaces provide buoyancy to keep the plants close to the light 
â€¢ They are reservoirs of oxygen and carbon dioxide 
Desert adaptations 
â€¢ All plants have to balance water uptake and loss 
â€¢ It is important that they maintain the turgor in their cells, or they will wilt 
â€¢ Very high rates of transpiration can kill a plant if it cannot absorb enough water to prevent long-
term wilting 

â€¢ Xerophytes are plants that exist in conditions where water is scarce 
â€¢ Cacti are xerophytes that survive in hot, dry, arid and desert regions  
â€¢ Cacti reduce water loss and conserve water in the following ways: 
o Their leaves are reduced to spines, reducing the surface area over which water can be 
lost 
o A thick, waxy cuticle covers the plants surface and reduces transpiration  
o They have swollen stems containing water-storage tissue 
o They have a shallow, spreading root system to quickly absorb any water from rain and 
overnight condensation  
o Many cacti have a round, compact shape which reduces surface area over which water 
can be lost 
o They have shiny surfaces which reflect heat and light  
o Their stomata are closed during the day to reduce water loss 
Natural Selection 
â€¢ Natural selection is the process by which organisms are well adapted to their environment have 
a greater chance to breed and pass on their alleles to the next generation that those that are less 
well adapted  
Variation within populations 
â€¢ Variation is the term used to describe all the differences that exist within populations of 
organisms 
â€¢ Gene mutation is the only way in which completely new genetic material is produced 
â€¢ Some mutation may give an advantage to the individual that expresses them  
â€¢ Variation is also produced by sexual reproduction between two individuals 
â€¢ During meiosis, the alleles of different genes are shuffled to give new combination in the gametes 
â€¢ At fertilization, when the gametes fuse, alleles from two different individuals are combined within 
the same nucleus 
â€¢ Gene mutation, meiosis and fertilization give rise to variation between individuals in every 
generation  
Competition for resources 
â€¢ Among the organisms that survive the early stages of life there is competition for resources 
â€¢ Plants compete for space, light, water and nutrients 
â€¢ Animals compete for food, water, territories and mates 
â€¢ This is known as the struggle for existence or struggle for survival 
â€¢ Competition is fiercer between individuals of the same species 
â€¢ This is due to the fact that they have the same adaptive features to obtain their resources from 
the environment 
â€¢ Individuals in different species also competed but the competition is not as fierce 
Reproduction  
â€¢ The individuals with features that adapt them to the conditions in the environment are those most 
likely to survive and reproduce 
â€¢ Individuals that are not so well adapted are likely to lose out in the competition for resources 

â€¢ They may die before they have a chance to reproduce, or if they do reproduce, they have few 
offspring  
â€¢ The better adapted individuals have a greater chance to pass on their alleles to the next 
generation  
Natural selection 
â€¢ If the environment does not change, then natural selection maintains populations of organisms 
so they do not change much, as many are already well adapted to their environment  
â€¢ Natural selection will bring about a change in species over time 
â€¢ Thus selection is the mechanism by which evolution occurs 
â€¢ Evolution is a process of adaptation whereby population become more suited to their 
environment over generations 
Antibiotic resistance 
â€¢ Antibiotics are chemicals that kill bacteria or inhibit their growth  
â€¢ When bacteria are exposed to an antibiotic they are killed 
â€¢ However some individual bacteria that have a mutation may have resistance to an antibiotic  
â€¢ The bacteria may be able to produce an enzyme that breaks down the antibiotic 
â€¢ These individual bacteria survive and now have more resources available as all their 
competitors- the non-resistant bacteria, have died 
â€¢ The resistance bacteria survive to reproduce and pass on this gene to their offspring 
â€¢ This is an example of natural selection  
â€¢ Humans have been responsible for the change in environment by introducing antibiotics 
â€¢ But we have not consciously chosen the bacteria which are resistant to antibiotics 
Selective breeding  
â€¢ Domesticated plants and animals have changed considerably over time due to artificial selection 
â€¢ These changes have happened in this way: 
o Humans choose a desirable feature or features of an animal or plant to improve 
o Animals or plants showing these features are bred to produce the next generation 
o The offspring are checked to find those that show an improvement in the desired feature 
or features. These are kept for breeding the next generation 
o This process of selective breeding continues for many generations 
â€¢ Selective breeding (artificial selection) involves humans finding organisms with desirable 
features, crossing them and selecting the best from the next generation  
â€¢ Commercial farmers want to increase the yields of their crops and animals 
â€¢ They want to improve features of economic importance to maximize their profits 
â€¢ This is called artificial selection as it is humans who are the selective agent not the environment 
â€¢ The danger of selective breeding is that there may be too much inbreeding between closely 
related individuals 
â€¢ This may result in harmful recessive alleles being passed on to the descendants and a reduction 
in vegetation 
 
 

Differences between artificial selection and natural selection  
Artificial selection 
Natural selection 
Selection due to human influences 
Selection due to environmental factors 
Produces varieties of organisms very different 
from native generations 
Produces greater biodiversity 
Does not result in new species 
May result in new species 
Inbreeding is common, leading to loss of vigor in 
the offspring 
Outbreeding is common, leading to hybrid vigor 
A relatively fast process 
A slow process, taking many years 
Proportion of heterozygous individuals in the 
population is reduced 
Proportion of heterozygous individuals in the 
population remains high 
 
There are two main methods of carrying out selective breeding: 
Outbreeding 
â€¢ Involves breeding of unrelated animals or plants 
â€¢ This may be used to combine the good characteristics of separate individuals 
â€¢ Outbreeding often results in tougher individuals with a better chance of survival 
â€¢ This is called hybrid vigor 
Inbreeding 
â€¢ Involves breeding close relative in an attempt to retain desirable characteristics 
â€¢ There can be harmful effects as a result of inbreeding  
â€¢ This can include loss of vigor, with the population weakened by a lack of gene diversity and 
reduced fertility 
â€¢ There is also a greater susceptibility to disease

Organisms and their environment 
Energy flow 
â€¢ The sun is a principal source of energy input into biological systems 
â€¢ Light energy is absorbed by photosynthetic organisms and made available to all other 
organisms as chemical energy  
â€¢ Energy transfer occurs when animals feed on plants and when animals feed on other animals 
â€¢ Eventually the energy is transferred to the environment as heat and is lost 
â€¢ Nutrients consist of chemical elements that make up living organisms 
â€¢ They are taken up by plants, passed on to animals and eventually recycled back inti biological 
systems 
â€¢ This is known as nutrient cycling, since they are constantly reused  
Communities 
â€¢ Producers make their own organic nutrients from simple raw materials, such as carbon dioxide 
and water 
â€¢ Green plants use light as a source of energy to make sugars from carbon dioxide and water by 
photosynthesis 
â€¢ Some bacteria are also producers as they are photosynthetic or obtain their energy from simple 
chemical reactions 
â€¢ Some bacteria involved in recycling nitrogen obtain their energy from reactions involving 
nitrogen 
â€¢ Producers make energy available for all the other members of the community in the form of 
energy-rich carbon compounds (carbohydrates, fats and proteins) 
â€¢ Sunlight is the ultimate source of energy for almost all food chains 
â€¢ The major exception are the vent communities in the deep ocean that rely on chemical energy 
rather than sunlight energy 
â€¢ Consumers obtain their energy by eating other organisms, either plants or animals or both 
â€¢ They cannot make their own food, so they have to consume it 
â€¢ Herbivores are primary consumers as they eat the producers 
â€¢  Carnivores are secondary consumers as they eat herbivores 
â€¢ Tertiary consumers are carnivores that eat other carnivores, called top carnivores 
â€¢ Decomposer are fungi and bacteria that gain their energy from waste organic material 
â€¢ Each of these feeding groups is a trophic level 
Food Chains 
â€¢ Food chains show what living organism feed on in a community  
â€¢ They show the flow of energy from one organism to the next 
â€¢ The arrows show the direction in which energy in food is transferred from one organism to the 
next 
â€¢ Food chains not only show the flow of food, they also show the flow of energy 
â€¢ Producers gain their energy from the sun, so an energy chain would look like this:

â€¢ We donâ€™t include the sun in food chains as it is not a food 
â€¢ Food chains start with producers 

â€¢ Energy flows to decomposers but they are rarely included in these simple food chains 
Food Webs 
â€¢ Animals will eat more than one type of living organism  
â€¢ A food web gives a more complicated picture of feeding relationships in an ecosystem  
â€¢ The over-harvesting of food species by humans in an unsustainable manner can result in a 
decrease in their numbers and extinction  
â€¢ Also the introduction of foreign species can displace native organisms due to predation and 
competition for resources 
â€¢ These disrupt food chains and food webs due to the removal of a species or a decrease in their 
numbers 
Pyramids of numbers and biomass 
Pyramids of numbers 
â€¢ Pyramids of numbers show how many individuals there are at each trophic level but give no 
indication of their size  
Pyramids of biomass 
â€¢ Pyramids of biomass indicate the mass of living material at each trophic level, but give no 
indication of the rate of growth  
â€¢ Biomass is the mass of living material  
â€¢ A biomass pyramid shows the actual weight or mass of living things at each trophic level  
â€¢ To draw a biomass pyramid, the data first needs to be collected 
â€¢ A sample of the organisms from each trophic level is taken and weighed  
â€¢ The average mass of the sample is calculated  
â€¢ The average mass is then multiplied by the estimated number of organisms present in the 
community  
â€¢ Dry mass tells us how much useful biological material is present as carbohydrates, proteins, 
and fats as food for the organisms in the community  
â€¢ The data is usually expressed in grams per square meter 
â€¢ The dry mass recorded is taken at one instant in time  
â€¢ Biomass pyramids do not take into account how fast an organism grows 
â€¢ This means it is better to calculate the biomass produced over a period of time  
â€¢ Biomass can vary with the seasons  
Shortening the food chain 
The efficiency of energy transfer 
â€¢ The efficiency of energy transfer between trophic levels can be seen by using energy pyramids 
â€¢ These show the energy transferred from one trophic level to the next 
â€¢ Energy is always lost as it passes from one trophic level to the next  
â€¢ Since only some of the energy is passed from one trophic level to the next an energy pyramid is 
never inverted 
â€¢ Its shape is not affected by the size of the organisms or how many of them there are since it 
simply looks at the energy has been passed on  

Energy Losses 
â€¢ Energy flows through ecosystems is relatively insufficient 
â€¢ At best plants absorb only 2-5% of the light energy that strikes their leaves 
â€¢ Much of this energy is not trapped in photosynthesis because it is reflected from the surface 
of the leaves, it passes straight through them or is green light which they cannot absorb 
â€¢ Plants use as much of the energy they trap in photosynthesis in their own respiration  
â€¢ As an energy process, respiration is about 40% efficient 
â€¢ Much of the plantâ€™s biomass us lost to decomposers 
â€¢ About 10% of the energy tapped by the plant is available to secondary consumers 
â€¢  Much of what they eat is not very edible or easy to digest 
â€¢ So primary consumers make available about 10% of what they have eaten to secondary 
consumers 
â€¢ At each trophic level, energy is lost as heat to the environment and consumers loses energy 
in their faeces to decomposers 
â€¢ Food chains on land are rarely more than four trophic levels  
â€¢ When farmers grow crops, all the energy in the grain is available to us primary consumers  
â€¢ Livestock farmers grow or buy their plant food to feed their animals  
â€¢ Animals use up most of the energy in their food 
â€¢  This means that there is not as much energy available to us 
â€¢ A vegetarian diet can support more people 
â€¢ This is because we are cutting down the 90% wastage of energy that occurs between each 
trophic level  
â€¢ People in many countries tend to have diets that mainly consist of food of plant origin or 
some meat or fish 
â€¢ The human population is increasing  
â€¢ If farmers are to provide enough food for everyone, our diet may change to one that includes 
more plant matter and less animal matter 
Nutrient cycles 
Nutrient cycling 
â€¢ Most living matter (95%) is made up of six elements: carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, 
phosphorus and sulfur 
â€¢ Living things must have a constant supply of these elements if they are to make proteins, 
carbohydrates, fats and other organic materials 
â€¢ There is a finite source of these nutrients 
â€¢ Bacteria and fungi feed on dead and decaying matter 
â€¢  They also feed on the waste matter of animals (urine and faeces) 
â€¢ They feed by breaking down carbohydrates, fats and proteins into small molecules that they can 
absorb 
â€¢ Many of these are respired 
â€¢ To do this they require water and a warm temperature as the process of digestion and 
respiration are catalysed by enzymes 
â€¢ They also need oxygen for aerobic respiration  
â€¢ Decomposers release carbon as carbon diocese when they respire 

â€¢ They also break down amino acids releasing ammonia into their surroundings  
â€¢ In thus way they recycle carbon and nitrogen  
â€¢ Single compounds are absorbed by plants and concerted into complex compounds 
â€¢ These nutrients are then passed in to animals when they eat the plants  
â€¢ We say that nutrients are cycled 
The carbon cycle 
â€¢ Carbon is used to make carbohydrates, proteins, fats, DNA and other important biological 
molecules 
â€¢ The carbon comes from carbon dioxide in the air 
â€¢ Plants also absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and use it in photosynthesis to make 
food 
â€¢ Animals get the carbon compound by eating plants 
â€¢ Carbon dioxide gets into the air in the following ways: 
o Plants and animals use some of their food for respiration, releasing carbon dioxide 
o Decomposer use dead plants and animals for food. They also use some of the decaying 
material for respiration, releasing carbon dioxide 
o  Fossil fuels and natural gas contain carbon. Carbon dioxide is one of the gases released 
in the air during combustion when these fuels are burnt  
â€¢ These processes release carbon dioxide in the air and balances the uptake from photosynthesis 
so the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere remains constant  
â€¢ Sometimes, dead plants and animals do not decompose 
â€¢ Their dead bodies become fossilised to form coal and gas-fossil fuels 
The water cycle 
â€¢ The water cycle demonstrates how important water is to life on earth 
The nitrogen cycle 
â€¢ Nitrogen is an element required for many biologically important molecules 
â€¢ Amino acids, proteins, DNA and chlorophyll contain nitrogen  
â€¢ Approximately 80% of the air is nitrogen gas  
â€¢ It is not useful to many organisms in this form 
â€¢ It has to be made available to them in the form of compounds such as amino acids and proteins, 
and ions such as nitrate and ammonium ions  
â€¢ Most of the nitrogen that plants absorb is in the form of nitrate ions 
â€¢ They use the amino acids in their leaves 
â€¢  The amino acids are used to form proteins such as enzymes 
â€¢ Animals eat plants and so obtain their nitrogen in the form of plant protein  
â€¢ Any excess amino acid are broken down to ammonia by deamination 
â€¢ Animals that live on land convert the ammonia to urea and excrete it in urine  
Decomposers 
â€¢ Break down dead remains and animal waste releasing ammonium ions 
â€¢ Bacteria also break down urea in urine to ammonium ions (deamination) 
 

Nitrifying bacteria 
â€¢ Change ammonium ions to nitrate ions 
â€¢ Bacteria gain their source of energy from the oxidation reaction  
Nitrogen-fixing bacteria 
â€¢ Convert nitrogen gas from the air into compounds of nitrogen that they use themselves 
â€¢ When they die this nitrogen ions available to plants 
â€¢ Nitrogen fixing bacteria is found is some legumes (peas, beans, alfalfa) 
â€¢ The bacteria are inside swellings on the roots called root nodules 
â€¢ These bacteria change nitrogen gas into ammonia that the legume plants use to male amino 
acids 
â€¢ In return, the legumes provide a stable environment for the bacteria 
â€¢  Nitrogen fixation requires a lot of energy  
Denitrifying bacteria 
â€¢ Live in water logged soil  
â€¢ Change nitrate ions to nitrogen gas 
â€¢ They balance the uptake of nitrogen gas by nitrogen fixing bacteria 
Lightning 
â€¢ Causes nitrogen and oxygen to react together at high temperatures 
â€¢ Nitrogen oxides are formed in these reactions 
â€¢ Nitrate ions are lost from the soil before plants can absorb them as they are washed out by water 
(leaching) 
â€¢ Farmers add fertilisers containing nitrogen to the soil  
â€¢ This provides material that enters the nitrogen cycle at the point where decomposers act 
Populations, communities and ecosystems 
Population growth 
â€¢ A population is a group of individuals of the same species living in the same habitat at the same 
time  
â€¢ All the individuals in a population may interbreed 
â€¢ Sometimes it is difficult to tell the geographical limits of a population  
â€¢ Some species are widely distributed and it is difficult to divide them into separate populations 
â€¢ However, there are usually barriers to reproduction such as rivers and mountains that divide 
them into separate populations 
â€¢ Some individuals migrate across these barriers, so there in interbreeding between populations  
â€¢ A community includes all the populations of different species in an ecosystem 
â€¢ An ecosystem is a unit containing the community of organisms and their environment  
â€¢ An ecosystem is made up of the biotic component (the community) and the abiotic component 
(physical factors: light, water, pH and temperature) 
 
 

Population size 
â€¢ The number of births adds to the population and the number of deaths decreases it  
â€¢ Individuals may enter or leave a population from neighbouring populations  
â€¢ Animals migrate so there is mixing between populations 
â€¢ Plant use seed dispersal to colonise new areas in this way individuals leave one population of 
plants to enter another  
â€¢ The main factors that affect the rate of population growth is food, predation and diseases 
â€¢ An organism that enter a new habitat may show the lag, exponential and stationary phases if 
there is plenty food, no predation and diseases 
â€¢ Competition for resources: plants compete for light, space, water and soil nutrients. Animals 
compete for food, space and mates 
â€¢ Predation: predators often take young, sick individuals or less well-adapted individuals. 
Predators may limit the growth of a population of prey animals. But it more often that the 
population of prey animals limits the population size of the predator  
â€¢ Disease: pathogens are transmitted more easily when organisms live close together  
The growth of a population: bacteria 
â€¢ A small number of bacteria are placed into a flask with a warm nutrient solution which is aerated 
so the bacteria may respire aerobically  
â€¢ Bacteria grow and divide under these conditions  
â€¢ Some species of bacteria divide every 20 minutes if conditions are ideal  
Phases of bacterial growth 
1. The lag phases, when doubling of the numbers has little effect as the numbers are so small. 
Bacteria take up water and nutrients and make new cytoplasm, DNA and enzymes 
2. The exponential or log phase when the population is increasing rapidly. The population 
increases by doubling and there are no limiting factors. After a while, lack of food and build-up 
of waste limits the population growth which slows down and stops 
3. The stationary phase, when bacteria cells are dying at the same rate at which they are being 
produced. This may be because of shortage of food or because waste products are building up  
4. The death phase, when more cells are dying than being produced so the population declines, 
causes of death may be lack of food, shortage of oxygen or a build-up of toxic waste products. 
The curve is known as a sigmoid growth curve 
â€¢ Some species show this population in the wild 
â€¢ When resources become available, species that can reproduce rapidly grow exponentially  
â€¢ When the resources are used up, most of them die 
â€¢ Most species do not do this, they remain fairly stable over time  
Human population  
Human population growth 
â€¢ Lack of food and shelter together with the effects of malnutrition, diseases and wars meant that 
mortality rates were high and people did not live long  
â€¢ The human population has increases exponentially over the past 300 years for the following 
reasons: 

o Improved agriculture means that most people are better fed. Better nutrition means they 
are better defended against diseases, especially those caused by malnutrition  
o Public health has improved. There are clean water supplies, drainage of waste and 
sewage treatment. This has decreased epidemics of waterborne diseases such as cholera 
o  Medical care has improved. People are also vaccinated against many infectious diseases 
â€¢ The effects of these improvements have been: 
o Decrease in the infant and child mortality rates 
o Decrease in death rates from starvation and malnutrition  
o Increase in life expectancy  
â€¢ In spite of these improvements there are huge inequalities in food, housing, water and health 
services 
â€¢ Many of the worldâ€™s human population live in poverty with high infant and child mortality rates 
Controlling human population growth 
â€¢ There are still controls on population increase 
â€¢ Famine, epidemics, floods, wars, tsunamis and other disasters lead to loss of life 
â€¢ The earth has limited resources and limited space and the population will have to stabilise and 
even decrease at some time in the future 
â€¢  The most obvious way to do this is to reduce the birth rate 
â€¢ Many groups of people have strongly held religious or moral views on birth control and family 
size 
â€¢ This means they often have large families 
â€¢ The rate of increase in population is most influenced by the proportion of child bearing women 
in the population 
â€¢ Increasing the human population size brings greater demands on resources and problems for 
the environment such as the supply of housing, food, transport and energy needs 
â€¢ There is also the problem of how to dispose of our rubbish
summary_text: The sun is a principal source of energy input into biological systems . Light energy is absorbed by photosynthetic organisms and made available to all other organisms as chemical energy . Nutrients consist of chemical elements that make up living organisms . They are taken up by plants, passed on to animals and eventually recycled back inti biological systems . The arrows show the direction in which energy in food is transferred from one organism to the next .  Carbon dioxide is one of the gases released in the air during combustion when these fuels are burnt . Fossil fuels and natural gas contain carbon . The water cycle demonstrates how important water is to life on earth . Nitrogen is an element required for many biologically important molecules .  The exponential or log phase is when the population is increasing rapidly and there are no limiting factors . After a while, lack of food and waste limits the population growth which slows down and stops . The human population has increases exponentially over the past 300 years for the following reasons: improved agriculture means that most people are better fed and better nutrition means they are better defended against diseases .

Microorganisms and biotechnology 
The use of microorganisms and biotechnology 
â€¢ Biotechnology is the use of microorganisms such as bacteria and fungi to make useful products 
or carry out services for us.  
â€¢ The use of both bacteria and fungi are in various processes is widespread 
o Bacteria reproduce very quickly with a generation time of less than 30 minutes 
o Unlike animals and plants, microbes can convert raw materials into the finished product 
very quickly  
o The use of bacteria means that food production can ne independent of climate 
o Bacteria can produce complex proteins that pass out into the surrounding medium and 
can be harvested. Enzymes made by microorganisms are used in the food industry  
â€¢ Examples of enzymes that are produced by bacteria for use in the food industry are: 
o Amylase for breaking down starch in the production of glucose syrup  
o Pectinase for extracting juice from fruit 
o Sucrose for breaking down sucrose in making confectionery  
o Protease for making meat more tender 
â€¢ With the aid of genetic engineering, scientists can quickly alter microbes and so modify products 
â€¢ Breeding new varieties of plants and animals can take a long time 
â€¢ Plasmids in bacteria are easy to work with, since they replicate very quickly 
â€¢ Plasmids can be cut open by enzymes and a gene from another organisms can be spliced into 
them  
â€¢ In nutrient media, bacteria multiply rapidly, making many copies of the plasmid and the inserted 
gene 
â€¢ The use of bacteria and fungi in the manufacture of complex chemicals raises some ethical 
concerns over their manipulation and growth  
Biofuels and bread making  
â€¢ Many microbes can respire successfully without oxygen  
â€¢ Yeasts can respire with or without oxygen  
â€¢ When yeast respires without oxygen (anaerobically) it is called fermentation
