Biofuels 
â€¢ Biofuels are fuels made from biological materials 
â€¢ The raw materials often used is sugar cane juice which contains a lot of carbohydrates 
â€¢ Glucose from maize starch is another raw material 
â€¢ This is obtained by treating the starch with carbohydrase enzymes 
â€¢ Ethanol is a good substitute for petrol because it has a high energy content when burnt and 
does not produce toxic gases 
â€¢ Using ethanol as fuel means there is no overall increase in carbon dioxide in the atmosphere 
â€¢ As a result this fuel is carbon neutral 
â€¢ Car engines need to be modified to be able to use pure ethanol  
â€¢ Oil seed rape is a crop that provides oil that is converted into fuel called biodiesel  
 

Bread making 
â€¢ Baking is another example of using yeast to produce a food 
â€¢ Bread is made from dough 
â€¢ This mixture is kept at a warm temperature 
â€¢ The yeast starts to ferment the sugar, producing carbon dioxide gas and alcohol 
â€¢ Bubbles of carbon dioxide are trapped inside the dough and make it rise 
â€¢ When the bread is baked in a hot oven the bubbles of the gas make the bread light in texture 
â€¢ The heat causes the alcohol to evaporate leaving behind the traditional taste of bread ] 
Enzymes and biotechnology  
Biological washing powders 
Biological washing powders may contain one or more of the following enzymes: 
â€¢ Proteases to break down protein stains  
â€¢ Lipases to break down fats in grease stains 
â€¢ Amylases to break down starch 
â€¢ Celluloses to break down cellulose fibers on the outside of cotton fabric to remove the dirt 
attached to them  
â€¢ The enzymes have been modified so that they withstand the high temperatures and alkaline 
conditions  
â€¢ During a wash cycle, the enzymes break down the stains and the products of the reaction 
dissolve or are suspended in water and are removed when the washing machine is emptied  
Extracting fruit juices 
â€¢ Pectinases are enzymes that break down pectin 
â€¢ Pectins are molecules that act like glue in plant cell walls 
â€¢ Pectinases are used for extracting fruit juices and for softening vegetables 
The use of lactase in making lactose-free milk  
â€¢ Some people do not produce enough lactase and therefore have problems digesting lactose 
â€¢ They may get diarrhea, wind or stomach cramps if they consume lactose products 
â€¢ Lactose is a complex sugar, similar to sucrose that can be broken down into simple sugars by 
lactase 
Fermenters 
Industrial production of penicillin  
â€¢ One important use of large-scale industrial fermentation is the production of antibodies such as 
penicillin  
â€¢ The fermenter is inoculated with a culture of suitable fungus  
â€¢ Then fermentation is carried out under certain conditions that have to be maintained inside the 
fermenter  
â€¢ These conditions should include: 
o Adding nutrients, such as sugar or starch as a source of carbon for respiration 
o Ammonia or urea is added as a source of nitrogen to make proteins 

o Vitamin B complex is added for respiration  
o Maintaining a constant temperature of about 30Â°C 
o Maintaining a constant pH of about 6.5  
Batch Culture 
â€¢ It takes about 30 hours for penicillin production to start 
â€¢ Penicillin is secreted into the surrounding liquid by fungus 
â€¢ This is because penicillin is a secondary metabolite, a substance which is not necessary for the 
growth of fungus 
â€¢ Penicillin production starts after the exponential growth phase in response to one or more 
limiting factors 
â€¢ After about 6 days, the mixture in the fermenter is filtered, the penicillin is extracted using a 
solvent and then purified into a crystalline salt  
â€¢ This type of production is known as batch culture 
â€¢ After the 6 day period, the fermenter is emptied, cleaned and sterilized ready for the next batch 
Industrial fermentation 
â€¢ Industrial fermenters are large tanks that can hold as much as 500 000 ğ‘‘ğ‘š3 of fermenting 
mixture 
â€¢ Conditions inside these huge tanks are carefully controlled 
â€¢ How fermenters work: 
o The fermentation vessel is made of stainless steel and is filled with a medium containing 
the required nutrients. These include sugars and ammonium salts. Some of the fungus is 
added 
o The fungus grows well in the conditions in the fermenter. Sugars provide energy for 
respiration and ammonium salts are used by the fungus to make proteins and nucleic 
acid. After a few days, the fungus starts to produce penicillin, which accumulates in the 
fermenter 
o A stirrer keeps the microorganisms suspended so they always have access to nutrients 
and oxygen. Stirring also helps to maintain an even temperature throughout the fermenter 
o An air supply provides oxygen for the aerobic respiration of the fungus 
o A water-cooled jacket removed the heat produced by fermentation to give a constant 
temperature of 24Â°c 
o Probes monitor the temperature and make sure the pH is constant at 6.5 by adding alkalis 
if necessary 
Genetic engineering  
â€¢ Genetic engineering involves changing the genetic material of an organism by removing, 
changing or inserting individual genes 
â€¢ A gene is a section of DNA that codes for the production of a specific protein  
â€¢ Genetic engineering is the transfer of a gene from the DNA of one species to the DNA of another 
species 
â€¢  This is a process that can never be achieved by artificial selection because only in rare species 
would one species breed with another 
â€¢ Genetic engineering allows the transfer of genes between totally unrelated species 

Examples of genetic engineering  
Human medicines 
â€¢ Insulin, human growth hormones and blood clotting agents are produced by bacteria that have 
been genetically modified with the appropriate human genes 
â€¢ These proteins are mass produced and used as medicines 
Herbicide resistance in crop plants 
â€¢ Genetically modified variety of rape seed has been developed in which a gene is transferred into 
it from a soil bacterium  
â€¢ This gene makes oilseed rape resistant to the herbicide glufosinate 
â€¢ When applied to fields of oilseed rape this herbicide would not only kill the weeds but the crop 
itself 
â€¢ But the GM oilseed rape is not affected by the herbicide and so continues to grow while only the 
weed is destroyed 
Insect resistance in crop plants 
â€¢ Maize and cotton can be attacked by insects which reduce their yields 
â€¢ The major pests of maize are root worm larvae and stem-boring caterpillars 
â€¢ The genetically modified plants produce their own toxin which kills insect larvae that feed on it 
â€¢ This has less environmental impact than sprayed pesticides, because only the insects feeding on 
the crop plants are killed 
Additional vitamins in crop plants 
â€¢ GM varieties of rice have been developed by transferring genes from maize and a soil bacterium, 
that enables people to make vitamin A 
â€¢ The resultant rice is a pale yellow in color giving its name, Golden Rice 
â€¢ If, or when, this rice becomes available to grow on a large scale it will improve the diets if the 
people who eat it  
â€¢ They will be able to make vitamin A 
â€¢ This will reduce the high mortality rates as a result of poor immune systems  
Industrial production on insulin  
â€¢ Genetic engineering makes it possible to make insulin quickly and cheaply on a large scale  
â€¢ The human gene that codes for the production of insulin is identified 
â€¢ Restriction enzymes act as chemical scissors to cut the human insulin-making gene from the rest 
of DNA 
â€¢ A circular piece of DNA called a plasmid is removed from a bacterium 
â€¢ The same restriction enzymes are then used to cut open the plasmid 
â€¢ The two ends of the DNA of the insulin-making gene are an exact match with the two DNA ends 
and the plasmid 
â€¢ These are called sticky ends 
â€¢ Another enzyme called ligase is used to attach the sticky ends of the insulin-making gene to the 
sticky ends and plasmid 
â€¢ The plasmid is now known as a recombinant plasmid as is inserted back into the bacteria 

â€¢ The bacteria now has the gene code for insulin  
â€¢ The bacteria multiply very rapidly inside an industrial fermenter and produce insulin  
Advantages and disadvantages of genetically modified crops 
Benefits: 
â€¢ Solving global hunger- GM could feed more people as the crops that are produced are able to 
tolerate extreme climate conditions and soils. Food production could be increased in marginal 
areas 
â€¢ Environmentally friendly- GM crops can be resistant to insects, weeds and diseases so there will 
be less use of pesticides. Also genes that improve nitrogen uptake would mean less need for 
chemical fertilizers and lessen the environmental threat they pose 
â€¢ Consumer benefits- GM crops have already been produced with improved flavor and better 
keeping qualities. They are easier to produce and require less additives 
Concerns: 
â€¢ Environmental safety- There are concerns that new GM plants will become successful weeds. 
Pollen from GM crops are resistant to weed killers and may be transferred to other plants by 
insects or the wind 
â€¢ Food safety- new gene combinations may have effects that are so far unknown, they result in 
harmful substances being produced 
â€¢ Biodiversity- increasing use of herbicides and plant breeding will reduce the number of plant 
varieties and wild varieties

Human Influences on Ecosystems 
Food Supply 
Increased food production 
â€¢ Modern technology has improved food supplies in many parts of the world 
â€¢ Arable farms use large agricultural machines to work very large fields 
â€¢ Chemical fertilizers encourage the growth of crops 
â€¢ Pesticides kill pests  
â€¢ Herbicides kill weeds that compete with the plant for resources 
â€¢ Selective breeding has increased yield and made crops more resistant to drought and disease 
â€¢ Genetic engineering has transferred features to crops from unrelated species 
â€¢ Intensive farming is using modern technology to achieve high yields of crop plants and livestock 
â€¢ This involves growing crop plants over large areas at high densities and keeping livestock in 
large numbers 
â€¢ In many intensive systems, animals are reared indoors in large numbers 
â€¢ Intensive methods have negative effects on the environment  
â€¢ Cattle produce methane which is a greenhouse gas 
â€¢ Urine and faeces pollute lakes, waterways and seas where it can cause eutrophication 
â€¢ The waste from animal farms can have serious effects on surroundings 
â€¢ High densities of animals means that parasites and pathogens can spread easily 
â€¢ This means using pesticides and antibiotics to treat animals and this could cause resistance to 
those chemicals 
â€¢ A monoculture is growing the same crop on large areas, year after year 
â€¢ This has an advantage of allowing farmers to concentrate on growing large quantities of a crop 
â€¢ This also has negative effects on the environment  
â€¢ Herbicides and pesticides kill harmless plant and insect species that may even help the plant  
â€¢ Continuous us of these chemicals act as selective agents, resulting in the evolution of pests, 
weeds and pathogens 
â€¢ The large scale use of chemical fertilizers can reduce the structure of the soil  
â€¢ Reduces biodiversity of soil organisms that support crop growth 
â€¢ The addition of organic mature, such as manure helps to maintain a good soil structure 
World Food Supply 
â€¢ As the world population increased, farmers ability to produce enough food increased] 
â€¢ There is enough food to feed everyone, but many people die of starvation and malnutrition  
â€¢ Shortage of food is caused by politics, economics, wars and poverty  
â€¢ Many poorer countries produce enough food to feed their population but have to sell food or 
grow non-food cash-crops to gain foreign currencies 
â€¢ Drought, flooding, pests and diseases may cause crops to fail  
â€¢ Famine is most often caused by failure to supply food to those at risk of starvation 
â€¢ Often there are problems transporting food to places where there is famine  
Social, environmental and economic implications 
â€¢ Food production requires large areas of land 

â€¢ This has meant that groups of people have been displaced, sometimes forcibly  
â€¢ Land clearance for plantations and ranching has resulted in environmental damage 
â€¢ As farming has become increasingly mechanized, there is not enough employment available 
â€¢ This has driven people away from rural areas to cities for employment  
â€¢ Intensive agriculture requires large input of energy from burning fossil fuels 
â€¢ It also requires much investment by large corporations intent on profit making  
Habitat destruction 
Reasons for habitat destruction  
â€¢ The clearance of land for crop production and for the production of biofuels 
â€¢ Space to build units for livestock production and cattle rearing  
â€¢ Digging mine and quarries for the extraction of coal and mineral ores, such as iron ore and 
bauxite 
â€¢ More people require more housing and associated infrastructure 
â€¢ Space for long-term storage of waste and recycling of it 
â€¢ Marine pollution. Major pollutants of the sea include fertilizers, which are thought to cause algal 
bloom in the sea, oil from oil wells and ships and industrial chemicals  
Human influences on food chains and webs 
â€¢ Killing of large predators- humans have killed many of these because they are dangerous 
â€¢ Killing of large herbivores for food- there were many different species of these in large numbers 
â€¢ Overfishing  
â€¢ Removing species results in unbalanced food webs and unbalanced ecosystems that are further 
at risk of damage and other factors 
â€¢ Top predators control the population of primary consumers 
â€¢ Their removal means that population of herbivorous animals increases and so there is increased 
competition for the plant food that they eat 
â€¢ The effect can be overgrazing and habitat destruction  
Deforestation  
â€¢ Humans have cleared forests to grow food, to provide space and transport links  
â€¢ There are now very few forests left 
â€¢ Deforestation has resulted in a number of environmental problems: 
o The extinction of species 
o The loss of soil  
o An increase in flooding  
o The increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere 
â€¢ When vegetation is removed from tropical forests, the soil is easily washed away causing 
erosion, formation of gullies and loss of plant nutrients 
â€¢ The land is rapidly degraded after all tress are cut down  
â€¢ Local weather patterns change with more frequent and severe storms 
â€¢ Flooding happens more frequently as water runs off the land and is not absorbed and transpired 
by plants 
â€¢ Forests act as stores of water, their leaves slow down the rate of evaporation and decrease the 
rate at which water reaches the soil 

â€¢ Carbon dioxide is added to the atmosphere when vegetation in burnt  
â€¢ There is increased decomposition that also releases more carbine dioxide which is not absorbed 
by plants  
â€¢ Rainforests have no effect on maintaining the correct balance of carbon dioxide and oxygen in 
our atmosphere  
â€¢ They produce about as much carbon dioxide as they use in photosynthesis 
â€¢ There is no evidence that rainforest are the lungs of the earth  
â€¢ Destruction of rainforests means the loss of many habitats and the extinction of many species 
â€¢ There are many species in rainforests that are yet to be discovered and classified

Waste Plastics 
â€¢ Biodegradable materials are those when thrown away can be broken down in the environment by 
decomposers 
â€¢ Some materials are unable to be broken down and are known as non-biodegradable  
â€¢ Plastics are used for packaging because they last a long time and do not decay easily  
â€¢ This becomes a problem when it comes to disposing of plastics 
â€¢ Most plastic wastes go into landfills where they take up a lot of space 

â€¢ Biodegradable plastics are designed to break down more quickly that non-biodegradable 
conventional ones 
â€¢ We can recycle many thermoplastics by melting and molding them into new shapes 
â€¢ Burning plastics in incinerators reduces volumes of waste but produces toxic gases when they 
burn 
â€¢ Non-biodegradable plastics pose a threat to aquatic life too  
â€¢ Animals can swallow plastic bags mistaken for food 
â€¢ Aquatic animals can become entangled in discarded plastic wastes and other forms of plastic  
Water pollution  
Pollution of rivers and seas 
Rivers empty toxic waste into the sea, resulting in the following: 
â€¢ Fertilizers and sewage encourage the growth of algae that release toxins 
â€¢ Pesticides are concentrated in the tissues of some mollusks  
â€¢ Radioactive chemicals are found in higher concentration around coastal nuclear power stations 
â€¢ Toxic metals, such as mercury, copper and lead are found in tissues of marine organisms 
â€¢ Sewage is the biggest single pollutant 
â€¢ It encourages the growth of algae and bacteria which use up a lot of oxygen killing fish and small 
invertebrates 
â€¢ If raw untreated sewage is dumped in a river it encourages the growth of bacteria that feed on 
organic matter 
â€¢ As water travels downstream, the water gradually improves as suspended waste settle out and 
are decomposed by bacteria  
â€¢ If no more sewage is dumped in the river, the community recover as the oxygen concentration of 
the water increases 
â€¢  In many countries sewage is treated so that raw sewage is not deposited into rivers 
â€¢ Fertilizers drain from the land into rivers and lakes  
â€¢ Problems occur if a farmer uses too much fertilizer of if the fertilizer is added at the wrong time  
Eutrophication 
â€¢ Water is enriched with plant nutrients 
â€¢ This is the sequence of events: 
o Fertilizer can be washed through the soil into rivers and streams- this is called 
leaching. The rivers may flow into a lake 
o Once in the water, this stimulates population growth of algae. Nutrients in the 
fertilizers are usually low in concentration in the water and so limit the growth of 
algae 
o Animals that eat the algae do not multiply fast enough to control their growth 
o Algae cover the surface layers of water, reducing the light reaching plants at the 
bottom of the lake 
o These plants eventually die and rot on the river bed 
o Algae also die as there is competition for resourced and many are shaded by the 
algae on the surface 
o Decomposers, such as bacteria, feed on dead plants and algae 
o Bacteria respire aerobically, multiply rapidly and use up the dissolved oxygen  

o The concentration of oxygen decreases and this kills fish and invertebrates that 
cannot respire properly 
â€¢ 
The same chain of events occurs if sewage gets into waterways 
â€¢ 
Bacteria multiply quickly and use up the oxygen available  
â€¢ 
The problems of eutrophication are caused by nitrate and phosphate 
â€¢ 
These ions are in short supply in most aquatic ecosystems 
â€¢ 
So they are the limiting factors to the growth of plants 
â€¢ 
When they are added in the form of fertilisers, plant growth increases 
â€¢ 
Farmers are encouraged to add appropriate amounts of fertilisers at appropriate times 
â€¢ 
Removing phosphate from detergents has reduced the amount of phosphate in the soil 
â€¢ 
Nitrate in the sea causes the growth of algae, many of which produce toxins and kill other marine 
life 
The effects of contraceptive hormones 
â€¢ Many women take contraceptive pills containing oestrogen  
â€¢ The hormone is excreted in urine and is found in sewage 
â€¢ The active ingredient in contraceptive pills is synthetic oestrogen known as E22 
â€¢ Oestrogens are not broken down in all sewage treatment plants 
â€¢ They pass through unchanged into rivers and lakes 
â€¢ Male fish and amphibians respond to this oestrogen in water by gaining certain female 
characteristics (intersex) 
â€¢ This is also called feminisation 
â€¢ This involves producing eggs inside their testes 
â€¢ Having some female structures and making a protein found in egg yolk 
â€¢ In addition their sperm cells do not develop properly 
â€¢ An increase in oestrogens in drinking water has been linked to the decrease in sperm count in 
men  
â€¢ There are other sources of oestrogen in the environment 
â€¢ Many other synthetic chemicals have the same effect  
â€¢ These chemicals are in plastics in waste from the agriculture industry 
â€¢ E22 is removed from the waste water from some sewage works so the rest could be upgraded 
â€¢ The use of charcoal filters is one way of doing this  
â€¢ Upgrading sewage works and drinking water treatment works will be expensive 
The Greenhouse Effect 
Greenhouse gases 
â€¢ Some of the gases in the atmosphere act like a greenhouse to keep in heat 
â€¢ Greenhouse gases are: carbon dioxide, water vapour and methane 
â€¢ Some man-made air pollutants such as CFCs also are also greenhouse gases 
â€¢ These greenhouse gases allow solar energy to pass through the earthâ€™s surface 
â€¢ Some energy enters food chains and is eventually lost in the atmosphere as heat 
â€¢ This is radiated away from the earthâ€™s surface 
â€¢ Some heat energy escapes into space but much is reflected back towards the earth  
â€¢ The greenhouse effect is a natural process which is essential to maintain suitable temperatures 
on earth  

â€¢ Power station, factories, domestic heating and transport using fossil fuels has released large 
amount of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere 
â€¢ After deforestation, roots and other remaining tree parts are decomposed by microbes in the 
soil, producing even more carbon dioxide 
â€¢ There has also been a significant increase in methane due to rice paddy fields and cattle rearing 
â€¢ Rotting material and the extraction of oil and natural gas are other sources of methane 
Climate Change 
â€¢ Human activities are causing an increase in the concentration of greenhouse gases 
â€¢ The atmosphere is getting warmer 
â€¢ This is causing the enhanced greenhouse effect  
â€¢ There is a fear that this warming is increasing  
â€¢ If the temperature were to rise over 0Â°C then the polar ice would start to melt 
â€¢ This would cause a rise in sea level and flooding in many low lying area 
â€¢ This could also cause a change in wind patterns and the distribution of rainfall leading to more 
extreme weather 
â€¢ Some parts are expected to become very dry 
â€¢ This could lead to a reduction of grain crops 
â€¢ The pattern of the worldâ€™s food distribution could be affected with economic and political 
consequences 
â€¢ Measures to reduce the effect of climate change involve reducing carbon emissions 
â€¢ This may be done by utilising public transport, using energy efficiently, recycling and altering 
the diet of cattle so they produce less methane 
The Greenhouse Effect 
â€¢ Solar radiation passes through the atmosphere and warms the earthâ€™s surface 
â€¢ The earth radiates heat energy back into space. This is mainly infra-red radiation  
â€¢ Some of this heat is absorbed by the greenhouse gases 
â€¢ This causes the air to warm up 
Acid Rain  
â€¢ Sulfur dioxide is released when fossil fuels are burned 
â€¢ Together with nitrogen oxides from exhaust fumes, they cause acid rain  
â€¢ Rain is naturally acidic as the water dissolves carbon dioxide 
â€¢ When sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide dissolve in water in the atmosphere and react with 
oxygen they produce sulfuric and nitric acid which lower the pH 
â€¢ These gases can be carried over large distances by winds before being deposited as dry 
particles or dissolved in the rain 
â€¢ When acid rain falls on tress it kills the leaves and reduces their resistance to disease 
â€¢ Vegetation is affected by high concentrations of sulfur dioxide 
â€¢ Some species of lichen are sensitive to sulfur dioxide and grow only where the air is free 
â€¢ Some are able to tolerate high conditions 
â€¢ Others can tolerate intermediate conditions 
â€¢ By looking at the species growing in area, you can deduce the average concentration of sulfur 
dioxide 

â€¢ When acid rain falls on soils on limestone or on chalk it has little effect 
â€¢ This is because the soils are alkaline and neutralizes the acid 
â€¢ When it falls on soils on hard rock such as granite, the soil is already acidic and there is nothing 
to neutralize the acid 
â€¢ Acid rain causes plant nutrients to become soluble and wash out of the soils leaving them 
infertile  
â€¢ Aluminum compounds in soil become soluble at a pH lower than 5.5 
â€¢ Acidified water that enters streams, lakes and rivers lowers the pH of these bodies 
â€¢ The aluminum concentration also increases considerable 
â€¢ Small invertebrates and fish cannot survive in such low pH conditions and aluminum ions are 
toxic 
â€¢ There is measures that prevent acid rain such as: 
o Low sulfur fuels could be used. Crushing coal and washing it with a solvent that dissolves 
the sulfur compounds reduces its sulfur content  
o Flue gas desulfurization removes the sulfur from power stations by treating the waste 
gases with wet powdered limestone, neutralizing the acidic gases before they can escape 
o Catalytic convertors can be fitted to reduce the nitrogen oxides in the exhaust fumes of 
cars 
Sustainable resources 
â€¢ A resource is any substance, organism or source of energy that we take from the environment  
â€¢ A sustainable resources is a resource which is renewed by the activities of organisms so that 
there is always enough to take from the environment without it running out  
â€¢ Nonrenewable resources are those which cannot be regenerated or reproduced. These 
resources cannot be replaced 
The need to conserve fossil fuels 
There are various ways to conserve fossil fuels for the future: 
â€¢ Use fossil fuels more efficiently by burning them to make full use of the energy released on 
combustion  
â€¢ Reduce wastage of energy 
â€¢ Reducing the demand for petrol/gasoline 
â€¢ Recycling materials 
â€¢ Alternatives to fossil fuels: wind energy, solar energy., hydro electrical power, nuclear power, 
burning rubbish and wood from fast growing willow tees  
Sustainable timber production 
â€¢ Timber is a valuable resource 
â€¢ As soon as the trees are felled, they are replanted 
â€¢ The replanting is an example of restocking so that resource can be harvested without depletion 
â€¢ Some governments manage forests by issuing permits to logging companies 
â€¢ They are given quotas so they do not take more trees than they can regrow  
 
 

Sustainable development  
â€¢ Certain areas of the sea are declared off limits for fishing during the breeding season  
â€¢ Quotas are issued by fishing authorities so that boats cannot take too many fish in each season  
â€¢ Fishing nets have to be a certain minimum size so certain small fish can escape and survive and 
breed 
â€¢ Some stocks of fish can be restocked if it is possible to breed them in captivity and raise them in 
hatcheries 
Sustainable development  
â€¢ Sustainable development aims to provide the needs of an increasing human population without 
harming the environment  
â€¢ Ssustainable development requires: â€“ management of conflicting demands â€“ planning and co-
operation at local, national and international levels   
Sewage treatment and recycling  
Sewage treatment  
There are three main stages in the treatment of sewage: 
â€¢ Primary treatment involves removing large solids by filters or screens. The grits and organic 
solids are allowed to settle out in large tanks 
â€¢ Secondary treatment involves microbes, mainly bacteria decomposing material suspended in 
water. This happens in two ways: 
o The activated sludge process in which air is pumped through the sewage with a 
community of bacteria, fungi and protoctists which respire in aerobic conditions and 
break down carbohydrates, proteins and fats to carbon dioxide. Urea is broken down to 
ammonia and then converted to nitrate ions 
o Trickle filters are beds of gravel covered with microbes, the liquid from the primary 
treatment is sprayed over these beds from large rotating arms. As the liquid trickles 
through the gravel, the microbes break down the organic matter 
â€¢ Tertiary treatment involves a period of settling. The liquid from the secondary process passes 
into large tanks. Here microbes and any remaining organic material settle out to form sludge. 
This sludge may be put back into the secondary stage to increase the population of 
microorganisms or it may go to an anaerobic stage in which bacteria break down waste matter to 
methane in anaerobic conditions. The methane is burned as a fuel in the sewage works to 
provide energy for operating the machinery. Sludge may also be dumped at sea or spread on the 
land as a soil conditioner 
â€¢ The water leaving the plant will be treated in a variety of ways to make it safe 
Recycling waste 
â€¢ Unless waste is handled and disposed of properly it may be hazardous 
â€¢ The solution is to recycle useful materials 
Endangered species 
â€¢ A species becomes extinct if there are no individuals left alive anywhere in the world 
â€¢ Some species are kept alive only in captivity and they are described as extinct in the world  

â€¢ When the numbers of a species decrease to such a level that it is at risk of becoming extinct the 
species is described as endangered 
â€¢ The reasons for species become endangered and extinct are: 
o Habitat destruction  
o Climate change  
o Pollution  
o Overfishing  
o Hunting for food and sport 
o Competition with species that humans have moved from one part of the world to another  
o Predation by introduced or alien species 
Threats to the survival of species 
â€¢ Climate change is occurring as a result of changes to the composition of the atmosphere 
â€¢ The world is growing warmer, plants and animals associated with tropical regions are extending 
their ranges away from the equator  
â€¢ Plants better able to survive in changing environments will outcompete other species 
â€¢ Deforestation is not the only cause of habitat loss 
â€¢ Wetlands are very important as they provide ecological services for us and also are feeding 
grounds for migrating birds 
â€¢ Many wetlands across the world have been drained to provide land for farming, housing, 
industrial and leisure activities 
â€¢  Pollution is occurring on a global scale  
â€¢ Introduced species have been moved around the globe by humans 
â€¢ Sometimes we have done this deliberately by introducing animals for sport or to control pests 
â€¢ Hunting has caused the extinction of some species 
â€¢ They have been hunted for food, sport, trade and as a deliberate policy to remove dangerous 
animals and pests 
â€¢ Animals have been trapped and shot for their fur in the days before man-made material became 
available 
â€¢ In some places animals are shot as a deliberate policy to protect farmland 
â€¢ There is very little genetic variation in small population 
â€¢ This makes rare and endangered species at particular risk of becoming extinct 
â€¢ With few individuals alive, many of the alleles of the genes in that species are no longer left 
â€¢ This reduces the chances of the population evolving in response to changes in the environment 
Conservation 
â€¢ Endangered species have to be conserved 
â€¢  Monitoring can involve labelling, radio tagging and counting flocks of bird and herds of animals  
â€¢ No species lives in isolation so we have a duty to conserve ecosystems and habitats. Here are 
some ways in which this is done: 
o National Park-s large tracts of land set aside for wildlife but which may be occupied by 
people who are patrolled by wardens 
o Marine parks to protect areas of the sea from damage by fishing and pollution  
o Growing endangered plants in botanical gardens and re-establishing them in the wild 
o Reducing habitat destruction 
o Re-establishment of ecosystems that have been degraded  

o Preventing the trade of endangered species 
o  Encouraging sustainable management of ecosystems. Trees removed from forests 
should be replaced by planting or allowing time for natural replacement of seeds 
o Seed banks are cold stores that conserve seeds of endangered or valuable species. Their 
genes may be useful for crop improvement in the future or to produce valuable products 
such as medicinal products. Seeds are collected from plants in the wild and are put into 
long term storage 
o Increasing peopleâ€™s knowledge and understanding of the way in which their actions affect 
wildlife will help to ensure the success of conservation programmers 
Reasons for conservation 
â€¢ Ecosystems provide us with services such as treating waste, providing food and fuels and giving 
us areas for recreation. They provide us with useful substances such as medicine 
â€¢ Ecosystems help to maintain the balance of life on the planet (nutrient cycle) 
â€¢ Habitats support a wide variety of organisms that interact in ways we do not fully understand, 
often to continue life on this planet  
â€¢ There are few foods, apart from some fish species that we can take directly from the wild in large 
quantities. There may be many more plants and animals that we could utilize as food sources 
â€¢ Fuels- fossil fuels cannot last forever. We still need timber to provide fuels such as biomass 
fuels 
â€¢ Drugs- drugs for treating cancer have been discovered in plants  
â€¢ Genes- as a result of selective breeding there is very little genetic diversity in our three main 
staples. It is important to conserve any locally adapted varieties that exist as well as any wild 
relatives that have genes we could use in the future. These plants can be kept in botanic gardens 
and their seeds in seed banks  
â€¢ Prevent species becoming extinct, especially those threatened directly by human activities

Intensive farming involves growing crop plants over large areas at high densities and keeping livestock in large numbers . The large scale use of chemical fertilizers can reduce the structure of the soil . The addition of organic mature, such as manure helps to maintain a good soil structure .  Major pollutants of the sea include fertilizers, oil from oil wells and ships and industrial chemicals . Pollution is the harm done to the environment by the release of substances produced by human . Plastics are used for packaging packaging because they last a long time and do not decay easily .  The rivers may flow into a lake oo Once in the water, this stimulates population growth of algae . Once in water, the algae stimulates the growth of the algae in the rivers .  The Greenhouse Effect is a natural process which is essential to maintain suitable temperatures on earth . Some of the gases in the atmosphere act like a greenhouse to keep in heat to keep heat . Human activities are causing an increase in the concentration of greenhouse gases . There is a fear that this is increasing the enhanced greenhouse effect .  Sulfur dioxide is released when fossil fuels are burned and together with nitrogen oxides from exhaust fumes, they cause acid rain . Unit 3 Movement in and out of cells 
Diffusion 
â€¢ Diffusion is the net movement of particles or ions of a high concentration to a low concentration 
down a concentration gradient  
â€¢ Particles in a liquid or gas spread out from regions of high concentration to areas of  a low 
concentration until evenly spread 
â€¢ The difference between the concentration of molecules is called a concentration gradient 
â€¢ The steeper the concentration gradient, the faster the diffuser takes place 
â€¢ The movement of molecules by diffusion across the cell membrane is a passive movement as 
cells do not need to use energy to move the molecules 
Factors that affect diffusion 
â€¢ The distance the molecules have to travel- cell membranes are very thin 
â€¢ The concentration gradient- cells maintain a steep concentration gradient 
â€¢ The surface area- the larger the surface area, the more diffusion takes place 
â€¢ The temperature- molecules move faster and collide more often as the temperature increases, 
diffusion is faster at warmer temperatures 
â€¢ The size of the cell- as the cell gets bigger, its surface-to-volume ratio decreases, making 
diffusion less efficient 
Gases vs Liquids 
â€¢ Diffusion through air is 300 000 times faster than through water 
â€¢ In mammals the gas exchange surface is formed of the alveoli in the lungs 
â€¢ There are many alveoli to give a very large area of gas exchange 
â€¢ In plants, gas exchange occurs inside the leaves 
â€¢ The spongy mesophyll cells provide a large surface area for the exchange of gases 
â€¢ There are air spaces between the cells  
Water as a solvent 
â€¢ Solute + Solvent = Solution 
â€¢ Solute: what dissolves in the solvent 
â€¢ Solvent: the liquid in which the solvent dissolves 
â€¢ Water is known as a universal solvent 
â€¢ 75% of cytoplasm is water 
â€¢ Water is needed for transportation in plants and animals 
â€¢ Water is needed for digestion and excretion 
â€¢ Most chemical reactions occur in water 
Osmosis 
â€¢ Osmosis is a special type of diffusion. It is the diffusion of free water molecules from a high 
concentration of free water molecules to a low concentration through a partially permeable 
membrane 
 

Water Potential 
â€¢ The ability of water to move via osmosis 
â€¢ Water potential is caused by the amount of free water molecules available to move. So water 
molecules will always move from a high to a low water potential 
â€¢ A  dilute solution has a high water potential 
â€¢ A concentrated solution has a low water potential 
â€¢ Water potential is influenced by the amount of water available and the pressure exerted on water 
in plant cells by the cell wall 
â€¢ Osmosis is measured using an osmometer  
Osmosis in plant and animal cells 
Turgidity 
â€¢ Vacuoles store sugars and salts in a solution which creates a concentration gradient 
â€¢ Plant cells have partially permeable membranes, allowing water to diffuse into the cell 
â€¢ As the water diffuses into the cell, the cell swells up 
â€¢ Water pushes against the cell wall creating turgor pressure 
â€¢ A cell full to the point of bursting is known as turgid 
â€¢ Plant cells will not burst due to a cell wall 
â€¢ Many cells in the stem of the plant are supported by turgor pressure 
â€¢ Wilted plants lose turgidity due to water shortage 
Plasmolysis 
â€¢ Placing a cell in a concentrated salt/sugar solution results in: 
i. 
Water moving out via osmosis, vacuole shrinks and becomes limp 
ii. 
Said to become flaccid 
iii. 
If more water leaves the cell it will become plasmolysed, cytoplasm begins to move away 
from the cell wall 
â€¢ Only plant cells can become plasmolysed  
Active Transport 
â€¢ Active transport is the movement of ions and molecules in or out of a cell through the cell 
membrane against a concentration gradient, using energy released during the respiration 
â€¢ Active transport moves substances against as concentration gradient 
â€¢ Movement involves the use of ATP from aerobic respiration to supply energy 
â€¢ Structural changes in the carrier protein result in the movement through the membrane 
â€¢ Active transport enables root hair cells to take up ions and epithelial cells of the villi to take up 
glucose 
â€¢ Root hair cells and epithelial cells of villi have adapted for active transport by having many 
carrier proteins in their cell membranes and a high rate of respiration to provide energy 
â€¢ Active transport relies upon respiration to take up ions or molecules against a concentration 
gradient. Any factor that affects the rate of respiration will also affect the rate of active 
transport. So a lack of oxygen will reduce respiration rate and active transport. 
â€¢ An increase in temperature would increase the rate of respiration, up to a point, so would also 
have the same effects on active transport. The presence of poisons such as cyanide can stop, so 
active transport would stop altogether.
summary_text: Diffusion is the net movement of particles or ions of a high concentration to a low concentration . The movement of molecules by diffusion across the cell membrane is a passive movement as cells do not need to use energy to move molecules . Diffusion through air is 300 000 times faster than through water .  Only plant cells can become plasmolysed, cytoplasm begins to move away from the cell wall . Active transport is the movement of ions and molecules in or out of a cell through the cell membrane against a concentration gradient .

molecule is made up of thousands of units each called a nucleotide. A single nucleotide is made up of 3 molecule: a 
phosphate, a sugar and a base 
â€¢ Sugar and phosphate molecules join together to form the backbone of the DNA strand, the base is attached to the 
sugar molecule 
â€¢ DNA consists of two strands together to form a double helix 
â€¢ Each strand contains chemical called Adenine, Cytosine, Guanine, and Thymine 
â€¢ Adenine always bonds with Thymine

Unit 5 Enzymes 
â€¢ A catalyst speeds up a chemical reaction and remains unchanged at the end of the reaction 
How enzymes work 
â€¢ Enzymes are biological catalysts, they speed up chemical reactions and remain unchanged at 
the end of the reactions. 
 
The reactions that enzymes catalyze can be divided into 3 groups: 
 
i. 
Breaking large molecules into small ones- This is important in nutrition when large food 
molecules are broken down into small ones so that they can be absorbed and used 
ii. 
Building up large molecules from smaller ones- Small molecules, such as glucose are 
joined together to make large molecules. These enzymes work inside cells to speed up the 
formation of storage molecules, such as starch, and structural molecules such as 
cellulose for cell walls of plants 
iii. 
Converting one small molecules into another- Many of the chemical reactions that occur 
inside cells involve small changes to molecules, such as adding or removing atoms of 
groups of atoms. 
 
 
 

All enzymes: 
â€¢ They are all proteins 
â€¢ Each enzyme only catalyzes one reaction 
â€¢ They can be used again and again 
â€¢ They are influenced by temperature  
â€¢ They are influenced by pH 
 
â€¢ Enzymes catalyze reactions in which substrates are converted into products. The enzyme and 
the substrate have shapes that are complimentary so that they fit together. Once they fit together 
the reaction van take place. When the reaction is over, the product, or products leave the enzyme 
and another substrate molecule enters 
 
â€¢ The part of the enzyme where the substrate fit and where the reaction takes place is the active 
site. The way of describing how enzymes work is known as the lock and key model. The enzyme 
and substrate combine like a key entering a lock to form an enzyme-substrate complex. 
 
Factors that affect enzyme action 
Temperature 
â€¢ The temperature at which the maximum rat of reaction occurs is called the optimum temperature. 
This is the best temperature for the enzyme. 
â€¢ Increasing the temperature of an enzyme controlled reaction increases the rate of reaction up to 
a maximum, which occurs at the optimum temperature. This is because the greater kinetic energy 
is causing a greater number of collisions between enzyme and substrate molecules. 
â€¢ At higher temperatures the rate of reaction decreases until it stops acting as a catalyst. This is 
due to a change in the active site which means the substrate can no longer fit. The enzyme is now 
denatured 
pH 
â€¢ Most enzymes work best at one value of pH 
â€¢ At either side of their optimum pH value, enzyme activity decreases 
â€¢ At some values of pH the shape of the active site changes so that substrate molecules no longer 
fit.
summary_text: Enzymes are biological catalysts, they speed up chemical reactions and remain unchanged at the end of the reactions . The reactions that enzymes catalyze can be divided into 3 groups: Break large molecules into small ones, building up large molecules from smaller ones . Temperature at which the maximum rat of reaction occurs is called the optimum temperature for the enzyme .

Unit 6: Plant Nutrition 
The process of photosynthesis 
â€¢ Green plants use light energy to convert carbon dioxide and water from their surroundings into 
simple sugars. This process is called photosynthesis. Photosynthesis is the process by which 
plants make carbohydrates from raw materials using sunlight energy. 
 
 
â€¢ If too much sugar is dissolved in the cell sap of plant cell it would make a very concentrated 
solution. This would make water mice in from other cells by osmosis and cause the cells to swell 
up. To prevent this, glucose molecules are linked together to form larger starch molecules which 
are insoluble and have no effect on osmosis. 
Testing a leaf for starch 
â€¢ Submerge a leaf in boiling water for one minute in order to destroy the cell membranes and make 
it easier to extract the chlorophyll 
â€¢ Put the leaf extract into a test tube of ethanol in a hot water bath for 10 minutes, the chlorophyll 
is extracted by dissolving into the ethanol. 
â€¢ Wash the leaf with cold water and spread it out on a white surface 
â€¢ Add a few drops of iodine solution 
â€¢ For a positive result the iodine solution will turn from the yellow-brown color to a blue-black 
color on the surface of the leaf.  
Requirements for photosynthesis  
â€¢ Light 
â€¢ Chlorophyll 
â€¢ Carbon dioxide 
â€¢ Water  
De-starching a plant 
â€¢ The plant is left in the dark for 48 hours in order to de-starch it. The plant is then given all the 
things that it needs except for the substance we are testing. 
 

Showing that chlorophyll is needed for photosynthesis 
â€¢ Take a de-starched variegated plant 
â€¢ Place the plant in the sun for 6 hours 
â€¢ Test the leaf for starch 
â€¢ Only the green parts of the leaf go blue-black  
â€¢ The green plants contain chlorophyll which is needed for photosynthesis to make starch 
â€¢ The white parts contain no chlorophyll, so no photosynthesis occurs there 
â€¢ Safety: wear eye protection. 
Showing that carbon dioxide and light are needed for photosynthesis 
â€¢ Take a de-starched leaf and enclose it in a plastic bag with a chemical that absorbs carbon 
dioxide (Soda Lime) 
â€¢ Leave the plant in the light for a few hours 
â€¢ Test the leaf for starch  
â€¢ The leaf should show a negative result for the starch test. Deprived of carbon dioxide the leaf is 
unable to photosynthesize. 
â€¢ A control experiment should be set up exactly in the same way without the soda lime. This means 
the plant in the control experiment does not have the carbon dioxide removed. Then we can be 
sure that it was the absence of carbon dioxide that caused the lack of starch and not keeping the 
plant inside a plastic bag.  
Showing that light is needed for photosynthesis  
â€¢ Take a de-starched plant. Cover part if the leaf with some aluminum foil to prevent light from 
getting through  
â€¢ Leave the plant in the light for a few hours 
â€¢ Test the leaf for starch 
â€¢ Only the uncovered parts of the test will go blue black. The parts of the leaf that were covered did 
not receive light and could not carry out photosynthesis and so could not make starch. 
 
Products of Photosynthesis

changed to starch

â€¢ Oxygen is a by-product of photosynthesis. Some used for respiration in the plant but most 
diffuses out of the leaf through the stomata 
â€¢ Plant products 
1. Food for humans and livestock 
2. Raw materials for industry 
3. Provides medicines 
4. Provides habitats for animals and microorganisms  
5. Keeps the concentration of gases in the air constant (lowers the amount of carbon dioxide 
and increases the amount of oxygen) 
 
Glasshouse Production 
Conditions inside a glasshouse allow plants to: 
â€¢ Grow earlier in the year 
â€¢ Grow in places they would not usually grow  
The following conditions inside a glasshouse are controlled: 
Temperature  
â€¢ Sunlight heats up the inside of the glasshouse 
â€¢ The glass stops a lot of this heat from escaping  
â€¢ Electric heaters  are used in cold weather 
â€¢ Ventilator flaps are opened to cool the glasshouse on hot days  
Light 
â€¢ The glass lets in sunlight 
â€¢ Artificial light can be used to grow plants when light intensity gets too low 
â€¢ Blinds keep out very strong light and shading lowers the temperature in tropical countries 
Carbon dioxide 
â€¢ Growers can pump carbon dioxide into glasshouses to increase the carbon dioxide 
concentration 
â€¢ They can also burn butane or natural gas which provides carbon dioxide and also heat to raise 
the temperature of glasshouses during cold water 
Water  
â€¢ Automatic sprinklers and humidifiers to ensure that plants always get enough water  
 
â€¢ All these factors are controlled by computers so few staff are needed. Sensors are used to detect 
changes in the limiting factors. Computers process the data transmitted from the sensors and 
control the heating, ventilation, lighting and shading in the glasshouse.  
 
 

Leaves  
Leaves have: 
â€¢ A large surface area to absorb light rays 
â€¢ A thin shape to allow efficient diffusion 
â€¢ Many chloroplasts to absorb light for the reactions that take place in photosynthesis 
â€¢ Veins to support the plant, carry water and ions to the leaf cells, take sucrose and amino acids 
away from the leaf and to other parts of the plant 
 
 
Adaptations of leaves for photosynthesis 
â€¢ Palisade mesophyll cells are packed tightly together and near the surface of the leaf to maximize 
the absorption of light where the intensity is the highest 
â€¢ There are many chloroplasts in the palisade mesophyll cells to absorb as much light as possible 
â€¢ Stomata open to allow carbon dioxide to diffuse into the leaf. Carbon dioxide is a raw material 
for photosynthesis 
â€¢ Leaves are thin so that the carbon dioxide does not have to diffuse far from the atmosphere to 
the cells of the palisade and spongy mesophyll 
â€¢ There are large intercellular air spaces within the spongy mesophyll layer. This makes it easy 
for carbon dioxide to diffuse to all the mesophyll cells. Diffusion through air is much faster than 
diffusion from cell to cell. 

â€¢ Xylem veins bring water and ions to the mesophyll cells. Water is a raw material of 
photosynthesis and magnesium ions are needed by the cells to make chlorophyll 
â€¢ The sugar produced in photosynthesis is converted to sucrose and transported away from the 
leaves in the phloem and veins  
Stomata  
 
â€¢ Stomata are opened and closed by guard cells 
â€¢ Stomata are usually open during the day water passes into the guard cells via osmosis 
â€¢ Carbon dioxide diffuses inti the leaf, and oxygen and photosynthesis diffuses out 
â€¢ At night the stomata close, water passes out of the guard cells by osmosis and they straighten 
and move closer together to close the pores 
â€¢ The stomata also close in hot, dry weather to prevent the plant from wilting 
â€¢ Stomata are usually in the lower epidermis, but some plants like water lilies have them on their 
upper epidermis.  
 
Plant Nutrients 
â€¢ Needed for healthy growth 
â€¢ Deficiency symptoms as a result of nutrient shortage 
â€¢ Nitrate (nitrogen) - needed for the making of amino acids, to make proteins for growth. A 
deficiency in nitrates result in poor growth 
â€¢ Magnesium is needed to make chlorophyll.  A deficiency in magnesium results in the plant 
turning yellow (chlorosis) 
â€¢ Phosphates are needed to make DNA and for respiration  
â€¢ Fertilizers may be used as supplements to growth 
Gas exchange  
â€¢ Respiration is a property of all living things 
â€¢ Night: plants exchange gases with surroundings and respire  
â€¢ Day: carry out photosynthesis and respiration 
â€¢ Bright light allows a higher rate of photosynthesis, and more oxygen is produced 
â€¢ Oxygen is used for respiration in mitochondria and the rest diffuses out of the plant 
â€¢ Carbon dioxide made by respiration is used for photosynthesis and more diffuses into the plant 
to make up for the shortage  
 
 

Aquatic Plants 
â€¢ Investigate gas exchange using sodium hydrogen carbonate indicator solution 
1. Provides carbon dioxide to the solution 
2. Acts as a pH indicator and provides carbon dioxide 
3. Carbon dioxide dissolves in water to form carbonic acid 
â€¢ Sodium hydrogen carbonate indicator solution is red 
1. Turns yellow in acidic conditions 
2. Turns purple in the absence of carbon dioxide
summary_text: Green plants use light energy to convert carbon dioxide and water from their surroundings into sugars . This process is called photosynthesis . Photosynthesis is the process by which plants make carbohydrates from raw materials using sunlight energy .  Conditions inside a glasshouse allow plants to grow earlier in the year . Growers pump carbon dioxide into glasshouses to increase the carbon dioxide concentration of gases in the air . Glasshouses are controlled by computers so few staff are needed .  A deficiency in magnesium results in the plant turning yellow (chlorosis) The plant needs phosphorus to make DNA and for respiration . Fertilizers may be used as supplements to growth .

Animal Nutrition 
A balanced diet 
â€¢ A balanced diet provides an adequate intake of biological molecules and energy needed to 
sustain the body and ensure good health and growth 
A balanced diet consists of: 
Carbohydrates, proteins, fats, vitamins, minerals, water and fibre. 
Each of these carries out one or more of three basic functions: 
â€¢ To provide energy- this is mainly the role of carbohydrates and fats. Proteins are used for 
energy only if they are in excess of requirements for growth, development, repair and 
replacement 
â€¢ To allow growth and repair of body cells and tissues. Proteins in the diet provide a source of 
amino acids for cells to make their own proteins 
â€¢ To regulate the bodyâ€™s metabolism 
The energy required for body functions in known as the basal metabolic rate (BMR), which varies 
from person to person. (Adults require approx. 7000kJ/day.) 
Diet depends on age, sex and activity levels 
â€¢ Children have a greater energy requirement than adults because they have a higher BMR, 
because they are more active and are still developing 
â€¢ Elderly have a lower BMR, they have a lower energy and protein need. However, they still 
need to eat a healthy diet to remain healthy. 
â€¢ Women have a higher fat content than men, fat tissues has a lower BMR than muscle, so 
women generally have a lower energy requirement as compared to men. 
â€¢ The energy needs of occupation that involve physical activity are greater than less active 
jobs. 
â€¢ Women need extra nutrients when they are pregnant and when they are breastfeeding. 
Why is fat bad for us? 
â€¢ Fat is a more efficient store of energy than carbs 
Two main types of fat: 
1. Saturated fat comes from animals 
2. Unsaturated fat that comes from fish and plants 
 
â€¢ Saturated fat in the diet leads to an increase in cholesterol. High fat diets tend to increase the 
risk of producing more cholesterol and having a high concentration in the blood. 
â€¢ High concentrations of cholesterol leads to the narrowing of arteries and risk of developing 
high blood pressure and heart disease. 
Two types of unsaturated fat: 
1. Monounsaturated fats have little effect on blood cholesterol 
2. Polyunsaturated fats reduce cholesterol concentration which reduces heart disease 
 
 

Sources of nutrients 
Food group  
Good Sources  
Role in body 
Carbohydrates 
(sugars and starches) 
Rice, potatoes, bread, 
yams, sugar and honey  
â€¢ Simple sugar = immediate source of 
energy. Energy as a result of respiration 
Proteins 
Meat, fish, milk and 
nuts 
â€¢ Develops new cells i.e. growth and repair 
â€¢ Can be respired producing energy  
Fats 
Butter, cheese, fat in 
meat, fat in fish and 
nuts 
â€¢ Long term store of energy  
â€¢ Produce twice as much energy as protein 
and carbohydrates 
â€¢ Thermal insulators  
â€¢ Buoyancy to marine animals 
Water 
 
â€¢ The body cannot survive without water 
â€¢ Needed for chemical reactions to take 
place 
â€¢ Blood transports minerals dissolved in 
water 
â€¢ Waste materials is passed out in solution 
(Urine and Sweat) 
â€¢ Water in sweat cools us down 
â€¢ Makes up majority of blood volume 
Fibre 
Bran-cereals, 
sweetcorn, celery and 
cabbage 
â€¢ Made from cellulose form plant cell walls 
â€¢ Adds bulk to our food 
â€¢ Helps food pass down the gullet 
â€¢ Prevents constipation 
â€¢ Absorbs poisonous bacteria  
â€¢ Lowers cholesterol  
â€¢ Reduces risk of heart disease and bowel 
cancer 
 
 
Vitamins and minerals 
Name  
Rich food source 
Use in Body 
Deficiency symptoms (diseases) 
Vitamin C 
Oranges, lemons, 
citrus fruit 
Tissue repair; resistance to 
disease  
Bleeding gums (scurvy) 
Vitamin D 
Fish oil, milk, 
butter, sun 
Strengthens bones and teeth 
Soft bones, legs bow outwards 
(rickets) 
Iron 
Liver, meat, 
cocoa, eggs 
Formation of haemoglobin in 
red blood cells for transport 
of oxygen 
Tiredness, lack of energy 
(anaemia) 
Calcium 
Milk, fish, green 
vegetables 
Strengthens bones and teeth 
Weak, brittle bones and teeth 
(rickets), muscles weakness and 
cramps  
 
 

Balancing energy needs 
â€¢ When eating too much, your energy intake is greater than your energy output which leads to 
an increase in fat and body mass 
â€¢ To be obese, means to be severely overweight 
â€¢ Obesity is caused by: 
i. 
High intake of fatty and refined foods containing a lot of added sugar 
ii. 
Too little exercise 
iii. 
Social and emotional stress, â€˜comfort eatingâ€™ 
â€¢ Health problems associated with being overweight: 
i. 
Heart disease  
ii. 
High blood pressure 
iii. 
Type 2 Diabetes 
iv. 
Arthritis  
Identification of obesity 
â€¢ Being above 20% of recommended weight for his or her height 
â€¢ Having a BMI greater than 30

â„ğ‘’ğ‘–ğ‘”â„ğ‘¡/ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘ 2 
BMI 
Classification 
Less than 20 
Underweight 
Between 20-24 
Normal 
25-30 
Overweight 
More than 30 
Obese 
More than 40 
Severely obese  
Constipation 
â€¢ Constipation is caused by the lack of fibre or roughage in the diet. Fibre helps with the 
movement of down the alimentary canal 
â€¢ Soft foods do not instigate peristalsis as much as harder indigestible food 
â€¢ If the movement of food is slow, it will result in constipation and difficulty to defecate  
â€¢ Fruit and vegetables relieve constipation  
Weight Loss 
â€¢ Eat less high energy foods (lower energy intake) 
â€¢ Do more exercise (increase energy output) 
â€¢ Combine balanced diet with lower energy intake 
â€¢ Gradually increase exercise 
â€¢ Have an ideal but achievable weight loss goal 
â€¢ Have a positive self-image, be realistic 
â€¢ Do not attempt a diet which eliminates a food group  
Starvation and nutrient deficiency 
â€¢ Starvation results in a very low body mass with lack of fat and muscle wasting, and a lack of 
resistance to infections 

â€¢ In terms of an inadequate diet, starvation is caused by the drawing up upon stores of 
carbohydrates, fat and proteins for energy, however, water is not stored. The BMR is 
reduced, and the body begins to break down proteins in muscles as a source of energy  
â€¢ During starvation there are deficiencies of protective vitamins; people are at risk of 
developing infectious diseases 
â€¢ Malnourishment is caused by: contaminated water, poverty, malaria, social unrest/war, poor 
harvest/drought 
â€¢ The most common form of undernutrition is protein energy malnutrition (PEM) 
Nutritional Marasmus 
â€¢ Protein deficiency  
â€¢ Severe wasting, extreme thinness 
â€¢ Skin on upper arms, legs and buttocks may appear baggy 
â€¢ Sufferer may be too weak to walk or sit 
â€¢ Stomach muscles may stick out because muscles are weak and there may be gas in the 
upper gut caused by parasites or infection 
â€¢ Heart and other organs will be extremely weak  
Kwashiorkor  
â€¢ Protein deficiency  
â€¢ Occurs between ages 1 and 3 years 
â€¢ Growth failure, low weight, oedema (swelling) feet, legs, face and hands 
â€¢ Wasted muscles 
â€¢ Misery and apathy 
â€¢ Hair turns orangeish, straightens out and pulls out easily 
â€¢ Skin becomes lighter on the face 
â€¢ Stools are loose 
â€¢ Anaemia  
â€¢ Flaky skin, which may lead to ulcers and gangrene 
 
The above may be brought upon by living conditions and being displaced by the breast by the next 
child and given a low protein porridge diet (cassava and plantain). Can be brought on by infection 
(HIV, malaria, cholera, diarrhoea) 
With both marasmus and kwashiorkor increasing food intake should be manages carefully to 
prevent too much strain on the body  
Vitamin C deficiency  
â€¢ Scurvy (Bleeding Gums) 
â€¢ Vitamin C helps bond together cells and helps the use of calcium by the bones and teeth. 
Vitamin C is used to make skin, tendons, ligaments and blood vessels. It also helps with 
healing of wounds and the formation of scar tissues 
â€¢ Lack of Vitamin C leads to areas of bruising and swelling of bone joints  
Vitamin D 
â€¢ Needed for the absorption of calcium, and regulation of deposition of calcium in bone cells 
â€¢ Deficiency causes rickets  

â€¢ Bones fail to grow properly and become soft, so when children start walking the bones bend 
with the weight of the body 
â€¢ In adults, deficiency gives rises to the condition known as osteomalacia which leads to the 
softening of the bones and increased chances of fractures 
Iron 
â€¢ A lack of iron causes anaemia  
â€¢ An adult needs about 16mg of iron a day 
â€¢ Women need enough iron in their diet to facilitate their menstruation cycle  
â€¢ Tiredness, lack of energy, shortness of breath, heart palpitations and a pale complexion  
Digestion  
â€¢ Ingestion is the taking of substances through the mouth 
â€¢ Digestion is the breaking down of large insoluble food molecules into small soluble 
molecules so that they can pass through the gut wall into the blood 
â€¢ Absorption is the movement of small food molecules and ions through the wall of the 
intestine into the blood 
â€¢ Assimilation is the movement of digestive food molecules into the cells of the body where 
they are used, becoming part of the cells 
â€¢ Egestion is the passing out of food that has not been digested or absorbed as faces through 
the anus 
Mechanical Digestion 
â€¢ Breakdown of large pieces of food into smaller pieces of food without changing the 
molecules 
â€¢ Creates a larger surface area for enzymes to work on 
â€¢ Continues in the stomach-muscular contractions (peristalsis) 
â€¢ Small intestine: large globules of fat are broken down into smaller ones (emulsification by 
bile) 
Chemical Digestion 
â€¢ Breakdown of large insoluble food molecules into smaller soluble molecules by the action of 
enzymes 
â€¢ Makes these molecules soluble i.e. it can be absorbed through wall of small intestine into 
bloodstream/lymph (fat) 
â€¢ Occurs in mouth, stomach and small intestine  
Protease: protein molecule â†’ amino acids 
Carbohydrase: starch molecule â†’ glucose 
Lipase: fat molecule â†’ fatty acids (3) and glycerol (1) 
 
 
 
 
 

Teeth 
â€¢ The teeth carry out mechanical digestion and break down food into smaller pieces 
â€¢ The teeth increase the surface area of food to aid the enzymes catalyse reactions 
â€¢ Adult humans have 32 teeth 
Tooth 
Shape 
Function 
Incisors (8) 
Chisel- shaped 
Biting and cutting 
Canines (4) 
Pointed  
Piercing and tearing  
Premolars(8) 
Uneven cusps 
Grinding and chewing 
Molars (12) 
Similar to premolars 
Chewing 
 
â€¢ During our lives we have two sets of teeth  
â€¢ The first set, milk teeth only have 8 molars 
â€¢ Between the ages of 6-12 these teeth gradually fall out and are replaced by permanent teeth 
â€¢ The last of the permanent teeth come through at 18, called back molars or wisdom teeth 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
â€¢ Enamel forms the hard, outer layer of the crown od the tooth, above the gum 
â€¢ Inside this is softer dentine which is like a bone in structure 
â€¢ A layer of cement fixes the root of the gum into a bony socket in the jaw 
â€¢ The root is the part that is below the gum 
â€¢ The pulp cavity is a space in the tooth containing several nerves and blood vessels 
Healthy teeth and gums 
â€¢ Tooth decay is caused by bacteria in the mouth, they mix with saliva to make plaque 
â€¢ Bacteria in plaque changes sugar into acid via anaerobic respiration  
â€¢ The acid can attack the enamel and propel tooth decay 
â€¢ The acid will then attack dentine and subsequently the pulp cavity and will cause severe tooth 
ache 
â€¢ The acid will make gums red and swollen 
â€¢ Brushing teeth at a 45Â° angle clean the outside teeth with short gentle movements  
â€¢ Brush the inside of the teeth by moving the brush gently back and forth  
â€¢ Brush biting surfaces with short scrubbing strokes 
â€¢ Tooth decay can be avoided with a good toothbrush, not eating sugary foods and regular 
dental visits  

Mouth, oesophagus and stomach 
Chewing and swallowing 
â€¢ 
The incisors and canine teeth bite the food into chunks 
â€¢ 
The molar and premolar teeth grind the food into smaller 
pieces 
â€¢ 
The tongue mixed the food with saliva and the moistened 
food is chewed 
â€¢ 
The food is then rolled into a ball or bolus 
â€¢ 
The salivary glands make saliva which contains: 
i. 
Mucus; a slimy substance that lubricate the passage of the 
food bolus down the throat 
ii. 
Amylase; the enzyme that catalyses the breakdown of 
starch to maltose 
â€¢ 
The food pushes your soft palette upwards preventing 
food from going into your nose 
â€¢ 
When you swallow, the epiglottis covers the opening to 
your trachea 
â€¢ 
The food squeezes past your epiglottis and into your 
oesophagus  
The oesophagus/gullet 
â€¢ Food passes down the oesophagus into the stomach 
â€¢ Has longitudinal muscles in its wall 
â€¢ The movement of food down the oesophagus is due to the contraction of muscles called 
peristalsis  
â€¢ The circular muscles relax and the longitudinal muscles contract to widen the oesophagus to 
move the food along 
â€¢ Peristalsis also occurs in the large intestine  
The Stomach 
â€¢ Muscular bag that can hold 1 or more litres of food 
â€¢ The walls of the stomach make gastric juice 
â€¢ This contains pepsin that digests proteins to smaller molecules called polypeptides 
â€¢ Gastric juice also contains hydrochloric acid which carries out two important function due to 
its low pH: 
1. It kills bacteria in food and the low pH denatures the enzymes in harmful 
microorganisms  
2. The acid provides the optimum conditions for the enzyme pepsin 
â€¢ The mixture, of food, gastric juice and hydrochloric acid is known as chyme 
â€¢ The muscular walls of the stomach churn up the food making sure it mixes well with the juices 
â€¢ After 2-3 hours of churning, the contents of the stomach are like a runny liquid 
â€¢ A ring of muscle called the pyloric sphincter opens to let the food pass a little at a time into 
the first part of the small intestine, the duodenum  
 
 
 

The small intestine and absorption  
â€¢ The small intestine is 6m long 
â€¢ The first part is the duodenum that leads to the ileum 
 
â€¢ The pancreas is connected to the duodenum by the pancreatic duct 
â€¢ Pancreatic juice flows down the duct to meet food arriving from the stomach. Pancreatic juice 
contains: 
i. 
Amylase â†’ breaks down starch to maltose 
ii. 
Trypsinâ†’ a protease that breaks down proteins and polypeptides to peptides 
iii. 
Lipase â†’ breaks down fats to fatty acids and glycerol 
â€¢ The enzymes do not all work well under acid conditions so the pancreas created an alkali 
(sodium hydrogen carbonate) that neutralises the acidic food which enter the duodenum from 
the stomach 
  
â€¢ Bile enters the duodenum through the bile duct 
â€¢ Bile is a yellow-green fluid made in the liver and stored in the gall bladder 
â€¢ Bile is alkaline and neutralises the acid which is added to food in the stomach  
â€¢ Bile emulsifies fat by breaking down large globules of fat into smaller globules  
 
â€¢ Cells lining the ileum make enzymes that complete the digestion of food: 
i. 
Proteases that break down peptides to amino acids 
ii. 
Sucrase that breaks down sucrose to glucose and fructose 
iii. 
Maltose is broken down by maltase to glucose on the membrane of the epithelium 
lining the small intestine  
Absorption 
â€¢ Absorption is the movement of digested food molecules through the wall of the intestine into 
the blood or lymph  
â€¢ Digested food includes simple sugars, amino acids, fatty acids and glucose  
â€¢ These molecules pass through the walls of the intestine either by diffusion or by active 
transport 
â€¢ The small intestine has adapted to I t function of absorption by: 
i. 
Having a large surface area (9ğ‘ğ‘š2) 
ii. 
A thin lining (one cell thick) so digested food can easily pass into the blood and lymph  
â€¢ The small intestine has a folded inner lining with millions of tiny, finger-like projections called 
villi. The epithelial cells lining the villi have microscopic projections called microvilli, these 
vastly increase the absorptive area of the cell membrane of the epithelial cells 
â€¢ The digested food reaches the capillaries and lacteals (lymph capillaries) in the villi 
â€¢ Absorbed food molecules are transported quickly to the liver by the hepatic portal vein 
â€¢ Fatty acids and glycerol are transported by the lymph 
â€¢ Movement of the gut empties the lacteal and lymph moves slowly through the lymphatic 
vessels which are thin walled veins, eventually enter the flood near the heart. As a result, fat 
does not enter the bloodstream quickly.  
 
 
 

Large intestine and intestinal disease 
The large intestine  
â€¢ The large intestine is about 1.5m long and can be divided into the caecum, appendix and 
rectum  
â€¢ By the time the food gets to the colon, it is now mainly fibre, dead cells and some water as 
most has been absorbed by the small intestine 
â€¢ The solid waste, or faeces is stored in the rectum and egested through the anus  
Cholera 
â€¢ Cholera us a disease caused by bacteria  
â€¢ The main symptom is diarrhoea (loss of watery faeces from the intestine) 
â€¢ Some are infected by the disease but may not actually suffer from the disease, this is called 
symptomless carriers  
Transmission 
â€¢ Cholera occurs in areas where there is lack of proper sanitation, an unclean water supply or 
contaminated food  
â€¢ Cholera is transmitted through the ingestion of contaminated water or contaminated food 
which has faecal material 
â€¢ Transmission can occur by infected people handling food or utensils without washing their 
hands 
Effects on the body 
â€¢ Most of the bacteria of cholera is killed by acidic conditions in the stomach, however, some 
pathogens may survive and reach the small intestine. Here they burrow through the mucous 
lining the wall of the intestine and start to produce a toxin 
â€¢ Molecules of this toxin enter the epithelial cells of the intestines here they disrupt the 
functioning of the cell surface membrane of the epithelial cells 
â€¢ Chloride ions pass out the cells into the space inside the intestine 
â€¢ The accumulation of ions in the lumen creates a water potential gradient 
â€¢ Water flows by osmosis from the cells and from the blood into the lumen 
â€¢ Movement of the ions and water from the blood into the lumen of the intestine cause 
symptoms of cholera-dehydration and diarrhoea  
Oral Rehydration Therapy 
â€¢ Cholera is treated by giving people a solutions of slats and glucose to drink. This is oral 
rehydration therapy (ORT) 
â€¢ The ORT solution contains water to rehydrate blood and other tissues, sodium ions to 
replace the ions  lost from blood and tissue fluid, glucose to provide energy for the active 
uptake of sodium ions from the intestine, other ions such as potassium and chloride ions to 
replace those lost in diarrhoea  
â€¢ During a cholera outbreak, sachets containing salts and glucose are made available, the 
contents of these packages dissolve in the boiling water so the administrator requires little 
training to administer-2 
â€¢  the medicine in large volumes at regular intervals 
â€¢ When these ions are absorbed the water potential of the epithelial cells decreases and water 
is absorbed to make up for the water lost in diarrhoea

subject: biology
raw_text:
Plant Transport  
Transport systems  
â€¢ Small organisms donâ€™t need transport systems, they have small, flat bodies so they rely on 
diffusion  
â€¢ Large organisms have transport systems which move fluids through tubes so that all the fluid 
moves in the same direction in each tube. This type of transport is called mass flow 
â€¢ Vertebrates have a circulatory system with a pump 
â€¢ Plants have two separate transport systems: xylem and phloem 
Xylem  
â€¢ Water and minerals travel in xylem vessels 
â€¢ Xylem vessels have thick cellulose cell walls strengthened by lignin. The inside of the walls 
are hollow. Xylem vessels are dead cells 
â€¢ Xylem vessels transport water and minerals from the root to the shoot and leaves. This 
transport only occurs in one direction  
â€¢ Thick walls also help support the plant  
Phloem  
â€¢ Phloem is made of columns of living cells. They transport food in the form of sugars 
â€¢ Sugars are carried from the leaves to the growing and storage parts of the plants. This 
movement takes place in both directions  
â€¢ Phloem cells are also called sieve tubes. Cells are joined by small holes in the cell walls at the 
end of each cell forming a continuous system. The end of the cell walls are called sieve plates. 
 

 
Water uptake by the roots  
â€¢ The main function of the roots is to anchor the plant and take up water and mineral ions 
Explaining how water is taken up by the roots: 
1. Osmosis is the net movement of water molecules through a semi permeable membrane (root 
hair cells) from a high water potential (inside the cells) down a concentration gradient  
2. The water potential gradient in the soil is higher than that in the cell because there are more 
mineral ions in the soil water 
3. The water molecule then moves from cell to cell until it reaches the xylem vessels. Once water 
enters the vacuoles, it increases the water potential of that vacuole, thus creating another 
water potential gradient as the cortex neighbouring cells have a lower water potential. This 
process repeats itself until it reaches the xylem vessels  
4. From here it moves up the plant towards the stem and spongy mesophyll cells in the leaves 
Itâ€™s a push, not a pull 
â€¢ Water needs to flow against gravity. The slight push from water entering from below is not 
enough to overcome gravity 
â€¢ Transpiration is the evaporation of water from the surfaces of the mesophyll cells in the 
leaves which leads to water vapour diffusing out of the stomata and into the atmosphere 
â€¢ Water is pulled up the xylem using transpiration pull 
â€¢ Mass flow of water in the xylem depends on two properties: 
i. 
Cohesion: water molecules sticking together 
ii. 
Adhesion: water molecules sticking to the inside of a vessel 
â€¢ Transpiration stream- a continuous flow of water through the xylem 
â†’ Keeps the plant from wilting 

â†’ Provides water for photosynthesis 
Wilting 
â€¢ Stomata open during the day for the diffusion of carbon dioxide into cells  
â€¢ Close at night to reduce transpiration  
â€¢ If the soil water is scarce, the plant will wily  
â†’ Water lost from cells result in turgidity  
â†’ No support for plant so leaves start to droop 
â†’ Wilting helps move the leaves out of direct sunlight to reduce transpiration  
Factors affecting transpiration  
1. Light 
â€¢ Stomata open when light intensity increases 
â€¢ Increase in transpiration 
2. Humidity  
â€¢ In humid conditions water vapour levels close to that in stomata, slows down diffusion, 
slows down transpiration 
3. Air temperature 
â€¢ High temperature, more kinetic energy in water molecules, faster diffusion from cell to 
atmosphere 
4. Air movement 
â€¢ Humid air taken away by wind which maintains the concentration gradient between the 
leaf and air 
Functions of xylem and phloem  
Xylem  
â€¢ Transports water and mineral ions from roots to stems, leaves, flowers and fruits  
â€¢ Movement is only in one direction  
Phloem  
â€¢ Transports sucrose, amino acids and hormones throughout the plant 
â€¢ Sucrose is a complex sugar used for energy  
â€¢ Made in the leaves using sugars from photosynthesis and starch from storage organs (roots 
and stems) 
â€¢ Hormones control cell division for growth in all parts of the plant  
â€¢ Movement in two directions: leaves to roots and leaves to flowers (upwards and downwards) 
Translocation 
â€¢ Translocation is the movement of organic solutes from a source to a sink through the phloem 
by means of mass flow 
Sucrose

Transport in humans 
Circulation 
The circulatory system 
â€¢ (Most) animals circulatory systems consist of blood, some sort of pump and blood vessels 
â€¢ Circulatory systems in animals transport useful substances such as oxygen and nutrients 
â€¢ Circulatory systems also transport waste such as carbon dioxide 
Blood circulation  
â€¢ The heart is a pump that circulates blood through blood vessels 
â€¢ Blood flows in arteries away from the heart to the different organs of the body 
â€¢ Blood flows back to the heart in veins 
â€¢ The smallest blood vessels that connect arteries to veins are capillaries 
â€¢ The circulatory system allows one way flow of blood around the body 
â€¢ The heart pumps blood giving it pressure so that it flows inside arteries and this helps maintain 
one way flow 
â€¢ This is good for getting blood to capillaries 
â€¢ High pressure blood will damage the delicate capillaries so small muscular blood vessels known 
as arterioles reduce the pressure before blood enters capillaries  
â€¢ When blood leaves the capillaries the blood pressure is even lower 
â€¢ There are semi-lunar valves in veins to make sure that blood does not flow backwards away from 
the heart 
â€¢ If this happens veins swell and blood is not circulated properly  
â€¢ Each valve has three of these pockets 
â€¢ The valves open when the pressure of the blood pushes them, but they close when blood flows 
back to fill these pockets 
â€¢ The semi-lunar valves in the heart are at places where blood leaves the heart chambers to enter 
arteries  
â€¢ There are also valves between the chambers the heart  
Single circulation (e.g. fish) 
â€¢ Blood flows through the heart once during a complete circuit of the body 
â€¢ Blood arriving to the heart via veins is deoxygenated 
â€¢ The heart pups blood to an artery which takes it to the gills to be oxygenated 
â€¢ The blood flows from gills to arteries and to body organs 
Double circulation  
â€¢ Occurs in mammals 
â€¢ Blood flows through the heart twice during one complete circuit around the body 
â€¢ The mammalian heart is divided into two halves: left and right  
â€¢ The septum is a thick wall of muscle that separates the two halves of the heart 
 
 

â€¢ The right side of the heart pumps deoxygenated blood to the lungs and back to the heart again 
â€¢ Pressure requirement is low as there is little resistance to flow in the lungs 
â€¢ Oxygenated blood returns to heart via pulmonary vein 
â€¢ Gas exchange takes place in lungs â€“oxygen enters the blood, carbon dioxide exits 
â€¢ Oxygen blood is bright red in colour 
 
â€¢ The left side of the heart pumps oxygenated blood to the rest of the body and back to the heart 
again 
â€¢ Pressure is greater as there is more resistance to flow 
â€¢ Gas exchange occurs in organs- oxygen leaves the blood, carbon dioxide enters 
â€¢ Deoxygenated blood is dark red in colour

to the body via the aorta

left ventricle to the rest of the body
