backflow of blood into the atria when ventricles 
contract 
â€¢ Pulmonary & aortic valves; prevent 
backflow of blood from the arteries into 
the ventricles 
â€¢ Ventricles have more muscular walls than atria as they have to pump blood further than the atria 
â€¢ The left ventricle has a more muscular wall than the right ventricle as it has to pump blood 
around the body and has to overcome resistance to flow  
 
Heart action 
â€¢ The heart pumps blood when its muscles contract  
â€¢ When muscles contract, the chamber squeezes out blood 
â€¢ After contraction, relaxation occurs, allowing blood to fill again 
â€¢ The two sides of the heart work in sync 
â€¢ The atria contract and relax at the same times 
â€¢ The ventricles contract and relax at the same time  

â€¢ During the relaxation phase, blood flows into the atria from the veins 
â€¢ During contraction: 
i. 
Atria contract and force blood into the ventricles, valves between atria and ventricles 
open due to pressure of blood  
ii. 
The ventricles contract to force blood into the arteries. The valves close to prevent back 
flow 
 
The electrocardiogram (ECG) 
â€¢ The control of heartbeat depends on electrical activity  
â€¢ Heart disorders can produce irregularities in this activity  
â€¢ An ECG is used to detect these defects 
â€¢ Electrode are taped to various positions on the body and the electrical activity 
 
Heart Sounds 
â€¢ The sound the heart makes when it beats is â€˜lub-dubâ€™ 
â€¢ During contraction, the ventricle walls contract to force blood out of the pulmonary artery and 
aorta  
â€¢ The pressure of the blood causes the atrioventricular valves to shut, preventing backflow 
â€¢ This produces the sound â€˜lubâ€™ 
â€¢ During the relaxation phase, the ventricles relax 
â€¢ The pressure of the blood in arteries causes the semi-lunar valves to shut, preventing backflow 
â€¢ This produces the sound â€˜dubâ€™ 
â€¢ Irregularities in the heartbeat can be detected by listening to these heart sounds 
 
The heart and exercise 
â€¢ During exercise, your muscles need more energy from respiration to contract 
â€¢ The heart beats faster and the artery dilate 
â€¢ These changes increase the flow of blood of blood to muscles and result in: 
i. 
Increase in removal of carbon dioxide 
ii. 
Increase in supply of oxygen 
â€¢ You can detect the flow of blood through your pulse 
â€¢ The resting pulse rate is an indication of a personâ€™s fitness

How blood vessels are adapted to their functions 
â€¢ Elastic fibres in arteries stretch and recoil  
â€¢ The recoil of elastic fibres help to push blood along so maintaining pressure 
â€¢ Capillaries provide a huge surface area for exchange between blood and cells 
â€¢ Blood moves slowly giving adequate time for exchange 
â€¢ As the walls are one cell wall thick, it is easy for substances to diffuse 
â€¢ Pressure of blood in veins is low 
â€¢ It gets moved along by the contraction of muscles and organs that surround veins 
Arterioles 
â€¢ Small subdivisions of arteries that carry blood to capillary networks 
â€¢ Have muscle in their walls 
â€¢ Function; blood transport and regulating blood pressure 
â€¢ Receive nerve impulses that trigger hormones to regulate diameter 
Venules 
â€¢ Small blood vessels that collect blood from capillary beds 
â€¢ Thin walled vessels that unite to form veins 
â€¢ Transport deoxygenated blood 
 

Shunt vessels 
â€¢ Vessel that links an artery directly to a vein  
â€¢ Allows blood to bypass capillaries in certain areas 
â€¢ Control blood flow by constriction and dilation 
â€¢ Endotherms- constrict in response to cold, reducing heat loss 
 
Coronary heart disease (CHD) 
â€¢ Coronary heart disease is caused by blockage of the coronary arteries that supply the heart 
with glucose and oxygen  
 
Risk factors of CHD 
i. 
Eating a diet with too much saturated animal fat 
ii. 
Being overweight  
iii. 
Smoking  
iv. 
Taking little or no exercise 
v. 
Stress 
vi. 
Genes inherited 
vii. 
Age â€“ risk increases with age 
viii. 
Sex â€“ men are more likely to get CHD than women  
 
Treatment of CHD 
â€¢ Coronary artery bypass- this is done by grafting a blood vessel from another part of the body, 
above or below the narrowed or blocked area. 
â€¢ Coronary angioplasty-this is whereby a small balloon is inflated inside the artery to widen it. A 
small metal tube is then inserted to help keep the artery open. This tube is called a stent  
â€¢ Antiplatelet medicines (e.g. aspirin) â€“ prevent blood clots from forming in the arteries. Low 
dosage of daily aspirin is used for people with CHD, angina, heart attack patients, coronary 
stent and bypass surgery 
Other conditions 
â€¢ Atherosclerosis- cholesterol sticks to the walls of the artery, effectively narrowing them 
â€¢ Thrombosis- artery walls become rough which can cause blood to clot and block the vessel 
â€¢ Angina- chest pains caused by not enough oxygen getting to the heart muscle 
â€¢ Angina acts as a warning for a heart attack  
â€¢ Total blockage or thrombosis can cause a heart attack  
â€¢ When this happens supply of oxygen is cut off  
â€¢ Causes severe pain and the heart is damaged 
â€¢ The heart may stop beating altogether â€“ cardiac arrest 
 
Blood Composition 
 
Plasma (accounts for 55% of the blood volume) 
Consists of water with chemicals dissolved in it: 
i. 
Nutrients (glucose, amino acids, lipids, vitamins, mineral ions such as sodium and chloride ions) 
ii. 
Wastes, such as urea and carbon dioxide 
iii. 
Blood proteins, such as albumen and antibodies 
iv. 
Hormones. such as insulin, glucagon and adrenaline 

Blood cells  
 Red blood cells have no nuclei, and have cytoplasm full of haemoglobin for transporting oxygen. They 
are disc shaped with the middle pushed in, they have a large surface area to volume ration that aids 
with their function.  
 
White blood cells have nuclei. They may appear white when spun around in a centrifuge, but with closer 
observation- they are colourless and have no pigment that gives them colour. We have to stain them in 
order for them to be visible  
 
Platelets are tiny fragments of cells that cause blood to clot when you cut yourself.  
 
Blood in defence 
White blood cells defend us against diseases, there are two types: lymphocytes and phagocytes. 
 
Phagocytes 
 
They surround pathogens, ingest them and take them into food vacuoles.  
Then they digest them by using enzymes that kill the pathogens, this is called phagocytosis  
 
Lymphocytes 
 
They make proteins called antibodies that have a particular binding site, much like an enzyme, each 
antibodyâ€™s binding site combines with one particular type of pathogen.  
Antibodies attack pathogens in the following ways: 
i. 
They make them sick (agglutinate) 
ii. 
They dissolve their cell membranes  
iii. 
They neutralise toxins produced by pathogens 
After a person has had a disease, the lymphocytes remain to produce more antibodies for that 
pathogen if the disease is encountered again. This is called immunity.  
 
Blood clotting  
 
â€¢ When you cut yourself â€“ you bleed 
â€¢ Platelets helps the blood thicken and the bleeding stops 
â€¢ The thickened blood forms a clot  
â€¢ This is a barrier against infection 
â€¢ Platelets release a substance that converts the soluble protein fibrinogen to the insoluble fibrin 
â€¢ Fibrin forms a meshwork of fibres 
â€¢ Red blood cells get trapped in these threads and clot 
â€¢ The clot hardens to form a scab 
â€¢ The skin heals and the scab falls off 
 
 
 
 
 

Lymph and tissue fluid 
 
Tissue fluid 
â€¢ Some constituents of plasma move out the capillary walls to form tissue fluid surrounding cells 
â€¢ Tissue fluid bathes the cell providing a stable environment  
â€¢ Tissue fluid helps substances diffuse in and out of cells 
â€¢ Useful substance such as oxygen and glucose diffuse in from the tissue fluids and waste 
products diffuse out 
â€¢ Most fluid tissue re-enters the capillary  
â€¢ Fluid flows from plasma back into plasma but some drains into our lymphatic system  
 
The lymphatic system  
â€¢ The remaining plasma enter the lymph capillaries, it is now called lymph  
â€¢ Lymph consist of plasma and white blood cells, but has no red blood cells or large plasma 
proteins  
â€¢ Lymph capillaries have tiny valves allowing entry but no exit  
â€¢ They join up to form lymph vessels  
â€¢ Similar structure to veins: thin walls and semi lunar valves  
â€¢ Has no pump so it dependent on the contraction of muscles 
â€¢ Lymph flows from tissues to heart 
â€¢ Substances empty into subclavian veins, mixes with blood and enters the heart via the vena cava 
â€¢ They are many lymph nodes throughout the lymph vessels  
â€¢ Lymphocytes are in the lymph nodes where they multiply during an infection and produce 
antibodies

Solids, Liquids and Gases 
â€¢ All matter is made up of particles. Three types of particles make up matter: 
1. An atom is the smallest particle that cannot be broken down by chemical means 
2. A molecule is a particle of two or more atoms joined together

Diffusion 
â€¢ The kinetic particle theory states that molecules in solids, liquids and gases are constantly 
moving 
â€¢ Diffusion is the random movement of particles until evenly spread 
â€¢ The overall direction of the movement of the particles is from where the particles are more 
concentrated to where the particles are less concentrated, however, since the particles are 
moving randomly, some are moving from less concentrated regions to even more concentrated 
regions 
â€¢ Diffusion does not occur in solids because of the arrangement of their particles 
â€¢ Diffusion occurs faster in gases than in liquids because gas particles move more rapidly than 
liquid particles 

â€¢ The speed at which diffusion occurs depends on how heavy its molecules are. Lighter molecules 
diffuse faster than heavier molecules 
â€¢ The rate of diffusion depends on the relative molecular mass. Substances with a high relative 
mass diffuse more slowly than those with a low relative molecular mass

â€¢ Volume can be measured using: 
1. A volumetric cylinder

â€¢ The volume of gases can be measured using a gas syringe or an upturned measuring cylinder 
(displacement) 
â€¢ Accuracy depends on: 
1. Using apparatus with small scale divisions 
2. Reading the measurements accurately (no error of parallax) 
3. Repeating measurements to remove anomalies 
4. Using the apparatus carefully 
Paper Chromatography 
â€¢ Chromatography is a method for separating and purifying colored compounds using filter paper 
and a solvent 
â€¢ Chromatography is used to identify compounds 
â€¢ Locating agents are used to make colorless compounds visible on a chromatogram

Chemical Purity 
 
â€¢ When chemists talk about purity they mean there is only one substance present 
â€¢ Medicinal drugs and food additives must be pure to avoid harming people 
â€¢ The computer industry needs pure silicon to make computer chips, to prevent the chips from not 
working properly 
â€¢ The melting point is the temperature at which a substance changes from solid to a liquid 

â€¢ The boiling point is the temperature at which a solid changes to a liquid 
â€¢ Melting and boiling points can be used to identify pure substances 
â€¢ A pure substance melts and boils at a definite temperature 
â€¢ An impure substance melts and boils over a range of temperatures 
â€¢ Simple distillation is used to separate water from a dissolved salt

Methods of Purification 
â€¢ A dissolved solid is called a solute 
â€¢ The liquid that dissolves in the solute is called a solvent 
â€¢ Solute + Solvent = Solution 
â€¢ An undissolved solid cab be separated from a solution or liquid by passing it through a 
piece of filter paper in a funnel. This is called filtration. 
â€¢ Decanting is to pour off a solution leaving the solid behind

forcing the solid particles to the bottom so the liquid can be poured off

immiscible

An acidic base is used in baking powder together with powdered tartaric acid .  There are lots of acid molecules present but very few ions present . Making and identifying salts 
How do we make salts? 
â€¢ Reacting a metal with an acid 
â€¢ Reacting an insoluble base with an acid 
â€¢ Neutralizing an alkali with an acid by titration 
â€¢ By precipitation  
Salts from metals 
â€¢ This method is only suitable for metals above hydrogen in the reactivity series, such as: 
magnesium, zinc, aluminum and iron 
â€¢ It is not appropriate for metals such as copper, lead and silver as they are too close to hydrogen 
in the reactivity series 
â€¢ It is also not a good idea to prepare salts of sodium and potassium using this method as the 
reaction is too violent  
Procedure: 
1. Add the metal to the acid in a flask so that the metal is in excess. The acid is the limiting reagent. 
2. Warm the flask gently to complete the reaction  
3. Filter off the excess metal. The filtrate is a solution of the metal salt 
4. Put the filtrate into an evaporating basin and evaporate the water until crystallization point. 
Allow crystals to form at room temperature  
5. Filter off crystals and wash them with small volumes of distilled water so that they do not 
dissolve  
6. Dry between the folds of filter paper 
Salts from insoluble bases 
â€¢ We can make salts with many metals by reacting an insoluble base with an acid 
â€¢ Used for making salts of metals that are low on the reactivity series 
â€¢ For example: 
ğ¶ğ‘¢ğ‘‚(ğ‘ ) + ğ»2ğ‘†ğ‘‚4(ğ‘ğ‘) â†’ğ¶ğ‘¢ğ‘†ğ‘‚4(ğ‘ğ‘) + ğ»2ğ‘‚(ğ‘™) 
Titrations  
â€¢ Titration is used to make a soluble salt from a soluble base and an acid 
â€¢ This method is used to make salts of Group 1 metals and ammonium salts  
â€¢ We use an acid-alkali titration to find out how much acid is needed to react exactly with the 
solution of an alkali  
â€¢ We use an indicator to find when the acid has just reacted with the alkali (called the end point) 
â€¢ At the end point the indicator changes color. 
â€¢ The titration is first carried out with an indicator and then without any indicator  
â€¢ The acid usually goes in the burette and the alkali in the flask  
â€¢ The indicator depends on whether you use a strong or weak acid or alkali: 
o For a strong acid and alkali use any indicator  
o For a weak alkali (ammonia) we titrate with a strong acid. The indicator used is methyl 
orange which goes from orange to red when there is excess acid 

o For a weak acid, we used a strong base. The indicator used is phenolphalein which 
changes from pink to colorless when there is excess acid  
Procedure 
1. Rinse the pipette with alkali, measure a known volume of alkali into the flask using a volumetric 
pipette 
2. Add a few drops of indicator solution  
3. Rinse the burette with acid, fill burette with acid using a funnel  
4. Record the burette reading  
5. Allow acid to flow into flask, swirl the flask to mix solution until the indicator changes color 
6. Record burette reading

7. Repeat this 3 times, add acid drop by drop without indicator  
8. Do calculation to find the concentration of alkali using accurate titres (taken on average)

â€¢ This is used to make insoluble salts  
â€¢ It is made by mixing 2 soluble compounds that contain the cation and anion of the insoluble salt 
you wish to make  
â€¢ The cation and anion will react to form a precipitate  
Procedure 
1. Identify the ions present in the insoluble salt 
2. Use the solubility table to choose soluble compounds including these ions 
3. Add one solution to the other 
4. Filter off the precipitate then wash and dry the solid

The Periodic Table 
â€¢ Elements in the periodic table are arranged in order of their proton number 
â€¢ Vertical columns are called groups 
â€¢ Horizontal rows are called periods 
â€¢ Elements in the same group have similar chemical properties, this is because they 
have the same number of valence electrons 
â€¢ Metallic character decreases across a period but increases down a group 
â€¢ Basic oxides are on the left hand side of the periodic table, acidic oxides are on the 
right hand side 
â€¢ Most metal oxides are basic oxides and most non-metal oxides are acidic oxides 
â€¢ The valency of an element is the number of electrons its atoms gain, lose or share 
when they form a compound.

â€¢ Group I metals are called the alkali metals 
â€¢ They are very reactive becayse they only have to give away 1 electron 
â€¢ They are stored in paraffin or oil because they are so reactive 
â€¢ The melting points and boiling points decrease down the group 
â€¢ The metals get softer down the group 
â€¢ There is a general increase in density down the group with the exception of sodium

â€¢ They react with water to form a metal hydroxide and hydrogen gas 
â€¢ Group I elements all react with water to produce hydrogen and a solution or 
the alkali metal hydroxide  

â€¢ The chemical reactivity of the alkali metals increases down the group 
because the atoms get larger down the group so the electrostatic force 
between the electron and the positive nucleus decreases 
 
 
Group VII elements 
â€¢ Group VII elements are called halogens 
â€¢ They are poisonous non-metals that have low melting and boiling points 
â€¢ They all exist as diatomic molecules 
â€¢ The melting points and boiling points of the halogens increase down the group. 
This is the opposite to Group I metals 
â€¢ The state of the halogens at room temperature changes from gas to liquid to solid 
down the group 
â€¢ The color gets darker down the group 
â€¢ Salts when metals react with halogens are called halide 
â€¢ Reactivity decreases down the group because as the atoms get larger the 
electrostatic force between the outer shell and the nucleus decreases 
â€¢ Chlorine is a green, bromine is an orange-brown liquid and iodine is a grey solid 
â€¢ When metals react with halogens, halides salts are formed 
â€¢ Displacement reactions occur when more reactive halogens compete to form 
compounds 
 
Noble gases 
â€¢ Noble gases are found in Group 0 
â€¢ They have a full outer shell of electrons  
â€¢ They are unreactive or inert 
â€¢ They are monatomic 
â€¢ They are colorless gases 
â€¢ Helium and neon are lighter than air 
â€¢ Argon, krypton, xenon and radon are heavier than air 
â€¢ The density of the noble gases increases down the group 
â€¢ The boiling points of the noble gases increase down the group 
â€¢ Helium is used in weather balloons and airships because it is less dense than air 
â€¢ Neon is used in advertising signs because it glows red when a high voltage is 
passed through it 
â€¢ Argon is used in lightbulbs because it is inert 
â€¢ Krypton is used in lasers for eye surgery and in bulbs for car headlamps 
â€¢ Xenon is used where very bright light is required, they are also used in lasers  

Transition Elements 
â€¢ They are all metals 
â€¢ They all conduct heat and electricity 
â€¢ They are malleable and ductile 
â€¢ They are shiny and sonorous  
â€¢ They have very high melting and boiling points 
â€¢ They have very high densities 
â€¢ They are stronger and harder than Group I metals 
â€¢ They have more than one oxidation state- they have variable valency 
â€¢ They form colored compounds 
â€¢ They form complex ions 
â€¢ Many transition elements and oxides are good catalysts 
â€¢ They are less reactive than metals from other groups. They do not react with cold 
water, although some react with steam

Metals and Reactivity  
Alloys 
 
â€¢ 
We can change the properties of a metal to 
make it harder or more resistant to corrosion. This is 
done by mixing it with another metal or with a non-
metal. 
â€¢ 
A mixture of two or metals, or one or more 
metals with a non-metal is called an alloy 
â€¢ 
Atoms in a pure metal are arranged in regular 
layers, when a force is applied the layers are able to 
slide over each other. This explains why metals are 
malleable and ductile 
â€¢ 
When a metal is alloyed with a second metal, the 
different sized metal atoms make the arrangement of 
the lattice less regular. We say they disrupt the 
crystal lattice. This stops the layers of metal atoms 
sliding over each other when a force is applied. This 
is why an alloy is stronger and harder than a pure metal 
â€¢ Some alloys are known to have properties of memory as they are able to 
resume their original shape when straitened and then placed in hot water. 
These are called shape memory alloys.  
The metal reactivity series 
â€¢ Metals can be arranged in a reactivity series by comparing how easily they react 
with water, steam and hydrochloric acid 
â€¢ Only metals above hydrogen in the reactivity series will react with hydrochloric 
acid  
â€¢ Only metals above hydrogen in the reactivity series will react with water or steam  
Reacting metals with oxygen 
â€¢ Copper: does not burn but turns black on its surface 
â€¢ Iron: only burns when in powder form or as iron wool 
â€¢ Gold: does not burn at all, even as a powder 
â€¢ Magnesium: burns rapidly with a bright white light 
 
 

Reacting metals with steam or water 
â€¢ All the metals above hydrogen react with oxygen to form a metal oxide 
â€¢ Iron and lead only oxidize in powder form 
â€¢ Only the surface of copper reacts to form black copper oxide 
â€¢ If a metal does not react with cold water it may react with steam 
â€¢ If a metal reacts with cold water, a metal hydroxide and hydrogen are formed 
â€¢ If a metal only reacts with steam, a metal oxide is formed 
â€¢ Group I metals are very reactive, on reaction with water they produce hydroxide 
and hydrogen 
â€¢ Group II metals are less reactive they produce an oxide and hydrogen 
Calcium 
Reacts rapidly with water 
Copper 
No reaction with cold water or steam 
Magnesium  Reacts very slowly with cold water but reacts rapidly with steam 
Sodium  
Reacts violently with cold water  
Zinc  
Only reacts when powdered and heated strongly in steam 
 
â€¢ Metals below hydrogen do not react with cold water or steam. They do not release 
hydrogen from hydrochloric acid either. So copper, silver and gold are unreactive 
â€¢ A more reactive metal displaces a less reactive metal from a solution of its salt 
â€¢ A more reactive metal loses its valency electrons more easily than a less reactive 
metal 
â€¢ The ease with which a metal loses its valency electrons to form ions depends on 
the distance of the valency electrons from the nucleus, the nuclear charge and the 
number of electron shells 
Reacting metals with acid 
â€¢ Only metals above hydrogen react with dilute acid 
â€¢ A metal reacts with an acid to form a metal salt and hydrogen 
Reducing metal oxides 
â€¢ Metal oxides below carbon in the reactivity series are reduced by carbon when 
heated 
â€¢ When a more reactive metal is heated with the oxide of a less reactive metal, the 
more reactive metal acts as a reductant 
â€¢ The apparent lack of reactivity of aluminum is due to an unreactive oxide layer that 
forms on its surface  
Thermal Decomposition  
â€¢ Thermal decomposition is the breakdown of a compound into two or more 
products by heat 

â€¢ The more reactive the metal, the more stable its compounds 
â€¢ Most metal hydroxides decompose to form a metal oxide and water 
â€¢ All metal nitrates decompose: 
i. 
Group I metals form a nitrite and oxygen 
ii. 
Other metals form a metal oxide, nitrogen dioxide and oxygen 
â€¢ Nitrites of very unreactive metals decompose to for the metal, nitrogen dioxide and 
oxygen 
â€¢ The more reactive the metal, the more stable its hydroxide, carbonate or nitrate 
â€¢ When you burn Sulphur in oxygen it burns with a blue flame 
â€¢

The more reactive the metal, the more stable its hydroxide, carbonate or nitrate . Sulphur in oxygen burns with a blue flame when burned in oxygen . Other metals form a metal oxide, nitrogen dioxide and oxygen . Nitrites of unreactive metals decompose to for the metal and nitrogen dioxide .

Metals from their ores 
â€¢ A rock from which a metal can be extracted from is called an ore 
Metal extraction and the reactivity series 
â€¢ The way we extract metal from its ore depends on its position in the reactivity series 
â€¢ Carbon is used to reduce metal oxides of metals below it in the reactivity series 
â€¢ Carbon monoxide is also a good reductant 
â€¢ Metals above carbon in the reactivity series cannot be extracted from their oxides by heating 
with carbon. This is because the metal bonds to oxygen too strongly and the carbon is not 
strong enough to remove it 
â€¢ Metals more reactive than carbon are extracted by electrolysis 
â€¢ Electrolysis is used to extract metals such as aluminium, calcium and magnesium 
â€¢ It is possible to use electrolysis to extract metals less reactive than carbon. This is not done 
because much more energy is needed to carry out electrolysis compared with extraction 
using carbon 
â€¢

(carbon) and air

â€¢ The main ore of iron, haematite, usually contains 60% of iron. Haematite is largely iron (III) 
oxide. We extract iron by the reduction of iron (III) oxide with carbon 
â€¢ The raw materials for making iron are haematite, coke, limestone and air.

Iron to Steel 
â€¢ The iron produced in the blast furnace us only about 95% pure 
â€¢ The impurities are mainly carbon but also include sulfur, silicon and phosphorus  
â€¢ The impurities make the iron brittle 
â€¢ If all impurities are removed, the iron becomes very soft. IN this condition, it is easily shaped 
but is too soft for many uses 
â€¢ Pure iron also rusts very easily 
â€¢ To make iron strong only some of the impurities are removed to produce various types of 
steel. Steel is an alloy of iron and or carbon with other metals 
Steel making 
â€¢ Steel is made using a basic oxygen converter  
â€¢ The converter is tipped to one side and molten iron and scrap iron are poured in 
â€¢ The convertor is put back into a vertical position. A water cooled tube called an oxygen lance 
is lowered into the convertor 

â€¢ Oxygen and powdered calcium oxide are blown onto the surface of the molten iron through 
the lance  
â€¢ The oxygen oxidises carbon, sulfur, silicon and phosphorus to their oxides. 
â€¢ The carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide escape from the convertor because they are gases 
â€¢ These reactions are exothermic. The heat released in these oxidation reactions keep iron 
molten. 
â€¢ Silicon and phosphorus oxides are solids. They are acidic oxides. So these react with the 
powdered calcium oxide which is basic and slag is formed 
â€¢ The slag floats on the surface of the molten iron and is removed 
â€¢ The amount of carbon in steel is controlled by the amount of oxygen blown into the impure 
iron. The longer the oxygen blast, the more carbon is removed 
â€¢ After the required amount of carbon has been removed, other elements such as chromium 
and nickel are added to make particular types of steel. 
Steel alloys 
â€¢ Mild steel is low carbon steel. It is soft, malleable and ductile. It is used to make car bodies 
and parts of machinery. It is also used for buildings and general building purposes 
â€¢ High carbon steel is used for hammers and chisels 
â€¢ Low alloy steels contain other metals such as chromium, magnesium and titanium. They are 
hard and do not stretch much. Nickel steels are used for bridges where strength is needed for 
bicycle chains. Tungsten steel is used for high speed tools because it does not change shape 
at high temperatures

used in the construction of pipes and towers in chemical factories. Stainless steel is also 
used to make cutlery. Surgical instruments are made from stainless steel.  
Other alloys 
â€¢ Aluminium is used for making aircraft bodies because it is lightweight and has a low density. 
Some food containers and cooking foil are made from aluminium. This is because there is an 
unreactive oxide layer that does not flake off, the oxide does not react with the acids that are 
present in many foods.  
â€¢ Zinc is used to galvanise iron or mild steel to prevent rusting, Galvanised steel is used for 
roofing because it is weather resistant.  
â€¢ Copper is used for electrical wiring and because of its high conductivity, it is also malleable 
and ductile. It is also used for the base of saucepans because of its high heat conductivity 
â€¢ Brass is stronger than copper and it does corrode. It is malleable, and an attractive colour. It 
is used to make musical instruments, door handles, ornaments and screws.
summary_text: Carbon is used to reduce metal oxides of metals below it in the reactivity series . Metals above carbon cannot be extracted from their oxides by heating them with carbon . This is because the metal bonds to oxygen too strongly and the carbon is not strong enough to remove it . More reactive metals such as aluminium, calcium and magnesium are extracted by electrolysis .  Iron produced in the blast furnace is only about 95% pure . To make iron strong only some of the impurities are removed to produce various types of steel . Steel is an alloy of iron and or carbon with other metals such as chromium, magnesium and titanium .  Tungsten steel is used for high speed tools because it does not change shape at high temperatures . Stainless steel is very strong and resist corrosion, so they are used in the construction of pipes and towers in chemical factories . Brass is stronger than copper and it does corrode, and is malleable and ductile .

â€¢ Water is used un the home for drinking, cooking, washing and cleaning 
â€¢ In industry water is used as a solvent for many chemicals and as a coolant to stop industrial 
processes from getting too hot. It is also a cheap raw material for some chemical 
manufacturing processes. Water is also used for generating power either in hydro electrical 
power station or by turning into steam to drive turbines 
â€¢ In agriculture, water is used on farms for watering crops and for animals to drink

â€¢ Water from rivers and lakes are not pure, it contains dead animals and plants, dissolved in 
bacteria, many of which are harmful to health  
â€¢ Cholera and typhoid are just two main diseases caused by bacteria in untreated water  
â€¢ A modern water treatment plant removes insoluble materials and bacteria by filtration and 
chlorination 
â€¢ Treating water is a complex process and there are many stages: 
 
1. The water passes through metal grinds which collect objects such as twigs and leaves 
2. In the sedimentation tank, particles of solids such as soil particles settle to the bottom of the 
tank 
3. Aluminium sulphate is added to make small particles in water stick together, the particles fall 
to the bottom of the tank 
4. The water then passes through a filter made of sand and gravel or crushed coal. This 
removes any small insoluble particles that were not removed in the other tanks  
5. Chlorine is added to kill bacteria  
6. The pH of the water is adjusted and the water is run off and stored or goes directly to homes 
and factories

these are present in small amounts, they have a big effect on our environment  
Separating the gases 
â€¢ Oxygen is used in welding, steel making and to support respiration systems in hospital 
â€¢ Nitrogen is very unreactive it is used to provide an inert atmosphere for food packaging, 
chemical processes and silicon chip production. The gases in air are separated by fractional 
distillation in liquid air: 
 
1. Water is removed from the air by passing it through a drying agent and carbon dioxide is 
removed by reacting it with sodium hydroxide solution 
2. The air is then cooled to -23Â°C and compressed (squashed into a small space) 
3. The cold compresses air is allowed to expand into a larger space. When it expands, the air is 
cooled. After this is repeated several times the temperature is cooled to -200Â°C. Most of the 
air is now liquid  
4. Argon, neon and xenon are removed easily because they are still gases under these 
condition. This leaves us with a mixture of oxygen and nitrogen  
5. When the liquid air is warmed, the nitrogen boils off first because it has a lower boiling point. 
Some of the nitrogen condenses at the top of the lower distillation column leaving a mixture 
of impure oxygen and nitrogen at the bottom. The mixture is then expanded into a gas 
6. The oxygen-nitrogen mixture is then fed into the top column. The temperature is the top 
column is below the boiling point of oxygen and the above the boiling point of nitrogen. So 
the oxygen condenses at the bottom and nitrogen gas is removed at the top.

â€¢ When we remove a hydrogen atom from an alkane chain we have a group called an alkyl group  
â€¢ Alkyl groups are named after the hydrocarbons by changing the â€“ane ending of the 
hydrocarbon to â€“yl 
â€¢ The general formula for an alkyl group is: ğ¶ğ‘›ğ»2ğ‘›+1 
Fuels  
â€¢ The fossil fuels: coal, petroleum and natural gas all contain hydrocarbons.  
â€¢ We cannot use petroleum as a fuel because it is a sticky black liquid that is difficult to set alight  
â€¢ When it does burn it produces clouds of poisonous black smoke  

â€¢ Petroleum is a mixture of many types of hydrocarbons having different lengths of carbon chain  
â€¢ Some of the chains are branched and there may even be compounds with rings of carbon atoms  
â€¢ Fractional distillation is used to separate the hydrocarbon molecules in petroleum into groups 
that have similar boiling points 
â€¢ These groups of molecules are called fractions  
â€¢ Each contains hydrocarbons having a certain range of carbon atoms  
â€¢ Apart from refinery gases, all these fractions are liquids 
â€¢ Many of these fractions are used as fuels: 
Fraction  
Number of carbon atoms

Diesel for cars and larger vehicles

For ships and home heating  
 
There is a variety of fuels we can use: 
â€¢ Wood- we use wood for heating and cooking. Some scientists are working to produce liquid fuel 
from very young trees 
â€¢ Biofuels- some plants such as oilseed rape and corn produce plant oils that can be modified for 
use in diesel engines. Other plants such as sugar cane and beet can be used to produce ethanol 
by the process of fermentation. Ethanol can be used as a fuel in cars  
â€¢ Solid waste- this can be burnt in some small power stations. But great care has to be taken that 
the poisonous chemicals formed in the furnace at high temperatures are not releases into the 
atmosphere  
â€¢ Methane (natural gas) - as well as being found underground, methane is also produced by 
decomposition of materials in rubbish sites. In some places, the gas can be piped out from the 
rubbish site and used for heating  
â€¢ Hydrogen- a good fuel because it releases a lot of energy per gram and is non-polluting. 
However, it is usually made by using energy from other fuels  
What makes a good fuel? 
â€¢ How much heat does it give out? Most hydrocarbon fuels give out a similar amount of energy 
per gram but hydrogen produces a lot more energy per gram 
â€¢ Is it polluting? Cola is very polluting, oil is less polluting and natural gas does not produce 
much pollution. But all these fuels produce the greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide when burnt 
â€¢ Is it easy to use? Solid fuels such as coal and wood are not as easy to use as liquid fuels 
â€¢ Is it readily available? Many people are worried that the supply of petroleum and natural has will 
run out over the next 100 years 
â€¢ Is it cheap? The price depends on many things: how easy it is to extract and transport, 
availability and politics 
â€¢ Is it easy and safe to transport? Many fuels are flammable so care has to be taken when 
transporting them and using them  
 
 

Petroleum  
â€¢ The hydrocarbon fractions are separated by fractional distillation  
â€¢ The petroleum is first heated so that all the hydrocarbons present are present as gases 
â€¢ The petroleum is then fed into a tower called a fractionating column  
â€¢ The column is kept hot at the bottom but is cooler at the top 
â€¢ So there is a range of temperatures in the column  
â€¢ Near the bottom, the hydrocarbons with higher boiling points condense  
â€¢ Hydrocarbons with lower boiling points are still gases 
â€¢ These move further up the column  
â€¢ As they move up the column, each hydrocarbon condenses at the point where the temperature is 
the column falls just below the point of the hydrocarbon  
â€¢ Hydrocarbons of similar boiling points are collected as fractions  
â€¢ Some of the hydrocarbons do not condense  
â€¢ They come off as gases at the top of the column  
â€¢ These are refinery gases such as methane, ethane, propane and butane 
â€¢ In many oil refineries these are removed from the petroleum before fractionation
summary_text: All organic compounds contain carbon and usually contain hydrogen and may contain other elements as well . A group of organic molecules with similar properties is called a homologous series . A functional group is an atom or groups of atoms that gives a compound particular properties . The physical properties change in a regular way as the number of carbon atoms increase .  Hydrogen- a good fuel because it releases a lot of energy per gram and is non-polluting . Cola is very polluting, oil is less polluting and natural gas does not produce much pollution . But all these fuels produce the greenhouse gas, carbon dioxide when burnt .

â€¢ Organic chemistry is the study of organic compounds: carbon compounds that originate in 
living things

Structural isomers 
â€¢ Structural isomers are compounds with the same formula, but a different arrangement of atoms.  
Alkanes 
â€¢ Alkanes are hydrocarbons which only have a single covalent bonds in their structure. 
â€¢ We call them saturated hydrocarbons because no more atoms can be added to their molecules  
Physical properties of the alkanes 
â€¢ All alkanes are colorless gases, liquids or solids 
â€¢ The first four member of the alkane homologous series are gases at r.t.p. 
â€¢ Alkanes with 5 to 17 carbon atoms in their chains are liquids 
â€¢ Alkanes with more than 17 carbon atoms in their chains are solids 
â€¢ The boiling points of the alkanes vary in a regular way 
â€¢ You can see as the carbon chains get longer, the boiling points of the alkanes increase 
â€¢ The difference in the boiling point from one alkane to the next also gets smaller as the number of 
carbon atoms increases 
Chemical properties of the alkanes 
â€¢ Alkanes are generally unreactive compounds  
â€¢ They do not react with acids or alkalis 
â€¢ They do burn and undergo a few reactions under special conditions  
â€¢ Alkanes burn with a clean blue flame if there is plenty of oxygen or air present  
â€¢ We describe this reaction as complete combustion  
â€¢ Carbon dioxide and water are formed  

They burn in air 
Type of Reaction 
Combustion 
Reactants 
Alkane + plenty of oxygen for complete combustion  
What else is required 
Flame to ignite the fuel 
What is produced 
Carbon dioxide + water + plenty of heat 
 
The reactions of alkanes with chlorine 
â€¢ One chemical that alkanes will react with is chlorine-but only under certain conditions  
â€¢ Alkanes do not react with chlorine in the dark  
â€¢ However, if we mix chlorine with an alkane in a sealed tube and keep it in bright sunlight, the 
green color of chlorine disappears 
â€¢ This is a photochemical reaction  
â€¢ We call this type of reaction a substitution reaction  
â€¢ You will notice that the acidic gas hydrogen chloride is produced. This turns damp blue litmus 
paper red 
â€¢ If we use excess chlorine we can substitute more hydrogen atoms  
â€¢ If enough chlorine is present all hydrogen atoms can be replaced by chlorine atoms 
â€¢ We can carry out similar reactions with alkanes and other halogens 
Reaction with chlorine 
Type of reaction 
Substitution ( one or more hydrogen atoms are replaced by chlorine) 
Reactant  
Alkane + chlorine gas  
What else is required 
UV light- this is a photochemical reaction 
What is produced 
Hydrogen chloride + chloroalkanes 
 
Cracking alkanes 
â€¢ Cracking is the thermal decomposition of alkanes 
â€¢ Alkenes are obtained from alkanes by a process called cracking 
â€¢ Cracking involves heating vaporized alkanes in the presence of a catalyst  
â€¢ Cracking breaks down molecules into smaller ones 
â€¢ Cracking always produces some molecules with double bonds: alkenes 
â€¢ Longer chained alkanes are cracked to form a mixture of shorter-chained alkanes and alkenes 
Cracking petroleum fractions on a large scale  
â€¢ Cracking is often carried out on a large scale using a catalyst  
â€¢ The huge tank where this takes place is called a catalytic (cat) cracker 
â€¢ The vapor from the gas-oil or kerosene fractions is passed through a catalyst of silicon (IV) 
oxide and aluminum oxide at 400-500Â°C 
â€¢ The catalyst is a fine powder which has to be continuously recycles to the cat cracker through a 
regenerator tank  
â€¢ This frees the catalyst from any carbon deposited on its surface  
 
 

The longer-chained alkanes in the gas-oil or kerosene fractions which are less useful are broken down 
to shorter chained hydrocarbons: 
â€¢ The shorter-chained alkanes are used for petrol and very small alkanes are used for fuel  
â€¢ The alkenes can be used to make a wide variety of chemicals, including plastics 
â€¢ Hydrogen may also be formed which can be used for making ammonia or as a fuel  
Catalytic cracking is not the only type of cracking.  
â€¢ Long chained alkanes can be cracked at a high temperature without a catalyst  
â€¢ A temperature between 450Â°C and 800Â°C is used 
â€¢ This type of cracking produces a greater percentage if alkenes  
Alkenes 
â€¢ Alkenes are a homologous series of hydrocarbons whose names end in â€“ene 
â€¢ We call them unsaturated hydrocarbons because they have a double carbon bond 
â€¢ They do not have the maximum number of hydrogen atoms around each carbon atom 
â€¢ More atoms can be added to their molecules  
â€¢ We can test to see if a hydrocarbon is unsaturated by using aqueous bromine  
â€¢ Bromine water is a yellow/orange color 
â€¢ If the bromine water is decolorized, the hydrocarbon in unsaturated  
â€¢ All alkenes decolorize bromine water 
â€¢ If the bromine water remains the same yellow/orange color, the hydrocarbon is saturated 
Chemical properties of the alkenes 
Combustion  
â€¢ The complete combustion of alkenes produces carbon dioxide and water 
Addition reactions 
â€¢ Many of the reactions of alkenes are called addition reactions 
â€¢ In an addition reaction, two reactants add together to form only one product 
Hydrogen reacts with alkenes to form alkanes 
â€¢ This addition reaction is also called a hydrogenation reaction  
â€¢ It can also be classed as a reduction reaction  
â€¢ The reaction is carried out at 60Â°C with nickel as a catalyst 
â€¢ This type of reaction is used to male margarine from unsaturated vegetable oils  
â€¢ Only some of the double bonds in the vegetable oil are changed to single bonds 
â€¢ This is enough to harden the oil and make it into solid margarine 
Steam reacts with alkenes to form alcohols 
â€¢ A high temperature 300Â°C, and high pressure 700 atms is needed for these reactions 
â€¢ The steam is passed over a catalyst of phosphoric acid  
â€¢ This method gives a good yield of alcohol  
â€¢ Ethanol of high purity is made by this method  
 

Alcohols 
â€¢ Alcohols are a homologous series having â€“OH as the functional group  
â€¢ Their names all end with â€“ol 
â€¢ Ethanol is a colorless liquid that boils at about 78Â°C 
â€¢ It is miscible with water  
â€¢ Ethanol can by manufactured from: 
 
Fermentation of glucose 
â€¢ During fermentation, the enzymes in living yeast cells catalyze the breakdown of 
glucose into ethanol and carbon dioxide 
â€¢ Fermentation is an exothermic reaction- heat is released 
â€¢ The ethanol is separated from the mixture by fractional distillation  
â€¢ Fermentation is used to make ethanol from corn, wine and grapes. When the % of 
ethanol reaches a certain level, or if the liquid gets too warm, the yeast stops working 
 
By hydration of ethene-the chemical way 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
â€¢ The reaction is called a hydration because water molecules adds on to the ethene 
â€¢ There is no other product- so this is an addition reaction 
â€¢ A catalyst is needed, to speed up the reaction  
â€¢ A catalyst is needed, to speed up the reaction  
â€¢ It is a reversible reaction, and high pressure improves the yield of ethanol  
â€¢ The hydration is exothermic- heat is released  
â€¢ A low temperature will improve the yield, but the reaction will be too slow- so 570Â°C is 
chosen as a compromise 
 
 
Uses of ethanol 
â€¢ As a solvent: ethanol is used in perfumes and other cosmetics, in printing inks and glues 
â€¢ As a fuel: ethanol can be mixed with petrol or used alone as a fuel for cars. It is less polluting 
than petrol and reduces the reliance on petrol and diesel 
â€¢ It is used to male other chemicals such as esters which are used in food flavorings and in many 
cosmetics 
â€¢ In some cultures the ethanol produced by fermentation is used for making alcoholic drinks  
 
 

Ethanol to ethanoic acid 
Oxidation/Fermentation in the air: 
â€¢ Acetobacter is a group of bacteria that causes wine to go sour 
â€¢ These bacteria are naturally present in air and the surfaces around us 
â€¢ When we leave a solution of ethanol exposed to the air, enzymes from the bacterium speed up 
the conversion of ethanol to ethanoic acid 
â€¢ The reaction does not take place in the absence of oxygen 
â€¢ This reaction makes vinegar 
â€¢ Vinegar is a solution of ethanoic acid  
Acidified potassium manganate (VII) 
â€¢ Potassium manganate (VII) is a good oxidant, especially when sulfuric acid is added 
â€¢ We heat the ethanol with potassium manganate (VII) and sulfuric acid 
â€¢ We do this in a flask with a condenser in an upright position  
â€¢ We call this refluxing  
â€¢ This prevents alcohol which is very volatile from escaping  
â€¢ Other alcohols can be oxidized in the same way 
â€¢ The manganate (VII) ions are reduced, which produces a color change 
Potassium dichromate (VI) 
â€¢ Ethanol is oxidized by potassium dichromate (VI) another powerful oxidizing agent  
â€¢ There is a color change when the chromate (VI) ions are reduced 
â€¢ Potassium dichromate is used in one type of breathalyzer  
â€¢ It oxidizes any alcohol on a personâ€™s breath and it itself reduced, changing color from orange to 
green 
Carboxylic acids 
â€¢ The carboxylic acids are a homologous series with â€“COOH as the functional group  
â€¢ Their names all end in â€“ioc acid  
Chemical properties of carboxylic acid  
â€¢ Carboxylic acids are typical weak acids 
â€¢ They are only partly ionized in water 
â€¢ The hydrogen of the â€“COOH group is the only one that is responsible for the acidity of 
carboxylic acids 
â€¢ Salts of ethanoic acid are named by changing the â€“oic to the â€“oate 
â€¢ They react with metals to form a salt and hydrogen 
â€¢ They react with alkalis to form a salt and water 
â€¢ They react with metal carbonates to form a salt, water and carbon dioxide  
Esters 
â€¢ 
Ethanoic acid reacts with alcohols to form compound called esters 
â€¢ 
The functional group is circled. It is called the ester linkage 
â€¢ 
Many esters have distinctive tastes and smells so they are used as artificial flavorings and fragrances

Polymers 
What are polymers? 
â€¢ Plastics and proteins are macromolecules 
â€¢ Macromolecules are very large molecules made up of repeating units 
â€¢ We make plastics from lots of small molecules that join together to form long chains 
â€¢ We call the small molecules that join together monomers 
â€¢ The long-chain molecule formed by joining the monomers is called a polymer 
â€¢ The process of joining monomers together to form polymers is called polymerization  
â€¢ Polymers are often formed by addition reactions 
â€¢ We call this type of polymerization, where there are no other substances formed, addition 
polymerization 
â€¢ Poly(ethene), commonly just called polythene is a plastic that is easy to shape and quite strong  
â€¢ It is made by joining ethene monomers together  
Plastics 
â€¢ Plastics are particular types of polymers that can be molded 
â€¢ Plastics have a wide range of uses: 
i. 
Poly(ethene) for bowls, buckets, dustbins and plastic bags 
ii. 
Poly(propene) for milk crates and ropes 
iii. 
Poly(chloroethene) (polyvinyl chloride, PVC) for insulation around electrical wires and 
for rainwater pipes and gutters 
iv. 
Nylon for ropes, clothes and fishing nets  
v. 
Terylene for clothing  
â€¢ Many plastics are non-biodegradable  
â€¢ This means they are not broken down in the soil or water by micro-organisms when they are 
thrown away  
â€¢ If plastics get into drains they can block them and cause flooding 
â€¢ Plastics can kill wildlife by trapping small animals or blocking the digestive systems of animals 
and birds  that eat plastic along with their normal food 
â€¢ How can we deal with unwanted plastics? 
i. 
Put them into landfills. These fill up very quickly and use up land that could be used for 
agriculture or housing 
ii. 
Burn them- we can use the heat produced to provide electricity or heating. But many 
plastic produce poisonous gases when they burn. PVC produces acidic hydrogen 
chloride. Plastics containing nitrogen may produce toxic hydrogen cyanide. Many 
plastics when burnt at high temperatures also produce poisonous compounds called 
dioxins. It is very expensive to put filters on the furnaces used to burn plastics so this is 
rarely done 
iii. 
Recycling- some plastics can be melted and then molded to make new articles. Not all 
plastics can be recycled. The ones that can be recycled have to be sorted out, which takes 
time and money  
iv. 
Cracking- some plastics can be melted, then cracked and then re-polymerized to make 
new articles  
â€¢ Plastics has now been made biodegradable but many are not 

Polymer structure 
â€¢ To add an addition polymer you have to put the name of the monomer inside the brackets and 
put â€˜polyâ€™ in front 
â€¢ Some polymers are often called by their common names so it is not always easy to deduce the 
structure from the name of the monomer  
From monomer to polymer 
â€¢ Write down the formulae for the number of monomer units you want but change each double 
bond to a single bond 
â€¢ Draw single bonds between the monomer units 
â€¢ Put continuation bonds at either end of the chain to show that the chain carries on in the same 
way 
We can also write the structure of the polymer much more simply: 
â€¢ Draw the structure of the monomer but change the double bond to a single bond 
â€¢ Put continuation bonds at either end of the molecule  
â€¢ Put square brackets through the continuation bonds 
â€¢ Put an n at the bottom right-hand corner. This means that the unit repeats itself n times 
From polymer to monomer 
You can find the structure of the monomer from a diagram of the polymer: 
â€¢ Identify the repeating unit in the polymer and draw this  
â€¢ Ignore the brackets, the continuation bonds and the n 
â€¢ Make the single bond between the carbon atoms of the polymer into a double bond  
Polyamides and polyesters 
â€¢ We make addition polymer by joining the monomers together to make a long chain  
â€¢ No other substance is formed 
â€¢ However, many polymers such as nylon and Terylene are formed in a different way-by 
condensation polymerization 
â€¢ In condensation polymerization, the monomers react together to form the polymer and another 
product 
â€¢ The other product is usually a small such as water or hydrogen chloride 
â€¢ We say that the small molecule is eliminated 
â€¢ Condensation polymerization usually involves two different monomer, each with a different 
functional group 
â€¢ These groups react together to form the polymer 
Polyamides 
â€¢ Nylon is a typical polyamide 
â€¢ The two types of monomer that form a polyamide are carboxylic acids and amines 
â€¢ An amine is a compound with an ğ‘ğ»2 functional group 
â€¢ A carboxylic acid reacts with an amine to form an amide 

â€¢ This type of reaction, where two molecules join together and a small molecule is eliminated is 
called a condensation reaction  
â€¢ Each monomer has two functional group  
â€¢ We put the word di- in front of the names to show that there are two functional groups per 
monomer 
â€¢ Because each end of the monomer has a reactive functional group, a long chain is formed 
Polyesters 
â€¢ Terylene is a typical polyester 
â€¢  The two types of monomer that form a polyester are carboxylic acids and alcohols 
â€¢ An ester linkage is formed
summary_text: Plastics and proteins are macromolecules made up of repeating repeating units . We make plastics from lots of small molecules that join together to form long chains . Polymerization is called polymerization . Plastics are particular types of polymers that can be molded . Many plastics are non-biodegradable, meaning they are not broken down in the soil or water .  Many polymers such as nylon and Terylene are formed in a different way-by condensation polymerization . Each monomer has two functional groups which react together to form the polymer and another product . This type of reaction is called a condensation reaction .

Unit 2: Atoms and Elements 
Atoms, Elements and Compounds  
â€¢ The sub atomic particle in an atom are protons, neutrons, and electrons 
â€¢ A proton has a charge of +1 and a relative mass of 1 
â€¢ A neutron has no charge and a relative mass of 1 
â€¢ An electron has a charge of -1 and a negligible mass of 0. 0054 
â€¢ Atoms are neutral because they have equal numbers of protons and neutrons 
â€¢ The number of protons and neutrons in an atom is called the nucleon or atomic mass number 
â€¢ Numbers arranged in order of their proton number in the periodic table  
Elements, Compound and Mixtures 
â€¢ Elements are substances made up of one type of atom 
â€¢ A compound is a substance made up of two or more different types of atoms joined together 
â€¢ A molecule is the same or different atoms joined together by covalent bonds 
â€¢ A mixture contains two or more elements or compounds that are not chemically joined together. 
Mixtures do not have a fixed composition. The substances in a mixture can be separated by 
physical means. 
Electronic Structure 
â€¢ Electrons are arranged in shells or energy levels around the nucleus 
â€¢ Electrons spin in orbits around the nucleus constantly 
â€¢ The arrangement of electrons in shells in called electronic configuration 
â€¢ The first shell contains a maximum of 2 electrons, the second, third and fourth shell hold a 
maximum of 8 electrons 
â€¢ The electrons in the outer shell are called the valence or valency electrons 
â€¢ The valence electrons are important to determine the chemical properties of elements 
â€¢ Elements in the periodic table are grouped according to the number of valence electrons 
Isotopes 
â€¢ Atoms of the same element with the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons 
â€¢ If an isotope is radioactive its nucleus is unstable and so it breaks down over a period of time (it 
decays). As it decays the nucleus gives out tiny particles or rays. We call theses isotopes: 
radioisotopes. The radiation given out by radioisotopes can be harmful 
â€¢ Although radioisotopes are harmful they are useful: 
i. 
Medicinal purposes: treatment of cancer cells, thyroid glands, for locating tumors and 
sterilizing medical equipment 
ii. 
Industrial-used to check for leaks in gas and oil pipelines and regulate the thickness of 
paper during manufacture  
 
 
 
 

Metals and Non-metals  
Physical properties  
Metals  
Non-metals  
Have high densities (exceptions: Group I metals 
and gallium) 
Have low densities 
Have high melting and boiling points (exceptions: 
Group I metals and mercury) 
Low melting and boiling points (exception: 
carbon and silicon) 
Hard, cannot be scratched easily and strong 
(exceptions: Group I metals, mercury, gallium) 
Soft, can be scratched easily (exception: 
diamond) 
Good conductors of electricity  
Do not conduct electricity (exception: graphite) 
Good conductors of heat 
Do not conduct heat (exception: graphite) 
Malleable 
Brittle 
Ductile 
Not ductile 
Lustrous  
Dull surface (exceptions: graphite and iodine) 
Sonorous  
Not sonorous  
 
Chemical Properties 
Metals 
Non-metals 
Metal oxides are basics 
Non-metal oxides are acidic 
Metals react with acids to give off hydrogen gas 
Non-metals do not react with acids 
When they react, metals form positive ions by 
losing electrons 
When they react, non-metals form negative ions 
by gaining electrons (exception: hydrogen)
summary_text: Atoms are neutral because they have equal numbers of protons and neutrons . Elements are substances made up of one type of atom . A molecule is the same or different atoms joined together by covalent bonds . A mixture contains two or more elements or compounds that are not chemically joined together .

Carbohydrates 
â€¢ Carbohydrate literally means carbon and water  
â€¢ So the empirical formula for a carbohydrate is: ğ¶ğ‘¥(ğ»2ğ‘‚)ğ‘¦ 
â€¢ But even simple carbohydrates are quite complex molecules 
â€¢ We can simplify the structure of glucose to show only those groups which react to form glucose 
polymers 
â€¢ We give the name monosaccharides to simple sugars such as glucose: mono means â€˜oneâ€™ and 
saccharide means sugar  
â€¢ We can join monosaccharide monomers together to make polymers called polysaccharides 
â€¢ You can see that this is a condensation polymerization  
â€¢ The monosaccharide monomers have joined together and the water has been eliminated 
â€¢ The linkage in these sugar polymers is called a glyosidic linkage  
â€¢ The general formula for a polysaccharide made from glucose is (ğ¶6ğ»10ğ‘‚5)ğ‘›- glucose with water 
removed 
â€¢ Two common sugar polymers found in plants are starch and cellulose: 
â– Starch is found in rice, pasta and potatoes. It provides us with most of the carbohydrate 
in our diet. Starch is made of glucose monomers arranged either in long chains or 
branched chains 

â– Cellulose is found in the cell walls of plants. It is also a polymer of glucose. But the 
glucose molecules are arranged in a different way 
The hydrolysis of carbohydrates 
â€¢ When we heat polysaccharides with hydrochloric acid they are hydrolyzed to simple sugars 
â€¢ When starch is hydrolyzed the glyosidic linkages break and simple sugars are formed 
â€¢ The hydrochloric acid acts as a catalyst in the reaction  
â€¢ In our bodies, starch is hydrolyzed to glucose using different enzymes 
Identifying hydrolysis products 
â€¢ The simple sugars formed by the hydrolysis of polysaccharides can be identified using paper 
chromatography 
â€¢ Because sugars are colorless, we have to use a locating agent so they show up on a 
chromatogram 
â€¢ We spray the chromatogram with a mixture of tin (II) chloride and a chemical called N-
phenylenediamine  
â€¢ We then warm the chromatogram in an oven to develop the color 
â€¢ You cannot always identify a sugar or an amino acid from a chromatogram by simple 
chromatography  
â€¢ This is because some compounds have the same or similar Rf values 
â€¢ We overcome this by using two-dimensional chromatography: 
â€¢ We carry out the chromatography as usual  
â€¢ We allow the paper to dry hen turn it around 90Â° and carry out chromatography using a different 
solvent 
â€¢ Only then do we spray the chromatogram with a locating agent 
Fermentation 
â€¢ Nearly all chemical reactions in living things are catalyzed by enzymes 
â€¢ Enzymes are particular types of protein that act as biological catalysts 
â€¢ But unlike inorganic catalysts they are very sensitive to changes in temperature 
â€¢ They work best between 30Â°C and 40Â°C  
â€¢ If the temperature is too low they work more slowly 
â€¢ If the temperature is too high they lose their structure and donâ€™t work 
â€¢ We say they are denatured 
â€¢ Most enzymes will not work above a temperature of about 50Â°C 
â€¢ Bacteria and yeast produce enzymes that catalyze fermentation reaction in organic materials 
â€¢ Fermentation us the breakdown of organic material with effervescence and release of heat 
â€¢ For thousands of years, ethanol has been made by fermentation  
â€¢ Ethanol is an excellent solvent and a good fuel, as well as being an important starting point for 
making other chemicals 
Fermentation of glucose 
â€¢ A wide range of vegetable material can be fermented  
â€¢ The most commonly used substances for making ethanol are sugars and starch 

â€¢ The bacteria and yeast that cause fermentation are found on the surface of many plants, as well 
as in air 
â€¢ When we carry fermentation to produce ethanol, we use a particular form of yeast so that 
unwanted reactions do not occur 
â€¢ The fermentation of glucose produces ethanol and carbon dioxide 
â€¢ The reaction tales place in the absence of air- it is anaerobic  
â€¢ The reaction will occur until about 14% ethanol is present in the mixture 
â€¢ If the ethanol concentrations gets much higher than this the yeast will die 
â€¢ The ethanol is separated from the reaction mixture by fractional distillation

â€¢ Ethanol can be made by fermentation using a variety of plant sources 
â€¢ Sugar cane waste is fermented to ethanol for use as a fuel for cars 
â€¢ It is either mixed with petrol to form a fuel called a gasohol or used by itself 
â€¢ Ethanol is a cheaper fuel than petrol- it does not produce as much pollution 
â€¢ The ethanol made by fermentation comes from a renewable resource 
â€¢ It is potentially â€˜carbon neutralâ€™: the carbon dioxide released into the atmosphere by burning the 
ethanol is balanced by the carbon dioxide absorbed from the atmosphere by sugar cane during

Structure and Bonding 
Ionic bonding  
â€¢ An ion is an electrically charged particle, it forms when atoms gain or lose electrons 
â€¢ Most atoms do not have a full outer shell so they react to become stable 
â€¢ Ions have the noble gas electronic structure with a complete outer shell of electrons 
â€¢ The full outer shell of 8 electrons is called a stable octet 
â€¢ The attraction between positive ions and negative ions is called ionic bonding 
â€¢ Ionic bonding happens when a metal and a non-metal react together and electrons are 
transferred  from the outer shell of the metal to the outer shell of the non-metal  
Covalent bonding 
â€¢ Covalent bonding happens when two non-metals share a pair of electrons  
â€¢ The pairs of electrons that are not used in bonding are called lone pairs 
â€¢ A double covalent bond is formed when two pairs of electrons are shared between two atoms 
â€¢ A triple covalent bond is formed when three pairs of electrons are shared between two atoms 
â€¢ The valency of an atom can be defines as the number of electrons gained or lost to form a 
complete shell in an ionic or covalent bond 
Ionic vs covalent bonding 
â€¢ In ionic bonding the attractive forces between the positive and negative ions result in the 
formation of a giant ionic structure. The ions are regularly arranged in the crystal. This 
arrangement carries on in three dimensions throughout the crystal. This three-dimensional 
network is called a crystal lattice. The electrostatic attractive forces between ions act in all 
directions and are very strong. It takes a lot of energy to overcome these forces. This is why 
giant ionic structures have high melting and boiling points 
â€¢ The covalent bonds within molecules are very strong. However, the forces between the 
separate molecules are weak. These weak forces are called intermolecular forces 
â€¢ Since the forces between molecules are weak it only needs a little energy to overcome these 
forces and get the molecules to move away from each other. This is why molecular 
substances have low melting and boiling points 
â€¢ Ionic compounds have high melting and boiling points because of the strong forces between 
the ions in the giant ionic lattice 
â€¢ Covalent bonds have low melting and boiling points because the intermolecular forces are 
weak 
â€¢ Ionic compounds are soluble in water but insoluble in organic solvents. They are soluble in 
water because the water molecules are able to separate the ions 
â€¢ Covalent bonds are insoluble in water 
â€¢ Ionic compounds only conduct electricity only when molten or when dissolved in water 
â€¢ Covalent compounds do not conduct electricity  
Giant Covalent Structures 
â€¢ There is a network of covalent bonds throughout the whole structure 
â€¢ Giant covalent structures have a rigid three dimensional network of strong covalent bonds 
throughout the crystal. It takes a lot of energy to break through these bonds. So unlike simple 
molecules, giant covalent structures have high melting and boiling points 
â€¢ Different forms of the same element are called allotropes 
 

Diamond 
â€¢ Carbon forms 4 bonds with other carbon atoms 
â€¢ Carbons link together to form a giant lattice 
â€¢ High melting and boiling points 
â€¢ Cannot be scratched easily 
â€¢ Used for cutting and drilling metal and glass 
â€¢ Form glittering colour-less crystals for jewellery  
Graphite 
â€¢ Atoms are arranged in layers 
â€¢ Each carbon atom is joined to three carbon atoms 
â€¢ These are arranged in hexagons 
â€¢ Bonding within is layers strong 
â€¢ Bonding between layers is weak 
â€¢ High melting and boiling points 
â€¢ Layers can slide over each other if force is applied 
â€¢ Slippery feel and can flake off so can be used as a lubricant 
â€¢ Graphite can drift along layers when voltage is applied 
Silicon (IV) oxide/ silicon dioxide 
â€¢ Sand is largely silicon dioxide 
â€¢ Silicon dioxide found in quartz has a similar structure to diamond 
â€¢ Each silicon atom is bonded to 4 oxygen atoms but each oxygen atom is only bonded to 2 
silicon atoms (SIğ‘‚2) 
Metallic Bonding 
â€¢ Metals from a third type of giant structure. The metal atoms are packed closely together in a 
regular arrangement. Because they are so close together, the valence electrons tend to move 
away from their atoms. A sea of free, delocalised electrons is formed surrounding a lattice of 
positively charged metal ions. The positively charged ions are held together by their strong 
attraction to the mobile electrons which move in between the ions. This is metallic bonding, 
the electrostatic attraction between electrons and the metal ions act in all directions.  
â€¢  Most metals have high melting and boiling points because it takes a lot of energy to weaken 
the strong forces of attraction between the metal ions and the delocalised electrons in the 
lattice 
â€¢ Metals are good conductors of electricity and heat because when voltage is applied, the 
delocalised electrons move through the metal lattice towards the positive pole of a cell. 
Conduction of heat is due to vibration of the atoms passing on energy from one atom to the 
next. 
â€¢ Metals are malleable and ductile because of the regular arrangement of their atoms, therefore 
when a force is applied, the layers can slide over each other.

The positively charged ions are held together by their strong attraction to the mobile electrons which move in between the ions . This is metallic bonding, the electrostatic attraction between electrons and the metal ions act in all directions . Metals are malleable and ductile because of the regular arrangement of their atoms .

Electricity and Chemistry 
Conductors and Insulators 
Conductors 
â€¢ Conductors are substances which have a low resistance to the passage of electricity. In other 
words they allow electricity to flow through them easily. 
â€¢ Metals and graphite conduct electricity because they have mobile valence electrons in their 
structures 
â€¢ Copper is used in electrical wiring because it is a good conductor of electricity, it is ductile and 
easily purified by electrolysis  
â€¢ Thick wires carry a larger electric current than thin wires ïœ we use very thick wires in high 
voltage power lines to reduce friction, and reduce the amount of heat energy produced.  
â€¢ Steel-cored aluminium cables are used in high voltage power lines because aluminium is a good 
conductor and steel strengthens the cable  
â€¢ Aluminium has a low density and is resistant to corrosion. 
Insulators 
â€¢ An insulator is  substance that resists the flow of an electric current, it does not conduct 
electricity  
â€¢ Insulators do not conduct electricity as they do not have mobile electrons  
â€¢ Examples include; plastics, glass, and ceramic materials  
â€¢ PVC plastics are useful insulators- they are flexible and non-biodegradable 
â€¢ Used for covering electrical wires or as short circuits in electrical equipment  
â€¢ Less useful when high current is used-heat easily melts plastic 
â€¢ Glass and ceramics are useful insulators-have high melting and boiling points 
â€¢ Used in high voltage electricity towers to keep wires from touching metal pylons or each other  
â€¢ Ceramics are not affected by water or air and can be moulded into complex shapes

electrons to enter the electrolyte. A cathode is negatively charged

Exothermic reactions

Following the progress of a reaction 
To find the rate of reaction, we can either: 
i. 
Measure how quickly the reactants are used up 
ii. 
Measure how quickly the products are formed 
Calculating the rate of reaction depends on measuring something that changes with time, for example, 
volume of gas, mass of the reaction mixture or the amount of light transmitted through a solution  
â€¢ There are many methods for measuring rate of reaction  
â€¢ You can use any property that changes during a reaction  
â€¢ You could use a pH meter or an electrical conductivity meter if hydrogen ions are present 
â€¢ You could also record changes in pressure for reactions involving gases

Catalysts  
â€¢ A catalyst speeds up the rate of reaction but it is not used up in the reaction itself

â€¢ A catalyst works by allowing the reactants to get close together on its surface so less energy is 
needed to get the reaction to occur

Enzymes 
â€¢ Enzymes are proteins made by living cells, they are biological catalysts 
â€¢ Enzymes in yeast cells are used as a catalyst in making enzymes, enzymes made by bacteria are 
used in biological detergents  
â€¢ Enzymes work in a limited range of temperature and pH

Concentration affecting rate of reaction 
â€¢ Increasing the concentration of reactants increases the rate of reaction

The collision theory  
â€¢ For a reaction to take place, there must be a collision between the reactant particles 
â€¢ But not every collision leads to reaction, some are unsuccessful

Chemical Reactions 
Reversible Reactions 
â€¢ In a reversible reaction, the products can react to form the original products again  
Heating hydrated salts 
â€¢ When salt crystals have water as part of their structure we say that they are hydrated 
â€¢ We call the water in the salt, the water of crystallisation 
â€¢ When the crystals are heated the water of the crystallisation is lost 
â€¢ We are left with an anhydrous substance 
â€¢ Anhydrous means without water  
Equilibrium  
Equilibrium reactions have particular features: 
â€¢ The reactants or products must not escape from the reaction mixture, we call this is a closed 
system 
â€¢ At equilibrium the reactants are constantly being changed to products and the products are 
being changed back to reactants. We say that this is dynamic equilibrium 
â€¢ In dynamic equilibrium the concentration of reactants and products are fixed  
â€¢ At equilibrium the concentration of the reactants and products do not change  
â€¢ This is because the rate of the forward reaction is the same as the rate of the reverse reaction 
â€¢ The equilibrium can be approached from either direction  
â€¢ We can start with only the reactants or products 
â€¢ Whichever we start with, we end up with fixed concentrations of reactants and products in the 
equilibrium mixture 
â€¢ The position of equilibrium tells us how far the reaction goes in favour if the reactants or 
products 
â€¢ If the concentration of the products is greater than the concentration of the reactants we say that 
equilibrium is towards the right- it favours the products 
â€¢ If the concentration of reactants is greater than the concentration of products, we say that the 
position of equilibrium is to the left- it favours the reactants  
Shifting equilibrium  
â€¢ Catalyst do not have an effect on the position of equilibrium they speed up both the forward and 
backward reactions equally 
Changing the concentration 
â€¢ When the concentration of the reactant is increased, the equilibrium moves to the right  
â€¢ Adding more reactants unbalances the equilibrium  
â€¢ So the equilibrium moves to the right to form more products until the equilibrium is restored 
â€¢ In this way the relative concentrations of products and reactants are the same as before 
â€¢ When the concentration of a product is increases, the equilibrium moves to the left 
â€¢ Products are changed into reactants until the equilibrium is rstored 
 

Changing the pressure 
â€¢ Pressure can only affect reactions where the is a gas in the equation  
â€¢ If there are more moles of gas on the left than the right  
â€¢ An increase in pressure moves the reaction to the right 
â€¢ This happens because increasing the pressure squashes the molecules closer together, 
increasing their concentration 
â€¢ The reaction mixture tries to overcome this by moving the equilibrium to the right so that the 
overall number of molecules is reduced 
â€¢ Decreasing the pressure has the opposite effect  
â€¢ It pushes the reaction to the left 
â€¢ If there are equal volumes of gas on both sides of the equation, increasing the pressure has no 
effect  
Changing the temperature  
â€¢ If the reaction is exothermic in the forward reaction, it will be endothermic in the reverse reaction  
â€¢ So for an exothermic reaction when temperature increases, the equilibrium shifts in favour of the 
reverse reaction  
â€¢ It favours the endothermic change when heat is taken in  
â€¢ In an endothermic reaction, the opposite happens 
â€¢ Increasing the temperature moves the reaction to the right to favour the products 
â€¢ It favours the exothermic change where heat is given out
summary_text: In a reversible reaction, the products react to form the original products again . This is because the rate of the forward reaction is the same as the reverse reaction . Catalyst do not have an effect on the position of equilibrium they speed up both the forward and reverse reactions .

Business Activity 
â€¢ A need is a good or service essential for living 
â€¢ A want us a good or service which people would like to have, but which is not essential for living. Peopleâ€™s want are unlimited 
â€¢ The economic problem-there exist unlimited wants but limited resources to produce the goods and services to satisfy those 
wants. This creates scarcity. 
â€¢ Scarcity is the lack of sufficient products to fulfil the total wants of the production 
â€¢ Factors of production are those resources needed to produce goods and services. There are four factors of production: 
1. 
Land- this includes all natural resources 
2. Labor- the number of people available to make products 
3. Capital- the finance, machinery and equipment necessary to manufacture goods 
4. Enterprise-this is the skill and risk-taking ability of the person who combines the other factors of production to 
produce a good or service 
â€¢ Unlimited wants + Limited Resources = scarcity 
â€¢ Opportunity cost is the next best alternative given up by choosing another item 
Specialization 
â€¢ Specialization occurs when people and businesses concentrate on what they are best at 
â€¢ Specialization is now very common because: 
1. 
Specialized machinery and technology are now widely available 
2. Increasing competition means that businesses need to keep costs low 
3. Most people recognize the higher living standards can result from being specialized 
â€¢ Division of labor is when the production process us split up into different tasks and each worker performs one of these tasks. It 
is a form of specialization. 
Advantages  
â€¢ Workers are trained in one task and specialize in this-this increases efficiency and output 
â€¢ Less time wasted moving from one workbench to another 
Disadvantages 
â€¢ Workers can become bored doing just one job-efficiency may fall 
â€¢ If one worker is absent and no one else can do the job, production might be stopped 
 
The Purpose of Business Activity  
â€¢ The purpose of all businesses is to combine the factors of production to make products that satisfy peopleâ€™s wants. 
â€¢ Business activity therefore: 
1. 
Combines scarce factors 
2. Produces goods and services 
3. Employs people 
Added Value 
â€¢ Added value is the difference between the selling price of a product and the cost if bought in materials and components.  
â€¢ Added value is important as it is able to cover the expenses of a business and increase profitability 
â€¢ Added value can be increased by increasing the selling price but maintaining the cost of materials or reducing the cost of the 
materials and maintaining the selling price.

Market Research 
â€¢ A product orientated business is one whose main focus of activity is on the product itself 
â€¢ A market orientated business is one which carries out market research to find out consumer wants before a 
product is developed and produced 
â€¢ A marketing budget is a financial plan for the marketing of a product or product range for some specified period 
of time. It specifies how much money is available to market the product or product range for some specified 
time. It specifies how much money is available to market the product or range, so that the Marketing department 
know how much they should spend 
Why is market research needed? 
â€¢ Market research is the process of gathering, analysing and interpreting information about a market 
Market research is carried out to find out the likes and dislikes of the consumers, the amount they are willing to pay for 
it, the place they are willing to buy it and the methods of promotion needed to be used to advertise and distribute the 
products successfully. 
There are 2 types of information: 
â€¢ Quantitative information which answers the questions about the quantity of something  
â€¢ Qualitative information which answers questions where an opinion or judgement is necessary 
Both types are gathered as a result of: 
â€¢ Primary/Field research is the collection and collation of original data via direct contact with potential or existing 
customers, also called field research 
â€¢ Secondary/desk research is information that has already been collected and is available for us by others. 
Primary Research 
The process of primary research 
1. What is the purpose of the market research 
2. Decide on the most suitable method of research

â€¢ The marketing mix is a term which is used to describe all the activities that go into marketing a product or service. These are 
often summarised as the four Ps.

â€¢ Product 
â€¢ Price 
â€¢ Place i.e. channels of distribution

â€¢ Consumer services- these are services that are produced for people 
â€¢ Producer goods- these are goods that are produced for other businesses 
â€¢ Producer services- these are services produced for other services  
A successful product is capable of: 
â€¢ Satisfies existing needs and wants of consumers 
â€¢ Design, product, quality and reliability should be consistent with the productâ€™s brand image 
â€¢ Capable of stimulating new wants from the consumer 
â€¢ Not too expensive (relative to price charged)

â€¢ Has something very distinctive that makes it appear different  
Product development  
1. 
Generate ideas from employees, sales department, research and development department, customer suggestions and 
competitorsâ€™ products
